description:
I didn't take any photos because I was too busy enjoying the sushi experience by the bar, but everything was d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s.

We went with Omakase and definitely got a variety of dishes. You begin with some cold apps, start going ham on nigiri, and then some hot apps are thrown in. Definitely loved doing omakase because it was comprised of a lot of items that I would have never personally ordered. And when you do omakase, you can always tell the chef what you would rather not have and if there's something you have been craving (which for me was yellowtail :) ). 

I compared the experience to Hinata (my most recent omakase experience in the city), and I noticed the flavors on the nigiri were well balanced. I could actually taste the fish, then everything else it was seasoned with. Rather be overwhelmed with wasabi/seasoning. 

Omakase is definitely pricey so if you have a budget in mind, I'd voice your concerns before starting your journey. But it was definitely delicious and I would come back. Service was great, I had a 5 star experience personally.
author: Arezou A.

description:
This place used to be pretty good, but every time I go it seems to get worse and more expensive. This last time, some of the nigiri had so much Wasabi that my nose coulda fell off.

Might as well go to Saru in Noe or a cheaper place.
author: Jacob H.

description: GREAT GREAT GREAT! We had the omakase menu and had so much food, we could barely walk home. Everything looked amazing and tasted even better - I liked that they told us that they don't serve soy sauce - it showed they had an opinion about the food and wanted us to get the full experience and we certainly did. We had sake with it and paid 250 dollars for two - worth every dollar.
author: Reham B.

description: Nigiri was good.  Enjoyed ankimo, sanma and ao ebi, especially.  I didn't understand why sushi rice in maki was dry though.  This may be a good place if you want to drink sake and pick some sushi. Thought of giving 4 stars but considering the price vs value... ranging from $6 to $15 for a piece, not 2 pieces is a bit too much?
author: M G.

description:
***Restaurant Week Edition***

A proud participant of SF's Restaurant Week, they are offering a prix fixe menu of 3 items, their fusion hot dogs consisting of either the Mapo Dog, Curry Dog, Kimchi Dog, Vegetarian Dog, and Okonomiyaki Dog, as well as your choice of Maki, be it Negi-Bincho, Tekka, Kappa, Negi-Hama, Abokado, and Ume Shiso. All served with ICHI's famous Japanese potato salad. 

I decided on the Mapo Dog and the Negi-Hama (yellowtail) maki, along with other a la carte items. 

My order:

Mapo Dog - This is probably the most interesting hot dog I've ever encountered and oddly enough, it worked. These mini frankfurters were served with traditional house-made minced pork mapo tofu poured on top and sprinkled with sliced scallions and sesame seeds throughout. A fusion I didn't quite understand at first, but the flavors began to meld as I continued eating. Strangely enough, this combination felt surprisingly natural. 

Yellowtail Maki - Fresh and tasty. No complaints here. 

Spicy Tuna Roll - This was delicious. Nice and spicy. You get about 4 pieces. 

Spicy Hotate - This scallop was fresh and great. I'm extremely picky about scallops and these came out soft and non-offensive. Perfect. 

Their famous potato salad - This was beautifully homemade and full of American-Japanese flavor. A great medley of fusion ingredients. 

Last, but not least, I ordered the Yama Shioyaki, which is fish collar. I asked the server what the chef recommended that day, and he said it would be the Big Eye Snapper because it would be the most flavorful. Not for the squeamish or faint at heart, but if you enjoy fish in its entirety, the Kintokidai Snapper is an absolute beauty. It's served with its head, but when plucking away at its collar, you'll discover some of the softest, moistest, and most luscious bites. 

What I mostly appreciate is that they served my meal with fresh grated wasabi. Oh yes, I do notice. 

Restaurant is small, but really cozy. Service is knowledgeable and incredibly friendly! 

I'll happily return, restaurant week or not!
author: Ann S.

description:
I love ICHI.  We've recently been to Robin and Hinata - both quite good - but we keep coming back here.  Even though we have to Uber here from our house, I like to think of it as our beloved neighborhood spot.

The restaurant itself is super cute and inviting.  The size is ideal to feel like you're getting lots of attention from the sushi chefs, and I love the decor....the blue walls, the art made from uni boxes, etc.

The first time I went here, I was actually underwhelmed....then I realized we made the mistake of trying to order a la carte and not really understanding anything.  You MUST do omakase when you come here.  There's no minimum or maximum, so you can make it as affordable as you want.

We usually do between 10-12 pieces per person, plus two a la carte appetizers, and leave feeling very satisfied....and we normally pay about what you would for a set omakase menu at other spots (about $95/person).  All of the sushi chefs are incredibly nice and - unlike other places - are open to avoiding things you know you don't like (raw shrimp) or incorporating things you love (uni).  The fish has always tasted very fresh to me.  The rice has always been lightly sticky and lightly vinegar'd.  And I love the creative preparations.  Yuzu sauce, lemon salt, charring, etc.

The servers are always friendly and appropriately attentive.

I really love this spot!
author: Tay H.

description: I loved the sushi. The chef was friendly and served amazingly tasty Nigiris. Amazing flavors.
author: Mayra T.

description:
This is my favorite Sushi place for Omakase!! Just ask for sushi chef Tadashi San and be prepared to have your mind blown away by all the deliciously. 
You pick how many pieces you want and he will do the rest!! Every time is an epic journey of top notch sushi.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Don't know about the sushi! Because we walked in....empty restaurant but they could not seat us because they were waiting on reservation! Oh come on! The all the seats were reserved......i smell something fishy here. 
Maybe we were not their prefer customers base.
author: Ramie S.

description:
When it occupied a much larger venue across the street, ICHI didn't just offer nigiri sushi and sushi rolls, but it also had a good selection of hot items like yakitori and larger entrees. Since I last dined there, the chef has had a health scare and has unfortunately downsized the restaurant and moved it into its smaller original space. 

Nevertheless, when I last visited, it was for omakase, which should still apply to Ichi's current venue and reincarnation. I found it to be a much better experience than its currently middling Yelp rating would imply. 

One caveat with the omakase, though: it's not a prix fixe affair, but one where you run up a potentially unlimited tab until you're full. That having been said, for the 16-18 pieces of nigiri sushi and other small dishes that I got, I felt the whole experience was of good quality and value. 

Seared or specially seasoned items were especially yummy, whether a seared piece of medai (Japanese butterfish) with sake soy reduction and its skin left on, a nicely glazed piece of shima aji (striped jack), a serving of Hokkaido hotategai (scallop) with green tea salted yuzu, or a beautifully seared and prepared piece of engawa (fluke fin / flounder's edge). 

Another highlight was the Canadian botan ebi (spot prawn) which was presented live, and then (sadly) prepared super-fresh - that is, slaughtered on the spot. It did indeed taste incredibly fresh, with the remainder of the shrimp (its head) then served fried. 

Overall, the omakase was quite a satisfying, value-friendly experience where you get to try lots of different pieces of fish, and where you get to see the sushi chef's skills up close and personal. While Ichi might not have the hype of a Michelin star, it's still an enjoyable, high-quality experience.
author: Vincent L.

description: Seriously... avoid this place at all costs. The only redeeming factor was that my server (a tall guy with salt and pepper hair) was pretty friendly. The hostess/manager/whatever her role is was condescending and dismissive. She made it quite clear she had absolutely no interest in accommodating me at all. To start, I ordered the chef's choice sashimi plate- the fish was definitely below average quality, at a way above average price price. I was going to get the miso clam dish next, but I was so turned off my the hostess' attitude and the poor quality fish, I just cancelled the rest of my order, got my check and left. $35 later, I have a couple pieces of questionable fish in my belly and a bad taste in my mouth. I think I would have enjoyed watching my cash go through a paper shredder more than I enjoyed my experience at ICHI.
author: Alex B.

description:
Adorable and eclectic, and as it turns out, back to it's roots.

If you've walked down this oft-overlooked section of Mission, you've undoubtedly seen Ichi + Ni Bar. Unfortunately, that location is now closed and they have moved back to their smaller, more intimate location. 

For me, I had walked to a garage sale and found myself in an area I hadn't walked to before. Fortunately 5 minutes away ways Coco's, Fumi Japanese Curry, and a number of other great spots. But before I could get there I saw ICHI Sushi and even though I had sushi plans for dinner I saw hot dogs on the menu and I hadn't had a good dog in a while.

Though Yelp and the sign said they close at 2, the great server Laura waved me in. There were a few groups finishing up their late lunch so I had choice of wherever and decided on a table as the sushi bar was pretty empty. Later I saw why - the chef in the back corner was prepping the fish for dinner, cutting some, seasoning others. They looked great!

The lunch menu is a bit limited - the hot dogs, some basic maki rolls, some salads. Actually they have more drink options for lunch than food options. I went with the Japanese Dog, a Negi-Hama roll, and a glass of cold sake.

-Negi-Hama: your basic hamachi and scallion roll. Basically used to whet my appetite. 
-Japan Dog: This was intense, with the beef hot dog topped with bonito flakes. I mean topped. The tonkatsu mayo really made this work.
-I forget which cold sake I got, one of the house sakes, but it was really nice.

I regret I never went here for the omakase dinner, but seeing some of the fish get prepped was really neat. Definitely worth coming back for that and the great service.
author: Michael C.

description: 100% best sushi in San Francisco. Love coming here. Music is awesome, chefs are amazing, great for dates.
author: SS J.

description: Overpriced and undertasted! Please spare your $$$...go to robin. Omakase, akiko's...don't waste it here...the wait staff is super nice, but the guy who runs the place can't handle criticism....sorry but clams with ground beef drowned in soy is not my culinary experience. Everything fell flat!!!from unexciting selection to the owners acceptance of fault. As soon as I came up to tell him what it is I didnt like, he declared us as outsiders not able to eat. He nonetheless charged us the full omakase menu!!! The ponzu sauce is lemon juice with a splash of soy. Yup!!! No ponzu or truffle in sight...what an unfortunate experience. I really do wish this went better than robin or any other small plate izakaya restaurant! How come can't I post this???This bot is smarter than I am! Yelp's new feature! Done done done!!! Can you please post this now???????????????
author: Lev F.

description: Really nice sushi but it's way too bank. The beer was really overpriced as well. It's pretty far out too past the mission. Thoroughly enjoyed the service and venue for a double date. My fav fish was probably the trout and albacore. There's better and closer.
author: Young Y.

description: awesome authentic sushi vibes. we tried at least 8-9 different pieces & loved every one. Albacore tuna belly, scallop, & mackerel rolls are a dream. service friendly and fun. casual ambiance.
author: Shelby W.

description:
After patiently waiting 45 mins past our reservation we were finally seated. Ichi is incredibly small so I suggest not going in a group. Their largest table seated 4 and there's was only one of those.

We sat at the bar and order omakase with a very helpful and friendly chef. He stated he'd dress all of our fish for us and no soy sauce would be given. Each piece of fish he laid in front of us he explained in detail (its name, where it was from, sauce he used and preparation). The chef used very unique toppings/sauces I haven't seen at other sushi bars like: green tea salt, preserved pepper paste, Myer lemon salt, a myer lemon compote and a sake and soy reduction. Possibly all made in house? Well for sure the myer lemon ones were in house cause the chef said he had a myer lemon tree and brings the lemons to work to use. Very sustainable if you ask me.

Can't comment much on service since we sat at the bar and didn't really order any kitchen items. The hostess was very apologetic since we waited so long and sent out champagne which we did appreciate. So thank you!

Coulda so lived without the shigoku oysters (topped with caviar) at $6.50 a pop!
and the scallop tacos $16 a plate
author: Liz N.

description: Godsmacked to see our bill-- holy crap this place is over priced... and honestly, good but not 100 bucks a person with NO BOOZE good. Service was with an attitude. Save your money and go elsewhere- there are many great sushi places in the city that don't cost this much
author: Elisabeth P.

description: I cannot figure out why this place is on the eater 38 list for best sushi in San Francisco.   I was unimpressed and would never return.  The quality of the fish was below par and sushi was not good.  The rice was hard, cold and crunchy and there was way too much wasabi on the Nigiri.  The hostesses was not very friendly and the service was horrible.  Food took forever.  I went to the larger location down the block when that opened a few years ago and I didn't like that either. I thought I would give it another try in the smaller location given the reviews but after tonight I'm done.  Stay away.
author: JEFF B.

description: the head waitress was rude and had a sour look on her face as if she had eaten a wasp sandwich. the "no soy sauce unless we grant it" menu statement was bold, but when she saw one of our party dip a nigiri in it (which had only been granted for the maki), she promptly came over to sternly remind us not to use it. and, my goodness, it's eye-wateringly expensive.
author: Gavin C.

description: Places in the mission are always hit and miss. This one was a big mess. I don't mind the occasional mall-grade sushi if I'm really hungry, there are no other options, and it's priced appropriately; however, this place bills itself as a high-end and quality establishment and it's neither of those. Besides having mediocre quality fish they can't even get the sushi rice right.  To add insult to injury they offer a very amateur sake selection.  Last but not least we were greeted very abruptly and dismissive upon arrival needless to say this was an omen of what was to come. Caveat emptor.
author: Jonas V.

description: Thumbs down on the warm omakase items and awkward side dishes.  In the omakase, the nigiri had wayyy too much wasabi smeared under the fish, and was otherwise not seasoned well.  I like that wasabi burn when I eat cheap sushi rolls, not on what is supposed to be quality nigiri.  I will say goodbye to this place, which is sad because the staff have always been kind to us, so I am embarrassed for them to serve bad food at such a high price, because that makes it seem like they don't have respect for their customers.  I don't think that is necessarily the case, but that's the resulting impression.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Just a very underwhelming experience.  I like both cheaper end sushi and expensive sushi.  The sushi here felt a little a little off.  

This is not a place where you'll feel full.  For about $50 a person we each got a drink, shared one roll, one single skewer of meat, miso soup and two nigiri.  Anywhere else that might be a meal.  

I appreciate the restaraunts attention to flavor but enough about not putting soy sauce on our nigiri.  We were warned when we got soy sauce for our roll, remember it's for the roll only.  

Maybe it just wasn't my style, I like warmer happier restaurants.  This one gave me way too little food, the flavors were not up to par, and the service made me feel uncomfortable.  

The bathroom and decor are nice.
author: Kate G.

description: The last space was so much better. The food was way more innovative and worth the price point. I went a few weeks back and was very underwhelmed! It was $280 for 2 people. 2 glasses of wines, 3 very small beers and some sake. The rest was boring sushi. The garnishes were what you'd expect and a ho hum middle of the roast sushi place. The fish quality was fine but didn't melt in my mouth. At the old space I never felt that the fish was mediocre. Always exquisite..  A few of the kitchen dishes were good, the rice was not up to snuff. Not worth the price point. $140 would still have been too much but fair. Oh and left hungry as well.
author: Stephen G.

description:
When it comes to unique eats, Japan is one of the countries that brings out the best.  Its raw seafood is the most popular of all the palatable dishes.  My love for sushi never ends; therefore, I go to any sushi bars and try different kinds of fin fish and shellfish coming from the Tsukiji Market of Japan.  After many attempts, anything straight from the special menu is a hit and miss.  If there's any fish I haven't come across, I take it right away.

Last Thursday evening was a perfect moment at ICHI Sushi to try a pair of nigiri one last time.  I'm glad walk-ins are acceptable.  Plus, I get to sit where the sushi chefs are.  My first pair: kelp cured fluke of Busan, Korea.  No soy sauce needed; a little hint of lemon juice with less wasabi; taste good enough.  My second pair: blue shrimp of Caledonia.  But where are its respective fried shrimp heads?  That sushi chef with moustache and glasses said no heads.  Good grief!  I once tried shrimp heads that are fried and I love it.  Before I put the whole raw shrimp into my mouth, I asked the same sushi chef about the shrimp tail, and he said no tail.  Then, he take back the pair of shrimps and chopped off the shrimp tails, and give it back to me.  What on earth!?  Is that how he taught me!?  Headless, tailless; it's like there's no beginning, no end!  Reminds me that I'm missing something, which is why my mom tried to tell me to "have head have tail".  Anyways, time for a taste.  There's some of the soy sauce in the shrimp with a some presence of wasabi.  Done!

I came to ICHI Sushi bar for one good reason, sushi etiquette.  In one of the yelpers' photos, I've seen how they eat nigiri the right way, so I followed their example.  At first I came to have a seat, given a lotus leaf with some thin slices of ginger.  I used both my fingers instead of chopsticks; never laid one nigiri on a white plate.  See!  No need to waste water to clean the dish.  Hope you do the same.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Not so special. Computer went down and we had to wait 25 min to pay and get out. A little discount or a couple nigiri while we waited would have been classy, instead of just hard little seats and a cold draft from the open door.
author: cc c.

description: Ichi.  The sushi legend in La Lengua. Was in this tiny little place where Chef Tim would give you piece by piece dressed nigiri. Was a thing to treasure. They expanded to a very large space up the street a bit.  Now they are back in the tiny space - scaled back down to the roots.  Just a life change for the Chef; the bigger venue was always packed but I think he wanted something else right now.  All good to me especially since now they offer a lunch!  Japanese Hot Dogs, Tekka Don, and other great things here for the lunch service. Go for lunch, it's great. Go for dinner and just ask for the Omakase and let them guide you through a meal. Personally I'm happy to see it back in the more intimate venue and really my only problem is that I want to go here all the time. Chef Tim knows he's got a fan for life with me...well if he didn't, he'd know if he read this.
author: David S.

description:
I used to love the last, larger location with a large, diverse menu.  It was a fantastic restaurant. The new/current place (which is really the original location) is not nearly as good. 

The main problems: small portions. Overpriced. Limited menu (almost only sushi). 

The sushi was fine, but not good enough to overcome the high prices and small portions.  Every member of our group was hungry after our meal. 

Very disappointing experience.  I see no reason to ever go back.
author: Michael S.

description: Went for the omakase, which was simple yet creative and perfectly executed and delicious. Got the pickle plate on the aide and it was a tasty, cleansing accompaniment to the sushi. The staff were lovely, attentive, and charming. The space doesn't quite overwhelm you with ambience, and it's a quick way to unload a small fortune, but if you want great service and outstanding fish that's not even in the same universe as your typical sushi joint, this is your place.
author: Matt C.

description: So yummy. Super great and fresh sushi, and the Japanese hot dog was off the hook! Will definitely be back with friends!
author: Shawnna M.

description: The sushi rice was dry and the scallops didn't taste very fresh or good quality. The hotdogs were pretty good but for $9 it's a bit pricey. The decor and atmosphere was great tho!
author: Terrie C.

description:
Over the past 5 years living in the Caribbean I've always had to throw barracuda back out of fear of Ciguatera but tonight that was not the case! It was absolutely delicious and I highly recommend trying these lightly braised  little Japanese cudas. Thank you for flying these bad boys in and making it possible!

The waters I fish in the US Virgin Islands are home to barracuda and jacks but most of them harbor a nasty disease called Ciguatera. The fish seem to show no signs of distress, not that they could inform us, but when humans ingest the fish containing this disease it can cause an extremely unpleasant neurological reaction which it's effects sometimes never dissipate from the host. 

This is the best sushi restaurant I've ever experienced. For some reason everyone is beautiful as well. Stoked!
author: Brad S.

description:
A great gem in southern Mission. When our friend lived in SF, this is one of his favorite restaurants, so of course we came here when he was back in town!

I really liked my a la carte menu items. My friends got the omakase, which I tried bites of. To be honest, the fish and the rice were a bit on the dry side. He felt the same and said the omakase has been better. Still very good, but not at the incredible standard he's put it at.

We sat at the front, near the sushi bar, but keep in mind if you sit in the back section (the "Ni Bar"), you can't get an of the sushi items!

RESERVATIONS
Made about a week in advance on OpenTable for 8:15pm on a Thursday for three people.

THE COST
$213.53 before tip. Two of us had omakase, plus a la carte items, on beer, and one dessert.

OMAKASE
A great variety of sushi, cold (pickled veggies, cucumbers in a sweet sesame sauce. We liked the cucumber!), and hot (salmon broth, fish). Of the sushi, our faves were the yellowtail, katsuo skipjack, ocean trout inidashi, and uni.

RAW
* Medai Tataki (pork chicharron, ponzu vinaigrette, shichimi. $12 for 2pc) - 4 stars
Less pork than I though, mostly some sprinkled crunchy pieces of chicharron, but still great combination of flavors. The fish had a good texture.

SKEWERS
* Momo Yakitori (chicken thigh, tare. $4 one skewer) - 5 stars
Amazing. Juicy, full of flavor. Use the extra spices they sprinkle on the plate, and drizzle the meyer lemon. I usually don't like to drizzle lemons, but theirs are so juicy & sweet, I was able to even eat a slice. 

HOT
* Miso Asari Clams (pork, miso broth, kuro oil. $11) - 4.5 stars
So delicious! Before we even tasted it, we could smell all the spices. I thought it was sesame oil that made it smell so good, but whatever that kurt oil is made it amazing! It also had a kick of spice that we loved. This was a broth but it was very filling. The clams were little bursts of juicy meat. I only wish there was a little more pork and it wasn't ground so small. The spoon you get is really thick and makes it very difficult to scoop up all the pork!

DESSERT
* Granita ($7) - 3 stars
The only dessert option of the night. Interesting fruity/lime flavors, and for essentially a shaved ice it had a nice silky texture. But $7 for a small pile of flavored ice.. not really worth it in retrospect. I wish they had the matcha ice cream everyone posts about!
author: Ziyan C.

description: If as a paying customer, you wanted to be treated with dignity, respect and appreciated for your dollars, do yourself a favor and stay the hell away from this place. We came as a family of 4 and we were told there was seating only for two people. We asked if it's okay if 2 of us stand in the meanwhile. The manager to my face said yes. We wait, 2 of us sitting, 2 of hanging out. Other Tables open up and the 4 of us split up. The waitress was super nice. The manager makes a face. Another table for 4 opens up. We ask the waitress if the 4 of us can be together finally and she agrees. She even thanks us for being patient and making her life easier. We sit down only for the manager to come galloping down, saying that we have been creating issues from the beginning and making life difficult for him. He embarrasses his staff and us. There was nothing unreasonable we asked and we already been waiting 45 min at this point for our food and asked him if we could be seated. His response was for the 4 of us, 'this is not that kind of place'. I presume he meant we aren't classy enough.  He also lies saying he never said it was okay for us to wait. Why the hell would we wait for 45 min unless he asked us to. He then says there is tables only for 2 people now. 70% of the restaurant was empty. At this point I was beyond frustrated and we left the place. Condescending, elitist, rude , and one of the most horrible experiences I have ever had at a restaurant. Please stay away.
author: Nikhilesh N.

description:
Very over priced for very average sushi. Would not waste your money and would definitely not recommend. Also they had ants crawling on the ledge right next to our table, almost on the table. Horrible! 

While the food was not good, the service was, hence the single star.
author: Sydney S.

description: The best nigiri I have ever had.  Complex. Layered. Just sit at the bar.  Order the chefs menu and sake and enjoy the unique flavors.
author: Jessica M.

description:
I am very selective about my reviews. This is my only negative one. 

My realtor and friend were celebrating my new home so the I was not personally concerned about the cost, just to set the precedence that the price point is not a preempting factor. 

I was quite intrigued by the sushi selection as it was a variety that was not typical of my extensive mid to upper grade sushi experience. 

Nigiri sushi si $4-7 per piece. That means $8-14 per normal 2 piece serving. 

In lieu of hot sake (which is ok for upscale sushi establishment), I opted for a delightful rose'

Sake was average of 13 per glass/ 70+ per bottle. 

The restaurant took pride in cultivating the culinary taste of a variety of flavor with the fish. 

I can understand respecting a chef's pairing of flavors with taste.

HOWEVER, DO NOT ASK FOR SOY SAUCE, let alone wasabi. 

The staff will fight you and take you down. 

We made the cardinal sin of asking for soy sauce and wasabi. 

I am still stunned at the resistance I received at the request.

Laura did her best to explain that the chef took great care in selecting the flavors to not over power the fish. That was their "thing." 

When we persisted to request soy sauce and wasabi, she deferred to our server. 

We asked our server Amanda who again explained the chef's intentions. 

At the price point charged and tasting the sushi we pointed out that we respected the chef's intentions, but for our taste we preferred some soy sauce and wasabi. 

I finally had to get firm and ask whether they wanted to compromise our enjoyment of the expensive sushi for the sake of the chef's creative vision and insisted that I was the customer paying for my meal. 

Amanda finally complied by "slamming" down 2 dishes, soy sauce and wasabi in a way I have NEVER experienced before. 

Not only are we paying upper end prices, we are experiencing elitist service. 

At that point the celebration took a sour turn. 

I tasted each piece with and without the soy sauce and wasabi. I really enjoyed how the chef added the additional unique flavors. However, I am sorry, it was immensely complimented with a little soy and wasabi.

We had more sushi coming. 

Laura was able to rise above and move forward with a positive attitude that significantly helped to shift an uncomfortable experience to one that ended on a decent note. 

Amanda had lost me. It wasn't until the end of our meal and time for the tip that her attitude had changed. 

The bill before tax was $188 for 2 people. The sushi flavor was fun, but NOT worth the fight.

I don't know what my friend/realtor tipped, but the experience was soured enough that I will NEVER go there again. 

I graciously give them the 3 star rating for the freshness of the fish and creativeness of the flavor along with the intimate ambiance. However, the service soured me forever.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Let me begin with the Omakase is NOT fixed price and our server did not bring this to our attention, nor does it say on the menu. Most sushi places, do state on the menus or comes with a fixed price on your bill. Even though each dish came out flavorful and fresh, had we known about it not being fixed priced or that we were being charged for each individual dish we wouldn't have allowed them to bring out all 15 courses. Our server was good on asking us about food allergies, and how the Omakase works (they keep bringing out the dishes unless you say done) but we wish she let us know that your charged per dish/sushi and not fixed. More of a cost background would have helped (left the important part out!). We had also had made reservations and requested bar seating but didn't get to sit at the bar.  The host said that our reservations must have got messed up.  So that this also doesn't happen to you call and confirm your reservations and seating. Overall the sushi was good and fresh, but the experience wasn't that great.
author: Abby C.

description: The food here is amazing!! The service is horrible! I keep coming back only because they kill it when it comes to the menu. But the attitude from our server I could live with out or the 15 minute wait to get two pieces of maguro not ok.
author: Syed H.

description:
I was excited to try this place since I've heard a lot about it recently, and it is also featured on SF Eater's Heatmap. The restaurant itself is beautiful, with clean & modern furnishings. They also have a high top sushi bar that you can eat at. We were able to make reservations at the last minute as well which was very convenient! 

Since we've heard so many great things about ICHI, our expectations were a little high. Unfortunately they were a little let down which is why I gave 3 stars. The service was pretty slow. We felt like we had to keep waving down our server to put in our order, ask for water, ask for our check, etc.

They had a nice selection of sake, so we ordered the Dassai which was smooth, clean, & floral. However, we were bummed out because it was served to us in water glasses. This is the first time I've been served sake this way. Normally we get the beautiful flask and small ceramic sake cups which is half of the fun!

ROLLS: We shared the Spicy Tuna and California rolls. They were simply good. Nothing out of the ordinary. Each roll contained 6 pieces and portion size was average. 

SKEWERS: The Momo Yakitori was grilled perfectly and served with a light sauce. This was probably my favorite bite. My friend said her Butabara Kushiyaki (pork belly) was also tasty and well seasoned.

NIGIRI: My friend had the Salmon Roe but said it "tasted funny." Not sure what that really meant and I didn't want to try it after her comment. I had the Albacore Tuna which was tender and had a light sauce. I thought it was very good. The Wagyu Beef was a little dry though.

All in all, this place was good, but not outstanding. In my opinion, I think Pabu is better but I'm at least glad I got to try ICHI Sushi + Ni.
author: Chisholm T.

description: Hands-down one of the best sushi spots I've ever had . Very authentic very delicious have to try. The Torros amazing the snappers amazing albacore is on point.
author: Jayjay J.

description:
Super amazing service and the chef Joji is very friendly. He has his own menu and unique taste of sushi. I strongly recommend to sit at the bar in order to get the best experience! I would definitely come back again.

As for all the SOY SAUCE review on Yelp, please understand that "real" sushi doesn't need it because the chef would already create the perfect taste for each bite!
author: Yilin Y.

description: Ridiculously overpriced with bad service. If you come here, be prepared to leave hungry after paying a big check. Also, if you order from the non-sushi items, they delay the serving in such a way that you are "forced" to order from the sushi menu because you get so hungry waiting for your orders to come out.
author: Joanna L.

description: If you like really authentic sushi - nothing fried, no cream cheese, no rolls named after sports teams, this place is amazing. Not cheap, but worth it for special occasions.
author: Lorin L.

description:
If you are doing SF Restaurant Week - this is the BEST $15 Lunch.
Enjoy the potato salad, Maki, and a Japanese hot dog dressed with mapo, curry, kimchi, or okonomiyaki bits of flavor explosions.

Be wowed.
The potato salad with Jidori egg delights with its richness.
I relished the tart bite of ume boshi and shiso in the Maki.
The snap of the Japanese hot dog - enhanced with okonomiyaki bonito flakes and tonkatsu sauce tantalizes the tongue with texture.
Hot dogs are fun food!
author: Geri S.

description:
I have a hard time believing the price to value at this place is worth it. Especially when it comes to the quality of sushi I have had from both ICHI and ICHI + Ni. I have tasted all walks of sushi, from the low-end to the high-end omakase. I don't profess to be an expert on the topic, but I do know what value tastes like and I just didn't find that here. 

I paid well over $120 for a meal for 2 and we both left feeling famished. The portions were lack luster and for the amount of sashimi you get -- I was expecting to get higher quality fish. Nope. About the same as any other place. So why am I paying for individual pieces of nigiri? Odd. 

Anyway, you can pass. It's too overpriced for what you get.

I will say the staff is nice. The location is cute. Ambience is perfect. But again ... not worth it for the quality.
author: Sara M.

description: Great food and great service but ONE BIG PROBLEM. After spending almost $800, my friend and I  decided to split the tab. Because of a previous arrangement, he decided to add a very healthy tip on both of our behalves. That meant the tip box on my receipt was left empty. As a matter of  fact, I drew a line across the tip line. I found out a few days later, going through my credit card statement, that someone at the restaurant added a generous tip on my receipt. I called the restaurant and the manager promised to investigate. He was very cooperative, polite, and professional. But this sort of thing should never happen. Not to mention that a very healthy tip was included. Disappointed.
author: Arash Ari A.

description: Had reservations and was told we would have to wait for 25+ minutes after our reservation time for our table.  Do not book a reservation and put your credit card in.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Dined here with a party of six last night and had a fabulous meal start to finish - from drinks to appetizers to hot dishes to sushi. And service was impeccable.

Rather than reviewing each piece of food, though I could easily do that from memory, I'll highlight some revelatory moments for me. I will be interested to read other diners' highlights from their visits to ICHI as I am sure there are many more than what I list here:

1. Nigiri: A large mural on the wall highlights some important points for sushi beginners (and even veterans like me) to know - it's ok to pick it up with your hand, eat it in one bite, do not dunk it in wasabi soy sauce. 

All the fish was super fresh, and the origins are listed on the menu. My wife has lived near the water for much of her adult life, but has always been wary of raw fish. Until last night.

The unsung hero of nigiri, the rice, was spot on, fresh and just the right flavor and texture for sushi rice.

2. Service: Our server knew expertly what each piece of sushi and each dish was, how it was seasoned, and where the fish came from. Same for the drinks. She (as well as the support staff) were somehow always there but not there, if you know what I mean.

3. Clams and uni (sea urchin) and eggplant: I have never been a fan of any of these foods, but since everything was so good I decided to get back into the game with all of them and was so glad I did. If you've ever had a bad experience with them, ICHI will redeem them for you. 

4. Shochu: is a Japanese distilled spirit, usually about 50 proof, which makes it somewhere between sake and whiskey in alcohol and flavor. Although Japanese whiskies are all the rage these days, shochu is the national spirit of Japan. ICHI offered two: Iichiko -- clear and fermented from barley -- and Kakushigura -- which is lightly aged in oak and has a slight tint therefore. I had one of each as well as a shochu cocktail. And will be heading to my local liquor store to pick some up to keep in the home bar.

I could say more, but you get the point. If you live in San Francisco (like my sisters), lucky you. If you are visiting San Francisco (like me, an ex-pat), do yourself a favor and check out ICHI.
author: David Y.

description:
Been here a few times already. Definitely better than other sushi joints in SF. Do not believe the reviews stating that it isn't fresh or it didn't meet their expectations, I've been to the fish market in japan, had Daiwa sushi and Sushi dai, of course you can't compare it with the sushi there, but I really can say it is one of the decent sushi spots in SF.

Sushi is decent but it is expensive since they serve nigiri by piece, unlike other places it comes in 2 pieces. And you won't be full unless you order some rolls or appetizers.

A lot of their fish is from japan so its definitely good fish. My all time favorite is definitely the uni and saba. 

Before coming you'll sure need to eat something since the sushi is on the smaller side, or you'll be spending A LOT.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
OVERRATED (yes, in CAPS)  Nothing to cry home about.  We tried nigiri as they suggested: no soy sauce, as they're already seasoned.  Ok that's great, but a problem when your rice is weird and "al dente."  We agreed it really took away from the fish.  The other dishes (skewers, oknomiyaki, etc.) are better executed at various other izakayas in the city.

Crowd is very...homogeneous.  Pros: ...er, trendy cat paraphernalia sprinkled throughout the restaurant?  Oh, and friendly service.

Thanks OpenTable for the rewards certificate I utilized so I DIDN'T cry when the bill for this meal came!
author: Jen E.

description:
We were wanting some GOOD FOOD for dinner and settled on getting some sushi...because that always fills my cravings.  First impressions of walking in: iit was a lot more modern/hip looking (not sure if I was feeling the ambiance vibe) and larger than I expected.  I did have a resi for us, so getting seated for dinner wasn't an issue.  We were well taken care of, and naturally got the omakase.  

The sushi was good.  I was concerned that we would still be hungry, but after the last plate came out I was the right amount of full.  The chef brought out a variety of hot/cold and nigiri for us.  I'm not gonna lie, and maybe cause I eat weird food, but my favorite was probably the fried shrimp heads.

If you don't wanna drop a lot of $$$, just order off the menu and skip the omakase.  I'd give it 3.5 stars.  I can't place my finger on it, but some type of wow factor was missing or something was off, but it was still a good meal so rounded up to 4 stars.
author: Lyn C.

description:
It's good sushi, no denying it. The fish is fresh, and the selection is pretty impressive. 
But the place is priced like Sushi of Gari without having quality that really matches. (I mean, their omakase is actually MORE expensive than Gari's.)

I came in around 8 for a weekday dinner and was seated immediately because I was alone, and I ordered pretty quickly. A couple rolls, a couple nigiri ($4-5 per PIECE), and a skewer. 

Didn't get any food until 30 minutes later. :|
The pork shoulder skewer was actually really good, so props to The Infatuation for their recommendation there. The nigiri was also great, but only one small piece for that price..?

About 45 minutes in the waitress informs me that they are unfortunately out of some tuna roll (I didn't catch the name). Good to know, but I had ordered two yellowtail rolls, not tuna, and everyone around me is finishing up their meal by now. :( 

The rolls were good though, when they finally came--pretty simple, but at 6 pieces each I can't complain about the pricing on the rolls.

Definitely a little overhyped -- not a bad place, cool decoration and atmosphere, but if I'm spending that much on sushi I think there are better options.
author: Gautam G.

description:
Almost a five star, so I round up. Really, great omakase. The key to this place is that it's very different.  Imagine having incredible curated flavors animating grass fed beef three ways.  Now compare that with the super dry aged prime NY porterhouse--one of the juiciest, most flavorful classic steaks in the world.

Ichi is like the "grass fed" experience--innovative, natural, clean, balanced experience. A Sushi of Gari or a Yasuda or (I imagine) a Nakazawa would be like the Peter Luger--juicy, giant pieces of insanely fresh fish that melt in your mouth. 

Ichi does not dole out thick, juicy, top 1%-type fish. It presents a beautifully curated selection of sustainable and delicious fish, then dresses them appropriately to two ends: bringing out some of that good-natured wholesome flavor in the fish, and leaving your palate with an invariably and persistently clean finish. I never knew this was possible.

Come here. Get Omakase. Expect not sensory overload dripping with umami, but instead meditate on the balance and clean execution.
author: Edward S.

description: I would actually give zero stars if such an option existed. This is by far the worst restaurant you would want to go to. They treat their customers terribly. I went with my family to this restaurant. When we reached, the manager said there were no tables and when we requested that we wouldn't mind if two people stand, he said ok. Thereafter once the tables became free, we requested the waitress whether we could sit together to which she said yes and she was very nice to us. However The manager was rude and openly overruled the waitress when she sought to help us. It made the Situation so uncomfortable. The waitress felt embarrassed and we felt even more embarrassed. The manager told us that we're making things very hard for him. This really upset us. I mean we come all the way to this place, wait for a table, stand for 20 mins and finally when there are free tables and waitress helps us, instead of making us feel comfortable, he behaves rude and arrogantly with us. We asked him if he would like us to stay or leave and he said leave. We were shocked and this was the worst experience we ever had. The manager is arrogant and doesn't care for his customers. We wasted almost one hour with no food and left hungry fir the night all because of one managers ego.
author: Nithyaesh N.

description:
I was excited to try ICHI given the open table rating but when I checked yelp (after the fact) I noticed the more mixed reviews. 

All in all, I liked the quaintness of the little restaurant, the extremely friendly service, and the unique attributes of some of the dishes. 

The two sticking points for me that felt like a miss, were the value and the gluten-free accommodation. I found it to be a bit on the high end. We ordered several pieces of nigiri ($5-$8 per piece), the avocado salad, the scallop "tacos", and two other small salad/sides. We each had a glass of sparkling rose. The total was about $140 with tip which is totally fine for a price, however the dishes were very small and the nigiri prices per piece were more on par with most places for 2 pieces. Additionally, there several items that the server told us could not be made gluten free because they were premixed so our options were pretty limited on an already small menu. 

Other than that, I truly did enjoy the restaurant.
author: Min M.

description: I've been here before 5 years ago at this exact location. Apparently they moved, and moved back, and I had trouble finding it, and it was pouring, but they Maitre D' was very sweet and seated us immediately. We decided to get Omakase and it was the right move. We told them we wanted to spend $X per person, and they delivered a hot and cold variety of Japanese delights that satisfied. We had a large variety of nigiri, which is their specialty, and none are served with soy sauce or wasabi, only ginger. The Chef decides the appropriate amount of seasoning. Our meal included two kinds of salad (cucumber and tuna/avocado), a hot dish of seared Australian wagyu beef, and a final hot dish of clam soup to finish in the several courses of fish. Everything was unique and assembled with care. Our waitress, Cheyenne, was sweet and knew all the fish types and was super enthusiastic. Recommended.
author: Jordan C.

description:
I can't for the life of me figure out why Ichi has 3.5 stars on Yelp. Are you people drinking scalding hot coffee before you sit down to eat their fish? Let me dissect this problem because it's mind bogging. 

If you can't tell already, I'm a massive fan of this establishment and EVERYTHING rolling out of their kitchen as the nigiri is among some of the best in San Francisco. I've read through the lower stared reviews and from what I gather, these people love to eat "California Rolls" and anything with "Japanese Mayonnaise". That's NOT Sushi. 

The owners have gone to such great lengths to capture what it's like to eat great nigiri in Japan and the varying, daily selection is proof of their commitment to the craft. 

Sit at the bar, ask for the omakase and let it rip. To all you naysayers, fish of this quality is expensive. So, before you knock the price per piece I'd suggest you check out the Safeway down the street and eat your sushi at home. :)
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Is omakase some sort of Japanese code word for $100 a person and still hungry? I don't know, maybe.

ICHI Sushi is a clever, swanky, pop culture-forward sushi bar on Mission near Bernal.  It's a fun, hopping spot.  The fish is fresh, but should the words "omakase" pass your lips, prepare to fork over major cash for the pleasure of the chef's choice.  Be prepared too that this popular spot may be running out of lots of items if you arrive after 8 pm, as it gets busy here, even early in the week.

ICHI highlights for us on an energetic late Monday night, included a wait for a seat even at 9 pm, but fortunately we were sipping a terrific Henhouse Saison at the roomy back bar.  Soon, we were seated in the front sushi bar.

We were steered towards the Okonomiyaki (japanese pancake) and it was the best I can remember eating in the U.S.  Really delicious.  

We read on Yelp that this place was a value, but of coarse omakase is the exception to that rule.  It is, the chef's assessment of the best in the house. We doubled down on experience over value and the nigiri that arrived was good and fresh, with wasabi and soy (and in some cases shiso added), already applied at arrival. You are not given any soy sauce, since all the heavy lifting (i.e. application of soy) has been done for you. Its a near perfect application. Admittedly, I'm now left wishing this was the standard everywhere. I felt truly spoiled. Signage on the walls reminds you that nigiri is to be eaten with your hands. Music to my ears. The sushi chef announced a lot of items were "Japanese" as in Japanese snapper etc. which I'm assuming means its frozen and flown in?  

A very enjoyable experience, but expensive. If you are used to paying about $100 a person for a good omakase, then (gulp) you will not be disappointed.  If you are searching for the value other Yelpers mention, then stick to their fresh rolls, some special nigiri and judging by their terrific pancake, a few exceptional hot items to round things out.
author: Rachel H.

description:
We've just arrived from the ICHI sushi and it was the best , very best, sushi we have ever had!! 
Our waiter, Johnatan, was the simply the best helping us on our choices and guiding through the menu since we didnt choose the chefs menu! 
The exclusive Rose wine was perfect!!!
Great Night to celebrate our 5th anniversary! Hope To come back soon!
author: Beatriz A.

description: Long time sushi eater- I had a couple issues with this place. The price is very high and the portions very small. I ate a burrito after eating $150 worth of sushi and saki because I was still hungry. Secondly the "no soy sauce unless we decide it shall be granted" vibe. This is so San Francisco. Never mind that you're paying high prices for average/decent fish, they insist on having you eat it the way the "chef" envisions it should taste. BS. Its fish and rice and if people want to enjoy it with soy sauce and wasabi, they should be able to. The hubris of this place is hilarious. Most of my dishes needed soy sauce and wasabi. They brought a bottle when they decided it was proper for the dish and then whisked it away before it could be used on other dishes. People who like expensive sushi and being told when they can season their food will love this joint.
author: Jim M.

description:
I came here for Omakase. I liked the options we had for the Omakase. We sat on the counter and it was a unique experience being able to converse with our sushi chef. Made for a more interesting and fun experience. The fish is amazingly fresh, the lineup we got was unique and tasty. We had some choices we might not have ever thought about so the adventure of Omakase was evident. It was a great meal. 

I didn't give Ichi 5 stars because I didn't like the restaurant's overall ambience as much as I thought I would. It was loud that night and it felt a little packed in but it was still manageable. 

The worst part about coming to Ichi is that there is no parking at all near this section of Bernal, so be prepared or take an uber if you are coming from outside the city. Be prepared to pay for parking at the bank parking lot.
author: James N.

description:
Table of 2, Friday night reservation. There was room at the bar but we opted for a table. Didn't really have a great first impression because the layout of the restaurant is actually a maze. if you're sitting towards the front of the restaurant, you can only get out one way, and the tables are too close together to walk through. Figuring out how to get the bathroom also required a double take.

There are a ton of options available on the menu. Many people recommend the omakase on Yelp, but we were told it would be in the $90+ range. Instead, we opted to try a few of their more izakaya style dishes.

Miso Asari Clams: A salty mixed miso soup with clams. It was very oily but delicious.

Then, some nigiri. We got the Maguro Zuke, Saba, and Shiro Toro. I didn't like the large amount of wasabi they put on these, since they used fake wasabi. The maguro zuke had very little flavor, and literally tasted like nothing. The other two were a bit more flavourful, but definitely not worth the $3.5-4 per piece price. We were pretty disappointed by the quality of the fish.

We then got momo yakitori, which is chicken thigh. The meat was very tender and juicy, making us want to order another skewer. We chose the buta katu niku kushiyaki, which was pork shoulder. Also amazingly juicy and delicious. A single skewer was only $3.50 each, making it the best value to price ratio on the whole menu. I'm surprised no one is talking about these skewer dishes at all.

We also tried the kampachi kama, which is amberjack fish collar, the best part of a fish. Very delicious and more filling than most items on the menu. This was $12 and great for sharing. 

We were not full after finishing all the dishes I named above, but had already spent ~$30 each so decided to call it. 

The service was friendly overall, the interior is very modern and clean, although the layout really bothered me. The non-sushi options on the menu are AMAZING, definitely recommend trying them over the overpriced sushi.
author: Elisa L.

description: I was very excited to dine here but unfortunately my experience was disappointing. For starters, the place smelled bad. We did their Omakase dinner and wasn't too impressed. Maybe the smell made the food less enjoyable. Two people 400 dollars was certainly not worth it.
author: Vinny B.

description: I had a great experience with my friend here. She wanted to try this place before she left to Vietnam. We sat at the bar and had nigiri sampler and some hot dishes. The Kama was juicy and delicious. The skewer sampler was succulent. I enjoyed the Japanese eggplant that looked like mushrooms. Uni from Japan was my favorite and Ikura! Yum. The sushi chef was very helpful with our questions. I will be coming back! Make sure you make reservation ahead because it's super busy and full.
author: Christina L.

description:
My entire night was great. I had intended on getting to the restaurant around 5:30 because they seem like they have a great happy hour, but I needed to get some work done, so I didn't end up leaving until about 7.  I got there, and there happened to be some people leaving and got to sit at the chef counter - definitely a plus! The chef in front of me was great at telling me what was in each nigiri which was great!  My favorite was the tuna and shrimp nigiris.  The shrimp one comes with heads deep fried - which had got to one my favorite parts of the dinner. I also ordered the miso asari clams - which have pork and clams together. 

Next time - omasake! 

Protip: sit at the chef's bar if you can. Definitely so much fun!
author: Nina Y.

description: My favorite Sushi in SF. The original location is very cozy. Just went recently for the first time in a while, still amazing. Really great service too.
author: Ryan W.

description: Single piece of uni nigiri is 12$? whaat? Thats all i can remember. And it wasnt very memorable. underwhelmed. Maybe I need to give omakase a try here.
author: Doby H.

description: We came for the Omakase, and left with our bellies and hearts full! Good food+great company=win/win. Each dish was more amazing than the next.  I can't thank Tim and his knowledgeable crew enough.  Every item was explained thoroughly to our group; drink pairings expertly suggested. It was my first time trying barracuda and uni, and I'm hooked!  Creative, quality dishes without pretension. By far, my best sushi experience ever.
author: AnaVera M.

description: Baffled at how the overall yelp score has reset and changed. But it just means that Ichi has finally come a bit under the radar. Make no mistake: the sushi here is some of the best in the city, and I say that after dropping $250 at Nakazawa in NYC. They're both outstanding, and Ichi is nearly as good as Nakazawa for a fraction of the price. The omakase is simply stunning, with amazingly delicate and complex dustings of shiso, many kinds of pepper, wasabi, and even salt among the many pieces. Of course the fish is superb. Don't listen to all the dummies in the other reviews, who seem to be comparing this place to their local Rockin Sushi, expecting some good awful spicy tuna roll drowned in soy sauce and wasabi. At $85 the omakase is actually a bargain.
author: Cliff K.

description:
Ridiculous prices for average sushi

Nothing special done by the chef - the ambiance was average and the sitting space was mediocre at best. Still the price for sushi was eye gouging.
author: Ash S.

description: High end, loud music, fresh sashimi, great selection of drinks. Great and friendly service.  Bring your wallet.  Families with little kids. Really liked the chef choice skewers.  No bento box here, mistly a la carte, nigiri, tiny plates.  Eat before coming here or after.  All their dishes reminds me of appetizer size.  Fyi, omakasi will cost you 75.00 per person, so let it rip.
author: Helen L.

description:
I want to like this place. I really do. I've tried twice, but I hate it. Until they stop trying to over-control my dining experience, I'm never going back.

Pros: The drinks were great (excellent sake recommendations from the waitress), and the yakitori, nigiri, and rolls were delicious.

Cons: I can't stand how they're so stringent about waiting for all party members to be present before being seated. The first time I came here was when the restaurant first opened. I had a reservation for 2. I was 7.5 months pregnant and asked to be seated, and they wouldn't seat me because my friend was late. Did I say I was 7.5 months pregnant? After several firm requests they finally seated me. Geez. I got better treatment on the BART. Fast forward to my second visit earlier this week, and they were still stringent about the "everyone must be present" rule. It was a Monday night and there were at least 6 tables open. Finally, they gave in and seated us when 3 of the 4 of us were present. Ugh. But that's not the worst.

The worst is their absolute control over soy sauce. I understand that the sushi is already pre-seasoned and doesn't need it - fine. But my friend ordered rice with soy sauce. They served it first, and when the sushi came out, they TOOK THE DISH OF SOY SAUCE AWAY so she "wouldn't be tempted." Is this elementary school? Is this the USSR? Are we in a lab? It's shocking to what degree they went to control the dining experience. It just ruined the whole thing for me. My toddler has more freedom at her daycare.
author: Cali K.

description:
Have been wanting to try this place for a long time! With SFRW deals, my friend and I decided to give this place a shot. We were actually kind of dumb and ended up not opting out of the discovery menu (where 1/3rd of the price is for drinks, and we didn't feel like drinking tonight, so not a viable option) and got the omakase instead. Omakase or go home yo. 

The place has some pretty sick artwork when you first walk in and is actually super popping. You typically expect Japanese restaurants to be quiet, calm, and serene... but this one is loud. Loud af actually. Don't go here if you want a super romantic date/are with someone who talks quietly. It's loud.

Anyways, this omakase is apparently more traditional than others. I didn't realize that rather than having a set budget, they just feed you until you're good. You can see my attached pictures, but basically we got two giant nigiri plates, which is what Ichi specializes in. I think we tried an total of maybe about 12-13 different nigiris? Yum yum. Every cut of fish was the perfect size--not a super generous fat chunk of fish, but a really nicely refined cut. 

Some highs and lows. High was definitely the ocean trout in both nigiri and cooked form. Who knew trout could be so good?!?! The nigiri form was definitely my favorite piece of the night--there was a nice flowery flavor that made the flavor really pop as well as a nice citrusy tang--would definitely recommend asking for more cuts of ocean trout if you're here! Ocean trout in soup form was also super spot on--radishes were a great blast of flavor. Low was the ikura.. Pretty sure it was sake soaked? I guess if you like sake or are already drinking it with your meal then you'll like it, but I'm not a fan and oh god it was so hard to finish. Not a fan at all. 

Beyond those comments though, I thought the experience was solid but not amazing. I felt that while the nigiri slices were great... sometimes the wasabi really overpowered the flavor of the fish so it was hard to enjoy it. Another common problem with their mackerel is that they like to serve it with ginger, but again, the ginger overpowers the flavors. I liked the subtler flavors--we had a scallop nigiri that had green tea salt on it which was really subtle but interesting. All in all, the fish cuts you're getting are definitely fresh and worth the money, so I think it's worth the money. Final bill per person after tip came out to be about $89. 

tldr; solid sushi; nothing mind blowing but pretty good nonetheless. place is really loud though
author: Jasmine X.

description:
The word of the day is: overrated. The fish is undeniably of exquisite quality, but it is prepared with HASTE and INATTENTIVE culinary practices that will leave the dinner wanting more after parting with 100-200 dollars, even if dining simply as a duo or a trio. At prices most restaurants would be proud to charge for two pieces of nigiri, ICHI demands 5-7 dollars PER PIECE. This is a WILD ride above market prices, netting the restaurant some 5-15X profits per pound of fish! 

I have been making my own fresh, sustainable sushi for the better part of the past decade and I can tell you that ICHI gouges its diners. It is quite unfortunate that I had to find this out the hard way. 

Unfortunately again, their rice is incredibly dry and was served quite cold underneath fish which was otherwise well-prepared. Their maki likewise left much to be desired, with flavors drowned by cheap ginger and pale wasabi. 

I would not review any restaurant poorly if it had not come in so far under par with prices so far above par. It is the DIFFERENTIAL that demands this low rating, and I promise you it was earned. With challenging reservations and inattentive staff who will over-sell you on everything, it's a wonder this place attracts any return diners. Perhaps sitting at the bar would net slightly better service and warmer rice with more moisture and flavor to complement the fish... but I will not be returning to find out. 

TL;DR: 

Dry, flavorless rice + talked-up fish that's definitely pretty great but WAYYY overpriced. Go somewhere like Saru or prepare to drop $$ on real Omakase somewhere else if you're a true sushi fan. This place attracts trend-chasers, nothing more. :/
author: Noah K.

description:
I really wanted to like ICHI. I love sushi, and I embrace all the quirks and idiosyncrasies that come with Sushi bars. ICHI, however, failed my expectations, both foodwise as well as the general attitude of both the sushi chefs and staff. I was seated at the bar, and had barely any interaction with either a server or the main chef (Tadashi). Upon requesting him for our orders, he often replied with short replies like "how many?" "What? Tell me how many?", all the while engaging with other patrons in a friendly fashion. Perhaps I irritated him with my politeness, or my choice of sushi.  I don't know.  Bottom line - maybe the food is good, it's not great, but it's no Saru or Maruya. And the attitude of the chef and staff certainly didn't help justify the price tag. 
I won't be returning here, sadly. Because I really really wanted to.
author: Parth B.

description: Yelp -- I love you, but you have this one wrong.  This is the best sushi spot in SF and I have been to almost all of them.  Get the omakase - sit back, relax, and have an amazing dinner.
author: Steve K.

description:
Conflicted about ICHI:
-Some really great fish
-Many of them are masked by all the toppings and citrus
-Favorites: Kuushi oysters, kohada, saba, tataki, umimasu, uni
-Friendly and knowledgeable servers
-Casual and fun vibe

Reasonable for omakase: veggie app, 2 oysters and 15 pcs of sushi EACH, plus a 300ml bottle of daiginjo.  $165 without tip.  Would give it another go purely for the variety of fish and the quality.
author: Cynthia C.

description: This was the most unique dining experience. Omakase is the way to go. Freshest fish I have ever tasted. I'll go every time I'm in San Francisco. Try it you won't regret it.
author: Richele P.

description: Limited selection of fish. Unfriendly chefs. Cramped location. Fewer cooked items than most other sushi places.  No effort to be creative. Not sure what the hype is about.
author: H S.

description: extremely overpriced. we were laughing whe we receive the taco and avocado salad. i will not come back here
author: Taryn M.

description: Overpriced and fussy for what it is. This place is pretty much what's wrong with SF restaurant scene. The Nigiris are good but didn't impress me much especially when you think about how much you are paying per piece. The place is so cramped and noisy, it just doesn't go with the the fine dining feel they are going for. Not gonna go back anytime soon...
author: Lo F.

description:
Why does everyone hate on here?  Is it because it's in Bernal Heights? Is it because it's hipster and not exactly what you'd find in Tokyo?  Please people, relax!

I went through a sushi craving to the point where I started perusing high end sushi experiences, and saw that ICHI has been getting a lot of press (for starters, 7x7 features them on the 100 things to eat list).  We made a reservation for a Friday night at 9:15pm and when we showed up, this place was PACKED! Sitting at the sushi bar was an absolute must for me, but unfortunately that meant we had to wait 30 minutes to be seated.  I'm not sure why or how that makes sense, and if it weren't for the fact that the sushi was amazeballs, I'd probably have more complaints about the fact that I didn't receive a single piece of food until 10pm, or 45 minutes after my reservation. Ok, moving on.

So, if you're going to remember anything from this, it's that you MUST order the omakase.  Not to be a snob, but for the people who sat next to me who ordered the two orders of the California Roll, why did you waste your time coming here? We went about 17 pieces deep, and threw in the chicken wings and fried fish collar from the hot food item list.  It was definitely an aggressive night, but hey, my LA Kings won the Stanley Cup that night and I was going to celebrate.

Highlights from the omakase included the hirame with chili and green onion, the saba with the egg yolk vinagrette and fried leeks, the barracuda, and the super sweet hotategai (giant scallop).  The tamago ended the evening, and while it wasn't warm, it was definitely quality.  The excellent quality of the fish here is what really blew both of us away.  The rice wasn't overly salty, and our sushi chef graciously put the shoyu or additional sauce on for us, so we never needed anything else. Dinner came out reasonably priced, including the hot food and some beers.  Something "strange" that we noticed was that we were charged per piece, not as a general "omakase" pricing.  Either way, ICHI sushi was definitely a great experience and while their sushi isn't what you'd find in the traditional sense, their quality of fish is absolutely on point.
author: Lisa I.

description:
4.5 STARS

Me: "Did you want to check out ICHI + Ni Bar on Wednesday?....Omakase and Izakaya dishes?"
Mr. NSS: "Sure...I love Japanese."

*Evil laugh* because I know it's his turn to pay. I know, I'm horrible. 

Having been to Ichi at their former location a block away and loved it (my review: http://bit.ly/1bP7qPR), I was ecstatic to check out their new location (across from Pizza Hacker) that opened on Tuesday. The new space is about three times larger AND they now offer a izakaya (Japanese tapas) menu.

While they now accept reservations on OpenTable, I hate their reservation policy. Not only do they require a credit card to secure reservations (with possible cancellation fees), I received ZERO dining points. WTF. Additionally, I made reservations for Wednesday at 5:30 pm and requested sushi bar seats. When calling to confirm my reservations, I was told that sushi bar seats are first come, first serve regardless of whether or not you have reservations. Hmmmm, this defeats the purpose of making reservations no? I hope they consider changing this but until then my rating is rounded down because of this. 

To secure sushi bar seats, we waited in line 15 minutes before they opened at 5:30 pm. Do come early because all the sushi bar seats were taken before 6 pm. Beware of line cutters, people. This fobby Azn couple thought it was perfectly OK to chain smoke in front of the restaurant and blow the smoke toward bystanders, then cut everyone else in line when the doors opened. Grrrrr....

One important thing to note is that you can only order from the full menu (sushi & izakaya) if you sit at the sushi bar side. If you sit at the izakaya bar side, you can only order from the izakaya menu (no sushi).  

Compared to other izakaya restaurants, the izakaya menu is very small and focused with about 10 things on the menu: 5 cold dishes and 5 hot dishes. An absolute must order is the Motsuni ($9.75): http://bit.ly/1d5wtci. The English cut short ribs and beef tripe were incredibly tender and the sauce was full of robust umami flavor. A total Japanese comfort dish.

Seeing how much I enjoyed the Omakase at Ichi's previous location, we requested a Nigiri Only Omakase which will range in price depending on how many pieces you order. We each had 14 pieces (including oysters) which was about $65 per person which was reasonable. What I appreciated (while some may not) is Ichi doesn't provide soy sauce or wasabi and the sushi chefs will explain every fish being presented.  The sushi chef (we sat in front of Darin/Darren) will season the pristine cuts of fish with various accoutrements like green tea sea salt, ponzu, garlic oil, etc that will best highlight that particular variety of fish. Why ruin a beautiful cut of fish by dunking into a pool of soy sauce? The shari (rice) was perfect; seasoned well and didn't fall apart upon picking up. If you're like Mr. NSS who is chopstick challenged, it's perfectly fine to pick up the sushi with your hands to eat. 

Like a good sushi chef would do, Darin/Darren started the omakase with a variety of firm, white fish selections and then progressed to a more fattier cut like umi masu (ocean trout). Their umi masu was so AMAZINGGGGGGG that we ordered two orders: http://bit.ly/1oWLFkj. If you like sake (salmon) and/or toro (belly), this is a must order as it was like a triple cream butter that just melts effortlessly in your mouth. 

Here are pics of our omakase sets: http://bit.ly/1l2hCaC and http://bit.ly/1cuwN7t. 

Ichi's omakase ranks among my top 5 places for omakase along with Akiko, Ino, Yume (Alameda), and Sushi Sam's (San Mateo). 

A tiny drawback is Ichi doesn't serve ankimo,  blue fin otoro, or unagi because they're not sustainable. I can appreciate that but I since foie gras was banned, ankimo is the only way I can get some type of fix. 

Expect to spend about 2 hours if you partake in omakase and also because they're crazy busy...even on a Wednesday. 

While I do like their new, hip location playing hip hop in the background, I found the sushi bar seats were so close to each other that we were rubbing elbows with our neighbors. It would have been nice if there were hooks underneath the bar for coats and purses. 

I'm usually adamant about only going to Japanese owned and ran sushi joints but Ichi is the exception. While the sushi chefs may be white boys, they do sushi ohh soooo right.

Shout-out to several parents who brought their kids to the sushi bar with them. Not only were they super well-behaved, they seemed to have enjoyed eating sashimi and nigiri. Love that they're such adventurous eaters at a young age. 

Me: "If we have kids in the future, we can bring them with us for omakase."
Mr. NSS: "Sure..under one condition?"

Me: "Ok....?"
Mr. NSS: "You can foot the $500+ bill." *Evil laugh*

Me: "On a second thought, maybe bento boxes are a better idea...."
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Apparently my friend was yakuza at the old Ichi and wanted to check out the new space, so we trotted on over on mid weeknight. It apparently is much larger than the old haunt. There's a large ramp that comes up from the left where te entrance is. A traditional sushi bar sits on the right side with some bar tables in the middle. As you go to the back there's another bar on the far right and some high tops which I guess is the "Ni" part of the space. Large murals are painted all over with quirky art, yet the tones are very subtle. 

We got one of the middle bar tables and as one does with a yakuza, get the omakase. Tons of things started coming out. Lots of well cut and put together nigiri, Eggplant, ebi, tofu, pickled veggies, oysters, clams...I wish I could remember everything and all that went in it. I do remember however that everything was tasty and you'll have to go by my bad pictures as a guideline. We met the owner and his brother who is a chef there. Very cool folks. My friend ran into folks from Hi Lo BBQ, Namu Gaji, and a few other joints. I did mention the yakuza status yeah? 

A bit off the edge for where I usually hang in the Mission but it seems like this, Pizza Hacker and the ever popular Blue Plate is bringing the Mission/Bernal corridor to life. Certainly worth checking out if you like the sushi arts. 4.3 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
BRUNCH review only

Pros:
- miso scrambled eggs-- omgggg they were SO creamy and the miso was a nice variation on traditional scrambled eggs. I would come back just for these eggs
- large portion of French toast! And it was pretty custardy
- the marinated egg in the ramen had a great, rich, creamy yolk!
- cute serving cups-- hot water came in a cute little teapot
- pretty good price for fancy brunch

Cons:
- the ramen we had came in *chicken broth*. WHAT. with *confit chicken breast*. This was a really Americanized bowl of ramen.......
- tamago French toast (yes, tamago means egg in Japanese so yes, this is a redundant name) was very average

Bottom line: The scrambled eggs were incredible-- I'd return just for those. But nothing else blew my mind. But, I went the opening week of their brunch menu, so the food might be on point by now. I might stop by again if I'm in the area.
author: Jiann M.

description: This is for brunch only.  I really wanted to like this place, but my Japanese breakfast was just ok.  The salmon and egg were a bit overlooked, and nothing really stood out.  Friends also had the cold Raman and thought it was just ok too.  I know Ichi is a top sushi place so I will try dinner at some point, but brunch was just ok.
author: Maile N.

description: Friend and I went the omakase route-- the nice part was that the waitress asked for our preferences so that our meals could be tailored accordingly. That said, for $100 per person I was hoping for something more special? The best thing we had was Uni from Hokkaido.. everything else was good but not memorable. Having just been to Kusakabe (also about $100) per person, this place was much less a celebration of food and more just a convenient place for pricey sushi without having to plan ahead too much.
author: Jean L.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurant in SF!  Not too far from 24th St Bart, walk on Mission St to 29th St.

I waited at 5pm for their opening at 5:30pm on Sat night 2/22/14, they recently opened on Tues 2/18/14 and already all the fans from the old place have found out, but it's not too crowded.  We got 2 seats at the sushi bar even without reservations!  Pretty casual place you don't need to dress up.  They shout Irasshaimase to everyone that comes in - it means Welcome!

Mural is awesome made from a SF artist, check it out.  Chef Tim made all the chairs, bar stools, and lights.

Daniel was our sushi chef.  Chef Tim was training the hot food cooks.  We let Daniel know we were only medium hungry and got 15 different course for our omakase.  

All the fishes were really fresh & we liked them all.  Our total was $130.77 with 15 courses (2 hot dishes & rest were 1 nigiri for each of us) & 1 beer before tip.  You can do it cheaper or more expensive.

Separate bathrooms in the back.
author: Ann L.

description:
Hadn't been here in a while since I now have a baby but am soooooo glad I revisited. We got the omakase and man was it amazing and filling. All the sushi was treated with different treatments and sauces that enhanced the natural flavor. Some of the fish was clearly aged or cured, it takes respect for the fish to know what to serve same day and what to give a couple days before serving. 
The kitchen food was incredible. The black sesame schmear for the spinach salad was not only beautiful but tasty. I love that they do not mix it for you since I prefer things lightly dressed and it gives you that option. The pickles were also so great and very different. The yuzu koshi daikon. Yes.
And there sake list is perfect. Many favorites as well as dassai 23! Well worth the price tag.
I won't be waiting so long before my next return. Our bill was only $200 including the fancy sake glass. I don't know where else you can eat this well for such a deal.
Next time we will order ala cart and not get all the fancy fish to cut the price tag, but it is possible.
See you soon!
author: tinkerbell e.

description: For the price point the quality of the food is poor. The nigiri was off balance, and the rolls basic and bland. We would have been better off getting sushi at the Safeway across the street. On the plus side, the service was excellent and above average.
author: David F.

description:
A little too bourgeois for me. I love nice places, but something about ICHI sushi rubs me the wrong way. The service isn't ever 'on point', the fish isn't the best quality (some fish I've tried were really good, some were not), and the prices are not reasonable. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here, but definitely not the worst sushi place that I've tried.
author: Lisa N.

description:
I had a terrible experience at ICHI Sushi, more specifically with a bartender at the NI Bar. I had walked by the restaurant several times and was looking forward to trying it. When I came in, I stood by the podium for a moment and seeing that the host was busy with something else with back turned, and that the bar was half empty I tried to approach it before a man working at the bar rudely told me to go back to the station and wait to be seated.
