The host was really gracious and nearly convinced me to stay, but the thought of going back to sit in front of a man who doesn't realize he works in something called the hospitality industry made me think again. I didn't get his name, but he singlehandedly ruined my experience with this place and I thought I should share this fact.
author: Harrison H.

description:
Food is ok, but not above average and the prices are RIDICULOUSLY high for what it is. Example? $15 for a single piece of Uni sushi?

I have been to a lot of Japanese restaurants both in the Bay Area and NYC, incl a number of higher end ones. This one is definitely not worth it.

Not going there again
author: C N.

description:
After hearing + reading up on ALL the hype about this place, I was a bit disappointed after having dinner here with the boyfriend last night. He and I love sushi; we're always looking for yummy places to have them. We went to ICHI Sushi + NI last night for date night -- I was excited, he was so-so after reading some of the reviews off of yelp. Coming in we already knew we were not going to take the omakase route. But after dinner and $120 dollars later, we knew we won't be coming back. Here's why:

Pros:
1. The fish was fresh + well prepared by the chef. It was tasty and definitely did not need soy sauce (at least for me). Uni was buttery & delicious. 


Cons:
1. The fish was nothing to write home about. The freshness and how well prepared it was was the only pro of the night but I've had similar sushi (size, quality, & preparation) at other places for a fraction of the cost. 
2. The Ginger Blush drink I ordered was too icy and tasted watered down. Def could not taste any alcohol. 
3. It really was loud in there... I knew this coming in but I was still surprised at how loud it was for such a tiny place. 
4. The rolls were OK. 
5. Ordered the pork belly yakitori and it was a little bland, undercooked, and too rubbery & hard to chew. The chicken skin was a bit better. 


I really wanted to like this place but it really wasn't that impressive for all the hype around it.
author: Jocelle A.

description: So fresh and good. I was impressed. The $ was worth it. Sushi guy was nice and staff were courteous. I'm from Japan and it's been hard to find good Japanese food in San Francisco. I'd go back again.
author: Urban E.

description:
Sustainable sushi, great service, and lively environment. We've struggled to find great sushi in Noe Valley/Mission, and besides Saru, these neighborhoods don't have good options. Yet, Ichi delivered really fresh sushi, cut perfectly, with rice that was seasoned and cooked as it should be. 
Their skewers, appetizers, and main dishes are a fusion of classical Japanese cuisine combined with a California twist, such as grilled shiitake mushrooms with meyer lemon and sea salt. 
Also, they are gluten-free friendly. They lightly season the nigiri with a tamari glaze, not with soy sauce. 
I highly recommend Ichi sushi!
author: Chef R G.

description: This place is fantastic. The fish is incredibly fresh and flavorful, and the service is attentive, yet not invasive. If you're looking for cheap run-of-the-mill maki, this isn't by place for you.  If you're looking for well-balanced flavors and quality ingredients, eat here now! Thanks for a wonderful experience, ICHI Sushi!
author: Melissa M.

description: Had a friend in for dinner who was requesting sushi. She is a bit of an artist, so I wanted to take her to a place that stands out in a town of sushi joints. Food was amazing, fresh and unique. Staff was super friendly and educated. Ambiance was super cute. I'll be back.
author: Mat S.

description:
3.5 stars. Our waitress was very nice. The cooked items were good, but the sushi and sashimi were a miss. 

The chicken meat ball w/ the egg yolk for dipping is my favorite. That egg yolk dipping is a must add. Just makes it that much better.

The pork and beef skewer was good too. 

MISO ASARI CLAMS  w/ Ground Pork, Miso Broth, Kuro Oil-this was really yummy also. Very comforting. 

UMI MASU IRIDASHI-Ocean Trout, Dashi Broth, Ginger, Daikon. Cooked right, but nothing special

The spicy scallop roll was bland

The nigiri was a thumbs down. The rice was hard. Everything tasted the same. The fish was ok fresh, but my friends did say their uni was very good. I don't eat uni so can't give my opinion on that. 

For dessert, walk down to Mitchell's for some amazing ice cream!
author: Karen H.

description:
Good place for sushi is SF. The decor is not very traditional, which brings to the preparation which I'll get to. Think gastropub/northwest decor complete with large signs on the walls and art with a bar feel.

What I had: Strictly Omakase Nigiri/Sashimi+ Some Apps

What I didn't have: Did not order any of the hot food or California type rolls.

Value: I would say fair, not over priced for what they serve, but it ain't cheap either. I find myself capable of pricing sushi for what they are worth and found it to be right on the mark.

Would I tell my friends: Yes for beginners and novice folks. Good for first dates. But I would throw some caution to purists alike.

Would I come back: For Omakase, no. I would however return with friends to try the other choices on the menu. It had a good selection of cooked food that would like to get to sometime soon.

Last thoughts: I'm generally a long time fan of non traditional sushi, the Morimoto inspired era. I am not against trying out new flavors and even citrus pairings and such. However lately as I'm getting older I am finding traditional or Edome style sushi best. Although I enjoyed the sushi very much, there are others I enjoy more around SF. Next time I return I'll stick to the basics like maguro and mackerel nigiri, and add some California type rolls in there along with non sushi offerings they serve. Spicy tuna and spider maki comes to mind. I really do enjoy this place, although reading my review may not seem like I do. I just did not find all the extra added flavors and toppings on a simple piece of fish and rice necessary. I enjoy my sushi clean and simple. I find there is always room for these types of places in cities that take sushi seriously. A really good spot in a city of plenty, they had me at the rice preparation alone. Something that the majority of bad sushi places just don't know how to prepare.tf
author: Juan G.

description:
Yikes, Ichi was extremely underwhelming and disappointing at the three dollar sign price point. It's not even remotely comparable to other high-end sushi restaurants like Kusakabe, Omakase, etc.

The fish on top of the nigiri was so thinly sliced that I could see through it!! 

The happy hour chirashi at $14 (add $7 if for uni) is probably the best chirashi deal in the city, but you get what you pay for...a tiny little bowl that most likely will leave you hungry.
author: Catherine C.

description: They treat me so well. They have amazing, inventive nigiri. Their sake selection is unparalleled and their tasting flight is an amazing deal. The food is fast but also clearly well prepared. I don't think there's better sushi+service in San Francisco.
author: Joshua R.

description:
I hate to give ICHI such a low rating but I'm afraid I was really disappointed by the overall meal. Perhaps if I were to try their omakase I would be more favorably impressed, but having tried other omakase in the city such as Pabu, Kusakabe, Zushi Puzzle and more, I can't see myself shelling out money for ICHI. 

My friend and I happened to get in during happy hour time, so we each got the chirashi with uni and then split some nigiri and a roll with ocean trout. I think my favorite was probably the ocean trout roll, which was fresh and flavorful. The chirashi had good sashimi, tamago, cucumber, and the rice was properly cooked. I was mostly disappointed by the nigiri, my wagyu was overseared and I wasn't impressed by the flavor, and the nigiri pieces were incredibly small. I appreciated that they seasoned and customized all of the pieces, but I didn't find the quality to be on par with the price, especially compared to other amazing sushi places in the city. 

It's a chic, trendy atmosphere, but unfortunately I wouldn't go back for more sushi.
author: Kate M.

description:
The sushi here is fantastic. It's the same quality as it was before when they were located across the street. It's the service that seems to be absent minded at this new location.

We got to the restaurant at 5:40pm for our 5:45pm reservation. Instead of walking straight in, we opened the door and there was a huge line waiting. We thought it was people who were waiting in line without reservations, until the party in front of us said they also had reservations. I don't know why it took so long to check everyone in. We asked for a seat at the bar. Nope, only 1 seat available.

It took forever for them to take our order. It took forever for us to get our order. We ordered 11 pieces of nigiri - it's fine that they gave it to us a few at a time. But when the first plate came to our table, only half of the nigiri came. As in, they gave us one piece of 4 different fish we ordered first. So we got this awkward plate, and it was embarassing because it looked like we were being cheap, by sharing nigiri or something. We told the waitress, she said the rest of the order would be out shortly. I checked the menu to see if each order includes 1 or 2 pieces, thinking it we forgot to order 2 pieces. Nope, the menu says 2 pieces per order. Huh. It ended up taking about 15 mins to get the rest of our 4 pieces of nigiri....

It was taking a while and we decided to order some Cold Somen with Shiso. We summoned one of the workers, who said "I'll get you your waitress so she can order it for you." Being that it took 5 mins already to get someone's attention, we were getting irritated. How hard is it to put in an order for us? What made me upset was that they were checking in on all the tables. The table before us, they asked if they wanted another beer. But they couldn't ask us if we'd like to order anything else? Another annoying thing is the worker that spoke with us was making rounds to all the table with another employee. So two people together couldn't put in an order for us. Very irritating!

Granted, the fish was amazing. This is the place to go when you are craving fish from Japan. It's very fresh, exotic, and definitely for sushi lovers only! I believe the special menu changes every night, and I can't remember what I ordered...only can recall the Anago, and ocean Trout. One downer was the Uni from Hokkadio. It didn't taste like Hokkaido Uni...for all you uni lovers out there who have tried both Santa Barbara and also the sea urchin from Japan, it was disappointing. I don't know if they had both in the house...but if they did, perhaps they switched it by accident. Just judging from the service, I could see this easily happening.

I also enjoyed the broiled fish selection. Most restaurants only have Hamachi Kama, but this place had about 5 different variations of this. I loved trying another type of fish! (can't remember which one we got). Somen with Shiso was really delicious. It was refreshing and modern.

I give this restaurant some slack since it's only a few weeks old. But their service needs to get with it!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
So I pulled a dork move. I showed up for a family gathering a month early. What?!? On a Sunday?!? I could've slept in! C'est la vie. I decided to make the best of it and have brunch. But, not wanting a wait, I pulled up the handy reservation app and the first to come up was ICHI Sushi + NI Bar. Perfect. I'd just read about their new brunch in Inside Scoop and the menu sounded divine.

Made my way down Mission St and walked into some great music. The Giants game was on and I had a view of it from my counter seat. Perused the menu and decided I needed an appetizer, an entree and a dessert. So I ordered a half bowl of the NI Bar Ramen with the kuro and chili oils, the ICHI Chirashi with the uni and the Tamago French Toast. 

The kitchen was going crazy as it was their first brunch. There was a bit of a wait for the food but hell, I had a whole free day and the game was on. Then the food came pretty much all at once. It looked like I ordered three entrees but technically it was only two and a half.

I looked like a little pig. And. I. Did. Not. Care.

The ramen was very tasty and I really liked the kuro oil. Chef Tim explained to me how its made and I truly appreciate the work that goes in to making that amazing flavor. I enjoyed the chirashi but wished the rice was a tad stickier. The French toast with the miso strawberries added just the right sweetness to my meal. I cleaned off all three dishes. It was truly a great way to spend some time on an unexpected free day.
author: J. P.

description: Hands down the best sushi and experience in the City. Authentic, fresh, perfectly seasoned, well paced and such friendly service. The best in town.
author: phil b.

description:
Another solid sushi spot in SF. Why am I just now discovering these places???

Here's a quick breakdown:

Environment: Hipster-Casual. Whuh? Yeah, I don't understand either
Food: Sushi was delicious. Particularly the Kanpachi (amberjack), Shima Aji (striped jack), Bincho Toro (Albacore Belly), Medai (Blue Nose), and Uni (sea urchin). 
Chef: Sushi chef was ultra nice. Get to know them, take care of them, get them a drink! Note: Wasn't sure how tip would be split, but I went ahead and tipped the chef in cash. Fantastic service.

Omakase for two people ranges, depending on how many pieces you want. It's essentially calculated by the individual pieces you receive x the price. Who woulda thought?
author: Andrew C.

description:
I really had no interest coming here, but we wanted sushi without leaving the hood, so we tried  ICHI. I never wanted to come here because it turned out to be exactly what we expected...Too-cool-for-school hip, overpriced, mediocre.

I guess everyone says it's about the omakase, but we came for a weekday dinner, so wasn't looking for anything overly extravagant. 

We got the sashimi sampler, a few rolls, the eggplant skewer, and a salmon in dashi with grated daikon dish, which was the best thing we had that night. 

The sashimi sampler was fine. The fish was fresh, but I didn't die a little like other people are saying their fish is. 

The rolls tasted okay but rice to fish ratio was totally unacceptable. I've never seen a thinner slice of fish in a maki roll before! 

The eggplant skewer had way too much sauce on it. 

As an asian who grew up in the suburbs of Philadelphia where it's not as diverse as it is in SF... I always notice when there are not a lot of asians around me. My radar went off that night ... "ALERT! No asians are around. I repeat, no asian are around." The only other asian person was our waitress. One thing I have learned about living in SF is that asians will flock to good food. It doesn't matter if it's a really white neighborhood (like Russian Hill or Noe Valley), they will go there to eat if it's good. 

This is a SUSHI restaurant with no asian customers. Enough said.
author: Bonnie H.

description: Just sit at the bar and get the omakase. The chef will give you seasonal and delicious fish that is customized to your preferences and price point. This isn't the place to get California rolls and imitation crab meat.
author: K J.

description:
I like how the omakase here is not a pre-set menu. They tailor to your table depending on what type of food you're able to eat. IE: Are you OK with shellfish? Do you eat all types of meat? Any allergies? They ask you a few set of questions to determine what selections the chef will have prepared for you. There isn't a set number on how many dishes will be served. It is determined by how full you are towards the middle. When they check in with you, you can definitely add more dishes or stop there. You can choose either a hot dish/cold dish. Even dessert! The price range for the omakase is between $60-$100. I really like this omakase option. Now onto the food!

They really specialize in nigiris (sashimi lying on top of rice). Their fish indeed are very fresh. They even have fish all the way from Hawaii!! Their nigiris are flavored by the chef, so they do not serve it with additional wasabi and soy sauce. I enjoyed the hot plates much more. The clams were so flavorful! I recommend ordering that. For all the items I received for the omakase came out to be $100/person (please reference my pictures). 

Don't forget to try their signature cocktail: Iceberg Cocktail.
author: Nancy N.

description:
Went here for birthday, got the omakase.  Had heard of this on Eater SF's heat map Was expecting something similar to Kusakabe, was unfortunately disappointed.  The fish was good, but not $100/person good.  The "hot" course was only ok...

The atmosphere was also way more casual than we anticipated.  A woman at the bar looked like she had come straight from yoga class.  It was noisy and hard to hear, and the food came out in spurts, with long breaks in between.

I know this was not supposed to be traditional, but we were expecting more of a wow factor for our dollars.  Would go back to Kusakabe instead as it is the same price point but feels much fancier.
author: Pauline W.

description: Pretty pricey, but tasty sushi. The fresh raw fishes of the day were unique and tasty, and the rolls were good too. I had a soju cocktail that was very nice and the wine selection was pretty extensive.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Omakase- #16 on the 2014 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

I've had the omakase at ICHI on my "to-eat" list for a while, so decided to come here for dinner with a friend. I made reservations a few weeks in advance for a 7:30pm dinner on a Friday night- however, there were still a couple of tables available along with seats at the sushi bar for walk-in customers when we arrived. We were seated away, and I convinced her to do the omakase with me. Our server was really helpful, and thoroughly explained the different options we had with the omakase- we could opt for sushi/nigiri only, or a combination of dishes + sushi/nigiri. We could also let them know if we had any allergies, or foods that we didn't like, and also if we wanted to eat something in particular. I loved the flexibility of their omakase, and we opted to go with a combination of dishes + sushi/nigiri, and let the chef choose for us. Our omakase consisted of:

-Cucumber Salad ($6, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA#6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA): Delicious- I loved the miso dressing they used for this salad, and the cucumbers were super fresh, crisp, and crunchy. I could eat a few bowls of this.
-Maguro Avocado Salad ($12.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA#sqE77a6p547sf0eg9I9Tjw): Just ok.. the tuna was fresh, and I enjoyed this dish, but it wasn't so amazing that I'd want to order it again, especially for the price. Skip.
-Hirame ($7) / Suzuki ($8) / Tai ($6.50) / Katsuo ($8) [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA#kwPw16hEteL0dqFNi0ixWA]: I normally wouldn't order any of these as nigiri, and I didn't really love any of them, but they were all good since they were so fresh.
-Inada ($8) / Shima Aji ($8) / Wild Sake ($7.50) / Shiro Toro ($8) / Sanma ($8) [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA#z2Pq9DaMhYujjU9EBFDWrA]: The toro and wild sake were definitely my favorites, but all the nigiri were really good since all of the fish were fresh. 
-Ocean Trout Dashi ($9.75, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA#G6z87SAgAZUtGNV7cCWNdg): Yum! I wasn't excited to hear that this was part of the omakase, but I was happily surprised. The ocean trout was cooked well, and the dashi had a good umami flavor- recommended!
-Pork Belly ($11.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=6HOOBDsRU8CqBwzEkdw9xA#_6ELkmIsENwMx28uJ-X4mA): Good, but not amazing. Some pieces of pork belly had the perfect crisp to tenderness ratio, but one piece was overcooked and dry. Skip.
-Uni ($4.25/1 piece, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ichi-sushi-ni-bar-san-francisco-2?select=p9sJ7Em0CuO2nhRlyB6_Ag#p9sJ7Em0CuO2nhRlyB6_Ag): Good, but not amazing. I would only order this again if I had a craving for uni.

Overall, we had a great dinner at ICHI, and if I came back, I would love to build my own omakase now that I know I can order just 1 piece of nigiri. One of the only negatives was the really small table- my friend and I are short Asian girls, and we felt a bit cramped. Also, the seats weren't the comfortable, and my legs started feeling numb towards the end of the meal. The other negative is the lack of parking in this area- there is very limited street parking, and very little parking that is really close to the restaurant, so you're almost guaranteed a short walk. The neighborhood isn't the best depending on which direction you walk, so be careful.
author: Amy D.

description:
If you get the "chef's choice" deal (I forgot what it's called, sorry), be VERY careful of sticker shock.  You're still hungry at the end and have no idea what anything is costing. The pot of gold they ask for at the end of the rainbow is QUITE an unpleasant surprise.  The sushi's great,  just very over-priced if you go this route.  Sometimes it's awesome (depending on the chef you get) and they get creative and blowtorch it, dress it up differently -- basically add value. But last time I got some older white dude and not only did he do none of that but the sushi was really nothing out of the ordinary.  I think it was around $150 for one person -- and I was still pretty pretty hungry.  Yeah.

They should be a little more reasonable with pricing for this menu feature. Or at least make you feel like you got your money's-worth.
author: Mortimer G.

description:
The food quality, service, and ambiance at Ichi is definitely there, but I can kind of see why the Yelp ratings is only 3.5. The fish here is super fresh, the Hokkaido uni was absolutely phenomenal. However, for the amount of food, this place is definitely overpriced. Be mindful that there could still be a wait even if you made reservation. 

The service is great though. Our waitress was super attentive and brought us some complimentary goodies for the wait. 

Definitely worth a try!
author: Becky W.

description: Extremely overpriced for what you get. $200 for 2 people after tax+tip for sushi that was no better than most neighborhood sushi places. $7 for one piece of small nigiri is pretty ambitious, considering it's not on the quality level of Kusakabe, Wako, Maruya, etc. If you're ready to drop $100 a person on sushi, just go to one of the places mentioned above. Much better experience, service and food.
author: Tom F.

description:
Some outstanding dishes here at ICHI Sushi + Ni, and then a couple of misses. I've been twice, and the repeat offenders have been the umi masu iridashi (ocean trout in dashi broth), sushi rolls, and kushiyaki plate (chef's choice of skewers). We discovered the umi masu when told that there was no salmon on the menu, and the ocean trout is very similar in texture and fatty-ness. In my opinion, it is not nearly as flavorful as salmon when covered up with avocado + cucumber in a roll, so I'd recommend getting it in the umi masu iridashi. The sushi rolls are a steal - high quality fish in an 8 piece roll, for $8? Not just "spicy tuna"? As for the kushiyaki plate, which will come with 3 meat and 1 vegetable skewer, these do not disappoint. They're actually not so difficult to split either, unlike other kebabs that will literally have you flinging meat across the table as you un-skewer them.

I have also tried the kama shioyaki (fish collar), miso asari clams, nasu (eggplant), and nigiri. I would definitely recommend the eggplant if you're a fan of the veggie. The nigiri have been fresh and pretty good quality, albeit a little small. Otherwise, the fish collar had too many bones in it, and the clams were just okay.

We've been here for happy hour, which didn't really have any of my favorite things, but did indulge us in the nasu ($4) and fantastic shochu cocktails ($10). Those cocktails are sour, refreshing, and intensely cucumber!

One odd thing about ICHI is that their omakase just sounds like a fancy way to get you to buy 12 pieces of nigiri. It's actually a la carte, as you select your own fish without any sushi-master guidance, so... just order a la carte.

I'm torn between leaving a 3 or 4 star review, but the price and several okay dishes are holding me back.
author: Stella A.

description: OH EM GEE THIS PLACE. This is going to be a somewhat unhelpful review because I have no idea what I had the night I came to Ichi for omakase because there was so much and I was in a rapturous sushi-induced pleasure blackout, but ALL OF IT WAS AMAZING. Like, everything that came out was mind blowing, and I kept saying "oh my god" throughout the entire experience. One thing I do remember: this is the only place that uni hasn't horrified me. I finally see the light! It doesn't taste like licking a rock pulled from the deepest depths of the filthiest harbor! It's delicious. Alas, it also ruined it for me because now I'll never get uni that good again (ok except in Japan). Just do it, get it all, give yourself (and your wallet) over to the skilled hands of Ichi's chefs, and prepare to die of happiness.
author: Maud D.

description:
Unbelievable waste of time and money.  I've lived in Japan now for 14 years, I know my raw fish.  When I saw the reviews here for this place around the corner from my parents' house I thought, 'nice to have a yummy sushi snack spot to drop in when I'm visiting the fam, and missing Japan'... Wrong.

I've given it two chances now; 1.5 years apart.  I've taken all daily recommendations from the owner/chef AND ordered on my own off his menu.

NO.  I'm sorry.  Not one saving grace.  Over seasoned rice; bad sake selection and knowledge.  Fish served too warm.... and on and on.  

WAY overpriced.

I don't give a hoot if they know how to say 'いらしゃいませー'。A total affect for the benefit of the hipster cheeze waiting to get fleeced.
author: Josh K.

description:
We'd had our eye on ICHI for some time. Especially recently, the spot has gotten some great press and rave reviews from a few culinary notables. Come restaurant week, we decided to give it a go. We managed to snag a last-minute 8pm reservation on a Friday night. The place was jam-packed when we walked in, but the bar seats seemed to turn-over quickly, so we probably could have walked in sans reservation.

Anyways, our table was a little on the uncomfortable side. Hard wooden seats and an awkwardly small table. We were seated on-time and placed our drink order quickly. About 20 minutes passed and still no drinks, or water. We ordered a beer and the restaurant week menu sparkling rose, so it wasn't like we were waiting on craft cocktails...

I actually had to get up and ask the waitress about the hold-up.  A few minutes later our drinks came out. I went with the RW menu while the hubs opted for the omakase. The pricing and quantity for the omakase is a little ambiguous. You pretty much tell them how much you want to eat and they gauge accordingly, so the fish pricing varies your overall cost. All in, I was pretty underwhelmed. I thought the sashimi was ok, the salmon being the best. The two rolls (CA and spicy tuna) were forgettable. There was a strong mayonnaise flavor which masked the fish. The last course, clams in broth, was also a huge miss. Sadly, I couldn't get past the look of the dish. Honestly, like a bowl of sewage water. The broth was overly-salted. Boo. 

Service did improve and they comped our first round of drinks which was appreciated. The food was nowhere near the quality I was expecting, though. Sadly, ICHI missed the mark for us.
author: Brianna M.

description:
This place REALLY impressed me... because it captures the authentic taste of Toyko with a little bit of East London Izakaya subtle flair thrown in. 
Start with the appetizers/side dishes- charred peppers with bonito flakes and cucumber miso salad. Hearty portions with strong AND balanced flavors. 

The fish? An intelligent and satisfying combo of vinegar rice and scallions to bring out the Yellowtail maki. Also, the Ocean Trout was a floral twist to everyday nigiri. After my first bite, I resolved to not use any soy sauce or wasabi- so yummy. 

The sushi chefs were Japanese (if you like it AUTHENTIC like that, I don't judge). The waiters are friendly and experienced. 

If you like cats, there are cat decorations- kitschy kawaii. 

***Trust on that seasonal fish menu girl***
author: Chris L.

description:
What a quirky, simple sushi joint. Our server was attentive and very helpful with explaining the menu. She checked with our table regarding allergies and asked us what fish we preferred for a more customized experience. The nigiri was delicately prepared/flavored and did not require any additional wasabi or soy sauce.
Omakase is the way to go and make sure to try the clams in miso broth. 
Definitely worth a visit
author: Coco M.

description: This was a very different sushi bar. American chefs.  Fish was high quality. Pre seasoned sushi. Very expensive $6 per piece. I would not recommend.
author: harry b.

description:
KenScale: 8.5/10

It's hard to find a place as hipster as Ichi Sushi + Ni Bar, a loud sushi bar located in the Mission. You can see all these young crowds, a loud place with a huge mural on the wall on how to eat sushi. Being used to going to elegant and serene sushi places that are on the more quiet side with attentive services, it was hard for me to take this place seriously on the first glance. How wrong I was. The sushi at Ichi Sushi was great!

If there is one word that would describe sushi here, it is "playful." There seems to be no structural or stylistic boundary with the sushi pieces here. You'll see a variety of fish, with different dressings from yuzu to plum. Unlike the high-end sushi places I had been to where chefs tend to be more disciplined in their attitude toward the craft of sushi-making, the chefs at the counter, all on the younger side, and are more open and seem less constrained by the rigor of the craft. Yet, I really loved the free-flowing approach, and there were really outstanding pieces that had remarkable texture. Various pieces like three line grunt (which came with plum sauce on top), tuna, Japanese mackerel, amberjack (with yuzu dressing on top), fluke fin muscle, toro and uni were all literally melting in my mouth. I went with the omakase option where the chef brings about 12 pieces. I should've kept ordering more pieces, but instead I also tried a couple of hot dishes. Unfortunately, they were somewhat underwhelming compared to the awesome sushi pieces. Both pork belly and ocean trout karage in dashi broth were more or less ordinary. 

The restaurant has that perfect hipster vibe that will make it an ideal place to grab dinner before a night out at Mission. There is a diverse selection of sake and a somewhat more concise list of wine. Getting a reservation wasn't too hard as long as you book a couple of weeks in advance, but the place was absolutely packed on a Friday night. Given that the flow of traffic tends to be on the faster side, I think you can probably try walk-in too. Ichi Sushi was a pleasant surprise that shows sushi at San Francisco is no slouch.
author: Ken S.

description:
REVIEW IS FOR HAPPY HOUR ONLY
M-F 5:30-7:00

Oh muh lord, the happy hour here is really good, and it definitely makes me want to come for dinner one day. Yeah, it's in Bernal Heights which is not hustling and bustling but at least it's easy to find parking, and hey, you can get Mitchell's for ice cream afterwards :)

$1 oysters YASSSSS. And it doesn't get crowded here like most places in the city because it IS far from everything and it's not close to BART.. The oysters were really good. It came already dressed with ponzu - so you don't use the typical cocktail sauce. SO GOOD - simply: fresh & sweet.

I believe the beers were $3-6 or so? Phat pint! I forgot what brand of type of beer were offered but it was decent stuff (I think I got a Stella?! @_@!).

We also had the Yuzu chicken wings which is usually $9.50 but I believe it was $6 or 7 for HH. SO GOOD. Dry fried chicken wings with SO much flavor and light/crispy batter. PERFECTION. Perfect with the beeeeeeeeeeeeeeeer.

The interior is modern, clean, and simple. It looks like their mission is going back to the tradition and basics of basically showcasing the fish / ingredients and not doing anything super crazy or adding a bunch of sauce. MY PHILOSOPHY WHEN IT COMES TO SUSHI AS WELL. Seeing all the good reviews for the omakase and having the nice service means I'm definitely coming back soon!
author: Emily C.

description: Sit in Darren's section and have him surprise you! Amazing sushi in a comfortable atmosphere. Truly a great experience and excellent sushi!
author: Mike H.

description: Go hungry and get the omakase. Great selection of beautiful, fresh fish with unique marinades/accompaniments. The waitstaff is super friendly and knowledgeable and will help you tailor your experience so you get plenty of your favorites as well as some new flavors. Good sake selection, too. This spot never disappoints!
author: Erin G.

description: Shocked that this place doesn't have higher reviews. The omakase here is absolutely fantastic - truly thoughtful and delicious combinations. I have celebrated my last two birthdays here and it has never let me down.
author: Laura G.

description:
Made a reservation at this place for a small get together with a couple of friends.  The omakase was on the 7x7 list, so we gave it a shot.  FIrst of all, we had a reservation and since there isn't really a good place (yeah, there's a small bar, but it was already packed with others waiting for their table), so the three of us stood in the corner awkwardly for at least 15-20 minutes waiting for our table to clear. Granted, maybe 15 minutes isn't that long, but there's more...

So we get our table, order, and start to chat it up not noticing how much time had passed when we got our first dish.  I can't quite recall how many dishes were brought out, but let me just say that we had at least 10.  Usually it would take some time for the first dish to be brought out, but after that it's smooth sailing right?  WRONG!  In between each dish we waited at least 20-30 minutes.  When you're hungry, that is just way too much time in between bites.  Remember, this is omakase, so it isn't like you're getting full plates of stuff slowly.  Another thing that turned me off, was the hamachi collar.  Yes, I'm used to getting my own, and granted there have been a couple of times where I had to share with ONE another person, but one collar for THREE people?!  Craziness.  

Now service was slow, but when we expressed a complaint about an especially salty dish, we were nicely surprised by an alternative dish that was much better.  The food was good, but nothing spectacular.  I gave this place 3 stars hoping that my experience was just a fluke of being short staffed, but given all the new sushi joints popping up, I don't think I"ll be back anytime soon.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
Considering that ICHI Suchi + NI was one of the better deals for SF Restaurant Week 2016, my friend and I decided to give it a try! This super hip and trendy place is located close to 24th Street BART, so it's easy access for those of us who prefer public transit.

(Link for restaurant week deals: http://sf.eater.com/2016/1/13/10764360/san-francisco-restaurant-weeks-best-worst-deals-2016)

For $65, you get a choice of rosé or sake, a cucumber salad with miso tahini dressing, 6 pieces of fresh sashimi (the fish was so good.. as my friend said, "It tastes like fishy butter!"), Bincho Tataki, which was seared albacore tuna, 2 rolls of chef's choice (1 was spicy tuna and 1 was veggie), miso clam soup, Mitchell's green tea ice-cream w/ shortbread. It doesn't look like much food, but it was definitely very filling.

I thought the service was great - each plate was presented with a thorough explanation. Also, everything came out at a decent pace. I'm glad I got to try this place for restaurant week. Maybe I'll have to try their Omakase next time!

(1/100)
author: Cassy H.

description:
Came here as part of SF sushi conquest and to catch up with my gay lover's ex-bff( got it?) 
Anyhow, we got the omakase which here in SF ( unlike my experiences in NYC)most of the time seems to be eat till you are full! I enjoyed my experience and fish was totally fresh but a bit over dressed for my liking! We got a hot dish too( like a big head of a fish!). We were both full and the total came done to like around $100 which is not bad at all!
author: Tina Z.

description:
Ichi sushi is a great place in the mission, an area that's been expanding like crazy lately. I took my brother and mom here and we sat the sushi bar. We chose to do the omakase and our chef was takashi. He's a sweet older man who was really friendly and served us great nigiri! I found out he does both the sushi and the kitchen foods and originally was a chef in japan! He also loves to surf if you ever want to sneakily bring that into the conversation!

We got about 11 pieces of nigiri and they were all delicious. Some were more unique and seasonal, while others were more traditional that really showed the quality of the fish here. I also love that ichi only serves sustainable fishes! 

We had: 
Isaki
Tai
Medai - butterfish, this was my mom's favorite
Shima aji
Buri - takashi's (and my) favorite
Aji
Kinmedai
Umimasu - i love trout and this one was delicious! it usurps my love for salmon by a long shot!
Hotate
Kanpachi
Shiro toro - i am always a sucker for white tuna and this was no exception!
Uni - so creamy!

We also ordered a couple hot dishes as well and I must say they do great izakaya style dishes! In particular, you must try those clams! It comes with an amazing broth and pieces of ground pork. So unique and it's on the 2015 7x7 must eats list! The fried chicken wings were also pretty good, in fact, my brother devoured ALL of them without even giving us a chance to steal more than a few bites.

I would come back here for the nigiri when I'm close to the mission and for those who love hot dishes and red meat, the skewers and hot dishes are worth trying as well. Also, try and get takashi! He's so fun and makes the experience complete.
author: Chloe Y.

description:
I went here over christmas with my family. 

First off we made reservations for four well in advance. Despite this we were seated at a table meant for three which meant one of us had to sit at the corner so the entire meal was uncomfortable. 

The waitress suggested we try the omakase so we decided we would and told her our diet restrictions, no meat for two of us and one of us is allergic to eggs. Despite letting the waitress know this we were served two egg based dishes and at the end of the night the pescatarians were still hungry because there had been only one vegetable substitution in the hot part of the omakase. 

Finally, it took forever to get the food. We were hungry which we let the waitress know but despite that there was still about a half hour break between each dish. Its not like they are cooking any of it, it should not take that long to cut up raw fish and put it on a plate for us. 

Also, the waitress was impossible to get a hold of. Took forever to get our check and would have liked more drink refills than we got. 

Probably the most important part was that the omakase was super fucking expensive. Thanks for the heads up that this meal was going to be close to $100 bucks per person.

Would not recommend. Never going again.
author: Meghan H.

description:
Oh my goodness! Where to start!?
Come here if you are interested in nigiri sushi.
It is not your place to go if you're jones-in' for a spider roll.This is also not your place to go if you want to douse your sushi in soy sauce & wasabi- it actually spells that out literally as writing on the wall.
Fresh fish & fantastic season fish daily & a lovely large sake menu to boot! 
My husband & I sat at the bar & ordered ordered omakase & had about a dozen pieces each. Everything was good but over half were excellent!!!! 
Darren was our sushi chef & he was fun & fantastic!! He is incredibly knowledgable & has been doing sushi for just under 2 decades! He got me to like octopus for the 1st time in my life!! :)
With a great combination of friendly & knowledgable staff, cute trendy atmosphere, & incredibly great ingredients, how can you go wrong?
Can't wait to go back again & hopefully we'll get Darren!
author: Ashley G.

description:
Once upon a time, there was a teenage girl named Stephy. She grew up in the San Fernando Valley and never really knew much about this thing people called "sushi." 

One day, she and her best friend were shopping at the Beverly Center and they decided to check out this new restaurant called Todai.  Now, if you never had the pleasure of dining at this establishment, their offerings were kind of the equivalent of a giant shit stain on brand new white sheets. Delicious. The "salmon" was flourescent orange. The "rice" tasted like stale cardboard. And it was all-you-can-eat, so as you can imagine, the quality was simply amazing. Safe to say, Stephy now hated "sushi." Sushi could go fuq itself.

As young Stephy got older, she and her friends were lucky enough to have things called expense accounts and she soon discovered amazing LA sushi places like Nozawa, Sushi Ike, Park Sushi, Hama, Sushi Gen and Asanebo. Stephy liked sushi now. Stephy really liked sushi now. Why is Stephy referring to herself in the third person? Knock it off, Stephy, you're creeping us out.

Cut to 2010 and Stephy is living in SF. Now with a honed palate for truly amazing sushi, a friend takes her to Ichi one night in it's original location and her mind is quickly blown. Like, it seriously exploded all over the sushi counter. It was ridiculous. In fact, a few customers are still probably suffering PTSD from witnessing her reaction. But that is neither here nor there. She couldn't understand how something so amazing had found its way onto her tongue. She couldn't even put into words how incredible this food was. She developed an insta-sushi chef crush on owner Tim Archuleta and wonders if he is actually (Food) God himself. Because, yes, THE SUSHI HE IS SLINGING IS INCREDIBLE ENOUGH TO ACTUALLY MAKE YOU BELIEVE IN RELIGION!!

She then becomes a regular. Actually, die-hard devotee is more accurate. The old location closes (terribly sad day) and the new location is born and she won't shut the fuq up about how incredible this place is. She takes dates there, boyfriends, local friends, out of town friends, anyone who foolishly thinks they've already had the best sushi in SF because she knows after an omakase experience here, hahahaha, good luck with that, you just got schooled! See what I did there. Schooled. Fish. Okay. Move On.

Having now eaten here a good 25+ times, I can tell you this with 1000000% certainty: You will be hard-pressed to find a better dining experience in SF. The caliber of fish. The sustainability. The amazing staff. The vibe. The music. The sake. The happy hour. The Ni Bar. It is everything. It's the reason you were born. It's the attainable bucket list item. And it is seriously one of my favorite restaurants on the planet. I would have dirty, raunchy sex with this restaurant if it let me. I'd even marry it afterwards. And still have dirty, raunchy married sex with it! DO YOU UNDERSTAND HOW DEEP MY LOVE IS?!?!?!

If you listen to nothing else today, listen to me now. Go to Ichi. It will change your life.

Third Person Stephy out

*drops chopstick*
author: Stephy S.

description:
This is the place I want to go when I'm feeling like sitting at a sushi bar and having the chef prepare an omakase for me. I've been here close to a dozen times dating to their original space, and they always deliver a delectable variety of nigiri with each piece uniquely seasoned with its own bright and unique accents depending on the fish. Some of the cool things they add are shiso, green tea salt, soy reduction, and yuzu. I usually ask for a 10 piece, but I am sure they will accommodate any size tasting you desire and cater it to your tastes. I pretty much like to try everything, so I leave it in their hands.

Because they adhere to sustainably sourced fished, you'll get some fish that isn't as popular (like Red Eye Snapper and Ocean Trout, for example) 

More and more places do this, but don't execute it quite as well as Ichi... Whenever you order a piece of sweet shrimp nigiri (Ao Ebi), you will also get the deep fried head to go along with it. Whenever I have ordered it, the head has come out piping hot and super crispy. If there was a menu item of just the heads, I'd order it in a heartbeat. 

The other thing I like about this place is the music. They always seem to play a selection of music from my Golden Age (the 90s) which will always earn some points with me. 

Overall, one of the better sushi bar experiences in the city.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Sublime. 

Less than 5 stars comes only from someone with A) impossible standards and B) no clue.
author: Scott S.

description:
Their happy hour is pretty boss. The collar is one of my favorite parts of a fish and you can get a variety of them for $6 before 7pm. Like 8 different ones. Really no reason not to get them all (we had four). The $1 oysters are also quite good and other izakaya stuff like great nasu dengaku, decent wings, and shishito peppers. 

They also have this pesto somen that's in credible and worth each person getting their own. It's super clean tasting and fits all that rich fish well.
author: Misha T.

description: This place is great.  Excellent combination of traditional sushi (you don't season it, order omakase, etc.) with modern touches.  Highly recommended.
author: Adam C.

description:
Sometimes 5 stars is not enough.

While the sushi is undoubtedly next level -the humble chicken wings - is the eye opening (as in - this can be done with chicken?) dish at this place - these wings literally smell like waffles - which results in a total senesthetic mindblow..

I've spent over 2 hrs at Ichi, and every dish was an unexpected surprise. Its literally difficult to imagine a restaurant continually improving on the previous dish for over 10 items but this is the place that pulls it off. There's possibly only one other place that can do this in SF that i've experienced (its american dim sum...). Srsly next level sushi yo (also helps if you go with Aaron V).
author: Oleg H.

description:
Eh I don't get the hype to this place. We went bc they were on thrill list top 100. 

Really underwhelmed for a few reasons:

1.  Don't tell us "don't be late!" and then make us wait around for 30 minutes to be seated. Granted you did give us complimentary cucumber salad and did thank us for being patient while we waited. That was appreciated. I get that it's not really your fault if people don't leave/finish when you think they will but I don't know was just an off feeling to being told don't be late. 

2.  After being seated 30 minutes late and asking if we have questions about the menu maybe tell us what you're out of instead of us trying to order things and then you being like oh we're out of that. Repeatedly. 

3. The skewers were bland and boring. Don't get them. 

4. The sushi rolls were indistinguishable between spicy scallop and yellowtail avocado. Kind of a bad sign when the rolls taste the same but are different seafoods and ones supposed to be spicy. 

On the bright side the albacore belly, clams and ocean trout were all good.
author: A C.

description: Chef Tim Archuleta, is a world class Sushi Chef. In my opinion he hits it out of the ballpark and into orbit at Ichi Sushi.  He elevates sushi to a level never before reached in my world travels. I had dinner last night at Chefs table. I still can't stop thinking about all the great favors of his Nigeri selection. What an incredible experience. I could hardly contain myself from audible expressions of joy as I sampled each exquisitely prepared piece of food. Thank you, I will be traveling from the depths of the Peninsula with a broad smile plastered upon my face, while anticipating my next seating at Ichi sushi.
author: Brett V.

description: Had dinner there with my daughter. Food was good. Everyone there was white. Which is fine, but don't try to talk to me with a Japanese accent. Not cool. Very expensive for what you're getting. Ordered a beer and they brought two out. Daughter is only 18.
author: Mr B.

description:
Rarely do I feel like I need to write a review since San Francisco is so full of people willing to share their experiences, an 834th review is bound to not tip the scales for anyone. But my experience at Ichi+In makes me feel in some sense obligated so all future diners can avoid the confusion we experienced. 

First a quick evaluation of the experience:
Nigiri - delicious, unlike any other sushi experience I've had in San Francisco. 
Skewers - amazing, best non-fish item of the night. Pork shoulder and flank steak were unbelievable, we could have made a meal out of these (and may do so in the future)
Miso Clams - disappointing after the hype, was hoping for more depth of flavor in the broth. 
Corn with Miso Butter - delicious, more places should serve fancy iterations of corn on the cob.
Ambiance - bustling/lively, to be expected on a Friday night at 7, interestingly, died down around 8.
Service - friendly, willing to offer advice and recommendations, but also the reason this review isn't 5 stars. 

The reason I'm writing this review is because there is at least one server who cannot properly communicate, in basic/blunt terms, what Omakase is, and none of the comments I've read on Yelp since have explained it either. We're we naive and should have known going in? Maybe. But when asked if it was our first time dining, we said yes, followed by "What's Omakase?" Because we didn't know, and think that would be made clear by the question. 

On the menu, Omakase just says "Chefs choice - ask your server for details." Per our server, Omakase "consists of an assortment of chefs choice fish and several small plates. It's super flexible!" She says, "if you like or don't like something, it's super customizable." 

"So... How many plates... Err... How much do you get with it?"

"However many you want! Like I said, it's super customizable!"

I'll spare you the rest of the exchange, but what our server is trying to say in her most delicate dance is "Omakase is allowing us to choose your meal, with any input you would like to offer, then we will give you a bill for everything you ate. We can bring you as much food as you would like and will create a full priced, itemized bill for all of it, which you will receive at the the end of the meal."

So if you're thinking to yourself, "Self, what's the difference between ordering off the menu and Omakase?" Nothing. Except you only choose as much as you want, and the chef chooses the rest.

It's hard to argue that there are more appropriate and accurate words to describe Omakase than "super flexible" because it is literally ordering food that is offered on their menu, then paying for it, like you would at every other restaurant that you order food off the menu. 

Those who know me know that it takes a lot for me to "complain," if that's what you call this review. And let me be clear, I am NOT complaining about the quality of the food, I am NOT complaining about the prices and I am NOT complaining about the friendliness of the staff. But last night, was a first. No quantity listed, no price listed, no explanation why there was literally no criteria associated with Omakase. And ultimately it made perfect sense - and honestly made for a fantastic meal! 

We're we naive for not knowing what we were getting into, yeah, turns out we were. But our server had the opportunity to clarify and communicate clearly so we could fully enjoy the beautiful and wonderful culinary journey we were about to embark on. A chance to allow us to fully appreciate what was happening and make the most out of it. And that was the missing piece. 

We'll be back. I'm sure we will, because the food was too delicious not to go back. But next time we'll be fully aware and appreciative of the experience, and able to enjoy it from start to finish.
author: Emily T.

description:
Good lord, I think I found heaven.

I'm a sushi snob, so when my friend suggested this place, I was a bit wary. At the end of it I was 100% wrong and I'm glad I did.

When we first got there, it was a wait so we put down our number for a text. An hour later, we got the text and headed over there. We sat by the sushi bar and our server was really helpful in assisting us in what we wanted. We were able to select a set menu and ate to our hearts content. 

I'm  a big albacore sushi fan and I can still taste it in my mouth. When I say it's like an orgasm in your mouth, I am not lying. It was better than sex. It was better than Nutella. Heck, it was better than sex AND Nutella. SO. DAMN. GOOD. The baby barracuda was banging as well. I think by the end of it I may or may have not proposed to my waiter, that's how good it was.

It's a bit pricey, but it is worth it if you love good sushi!
author: Kemi A.

description:
Don't really know what people like about this place. I've heard that the sashimi is good, but at $4 per piece, we didn't want to go that route. A good sushi restaurant should also have good rolls. Ichi does not.

We ordered all the spicy rolls on the menu. None of them were spicy in the slightest. 

The hand roll wasn't bad, it just wasn't good. And again, a spicy tuna hand roll should be spicy. 

Regular rolls were all variations of the same California roll theme. Heavy on the rice. Very little fish. On their wall, they proudly painted the words (sic) "you shouldn't use soy sauce." Well, at this place yes, yes you should. Their rolls are boring, skimpy, and flavorless. Perhaps they've figured this out, because they give out a bottle of soy sauce to every table. 

Skewers were overpriced and not at all memorable. Just protein. They try to flavor them up, but the effort fails in execution. 

Two things they have going for them:

1. Service. Friendly and engaging. We felt well taken care of. 

2. Okonomiyaki. They have it on the menu. And they do a great job with it. The standout of the meal.

Like I say, we didn't have what they're famous for: sashimi. Perhaps that was our mistake. But I've never been to a place that has such a great reputation for sashimi yet utterly fails so miserably at sushi rolls. 

Prices are reasonable.
author: Walter P.

description:
3.75 rounding up since this is the best I've had so far.
One of the better sushi bars in SF. 

Sure they don't pay attention to detail. And the cuts of fish and garnishes can be sloppy. 
But it is one of the better ones that I've been to. They have a large enough selection of fish and the quality is somewhat decent.  And for the price it's not bad. 

The bill came out to about to a little less than $100 per person for a 24 pc omakase. Not including tip.

There's a bar area in the back where you can have drinks and appetizers while you wait.
author: Heejin L.

description:
The reason I am giving this 2 stars instead of one is that the service was great... That being said, the server makes it a point to say that the raw fish does not need soy sauce. I ended up having to dunk the sashimi in soysauce and on top of that asked for some sesame oil because the sashimi was flavorless and bland. 

Bottom line - the food is over priced, the plates are tiny, and the food is under seasoned. Paid $280 for 3 people and STILL left hungry.

Reminds me of a chipotle burrito VS an el farolito burrito... Just ain't the same.

Don't believe the hype!
author: Ryan G.

description:
This review is based on the HH side. 
Chicken skewer: a little overcooked and dry
Pork belly skewer: underwhelming and flavorless
Eggplant skewer: meh
Chicken wings: where is the flavor?
Corn: probably the best thing we had
Chirashi: I'm going to try to be a little nicer about it but I have never been this disappointed. The fish was cut in to such tiny pieces. Is it because the  quality of the fish is not up to par that they must cut it in such small pieces? 
Service: the bartender/server looked like she hated her job. She was constantly on her phone and barely even served us. 
I have nothing against this place but I don't think I will ever give it a second try. Maybe I'll one day try the nigiri side because it's better but I think anything would be better than that meal.
author: Nicole H.

description:
This review was originally written about ICHI in its old space. Now that it's moved across the street, it still applies -- I visit at least once a month.

Plus, the awesome NI bar in the back is a chill place to drink awesome sake and eat tasty things.

If you love sushi, go eat here now. You will almost certainly find a revelation: fish that you've never tried before, fish that you have tried before but haven't liked elsewhere, and preparations that complement, not overwhelm.

If you don't love sushi, go eat here now. The hot menu is fun and the fish is fresh and mild. Try something that you thought you didn't like -- it's different here. It's better.

Seriously. San Francisco sushi does not get better than this, and you don't have to wait for 2 hours to enjoy it.

Just remember one thing: when you see me come in the door at ICHI, remember who turned you on to this place, and make room at the sushi bar for the hungry bald guy.
author: Cameron C.

description:
ICHI Sushi + NI Bar is amazing. My family and I had a wonderful dinner here, sampling a bunch of dishes from their new izakaya menu. From the seared pork belly to the somen with shiso, everything was delicious. Equally as impressive is the atmosphere. From the second you walk in, ICHI is incredibly warm and welcoming, and the staff is super friendly and helpful. 

You should definitely try ICHI if you're in SF. Hell, you should go to SF just to try it!
author: Amy R.

description:
Last night, I experienced omakase at Ichi for the first time, and I was completely swept off my feet. The freshness and flavor that is packed into every piece is a marvel--simple flavors come together with incredibly fresh fish to form a complex. Even the pieces that aren't for the faint of heart, such as anago and uni, are so enjoyable that anyone can love them. 

My two favorite pieces were the inagi and shiro toro. The inagi was so fresh and wonderfully seasoned. Shiro toro completely melts in your mouth, and is exploding with flavor. 

Omakase at Ichi is truly an otherworldly, ethereal experience with food. Go, spend, eat, fall in love. Experiencing food like this is what life is made for.
author: Ashley-Jayne O.

description: Honestly the sushi here is not very good. I went after seeing rly omakase great pics on yelp and it does not great but the fish is not fresh, kinda flavorless and they don't use sushi rice (!!) which should be a basic requirement of good sushi. I really didn't want to rate one star because the owner is a super nice guy but the sushi was not good.
author: Jessica S.

description: I hate when folks complain about prices. It shouldn't be a surprise of you did your research. That being said, love Ichi. Everyone piece of fish is fresh and well seasoned. Quality of the cooked food is wonderful. Try the wings.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Came here with a bunch of friends and not only was the service was great 
but the food and drinks were tops! I so will be back here.
Thank you for a full belly and quench my thirst.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Trying to be too many things at once.

Nigiri experience at the bar. Set the bar high. Check. Those stools at the bar, high? Sure. Uncomfortable? Yep. Nevertheless, fantastic fish.

Ni Bar in the back. Meh. If you can't get seats at the sushi bar or a restaurant table, grab first come first serve seats in the back for drinks and bites (hot and cold menu, but no nigiri). Kama was acceptable, skewers were okay, two white wines we tasted left much to be desired. The Kama (collar) was really only half a collar.

High ceilings, open space, bold mural. Not warm or inviting or the feeling one often gets when going out for sushi. Just a bit confused.

Nigiri I would return for, the rest I could do without.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Went here this past Friday to see what all the hype was about. I had a reservation and was sat promptly even though the third person in our party was not there quite yet.
We got the Omakase, it was good but it was REALLY expensive. It ended up being $129 (including tip) per person, there were 5 beers amongst that total. There were highlights- barracuda, fatty albacore and UNI (OMG UNI!!) and some not so awesome, for example, I did not care for the young yellowtail - it was very tough and not much flavor even with their added "dressing". We also ordered the goma ae, shishito peppers and edamame. The goma ae was great because it was peas shoots instead of the standard blanched spinach, it was heartier and had a great crunch. The shishito peppers were also great, a nice salty, lemony garlic-y flavor going on with them. 
I appreciate that they serve all sustainable fish, that is great and for the sake of our ocean, all sushi restaurants should follow suit. Maguro for example, not from Japan but line caught from Hawaii. I love that!
I guess the biggest downside was how loud it was. It was VERY hard to carry on a conversation. Maybe I am just getting old..
Overall, I would come back but I will make sure that my pockets are deep.
author: Sarah M.

description: My gf and I grabbed dinner here and we decided on omakase with six pieces. Our favorites were ocean trout and wild salmon. We were suppose to end with uni but it was such a letdown. The aftertaste was so bad that we had to get another piece to take it away. The restaurant was kind enough to take the uni off our bill. For two people with a glass of sochu each along with a scallop roll, the bill came out to about $100 which was pretty good but maybe not great enough to come back for. For that price, I'd rather go to Sushi Sam's in San Mateo.
author: Chi N.

description: Showed up a bit before 7pm. Half the seats were empty, they said the next seats available to wait for were at 8pm. Even the "sushi bar", which was mostly empty. I hope they fill all those reserved seats and not lose any business. It's not "casual" if reservations take up most of the slots, so go there if you plan on it ahead of time. Hope to re-review soon.
author: C P.

description: Well, at the very least this place is "on-trend." The food is pretty good but you have to order twice as much as you think to get close to a meal. And then you'd be broke.
author: Statler W.

description: Underwhelming experience at this supposedly "hot" restaurant in Bernal Heights/Mission. We walked in and were overwhelmed by the fishy and somewhat unpleasant smell in the restaurant. The sushi was just okay. Nothing special or remarkable. It's not worth the trip if you are venturing in from another neighborhood in SF.
author: K A.

description:
Just ate here tonight with my girlfriend and we loved every bite. We sat at the sushi bar, served by Joe. I always prefer to sit at the sushi bar to see the fish, see the work put into the sushi and have the experience of meeting the chef. This was such a great experience for all of those things - super beautiful, fresh fish, immaculate prep space and a sushi chef with a fun, outgoing personality.  

The fish was melt-in-your-mouth, fresh, light, and delicious. I was beyond impressed with the pre-dressed nigiri, served with anything from a light soy sauce-wasabi brush-on or a Meyer lemon and salt glaze. Each bite was perfectly matched with flavor pairings and no need for a side dish of soy and wasabi. 

We also got the Nasu skewer and a couple rolls. Delicious, and I lean toward chef's choice on nigiri items. Amberjack with this great fermented chili paste and Fuji Apple... There are no words. 

Go here, enjoy the experience. Take your time, hangout and ask for recommendations. Also, sit with Joe.
author: Chanda G.

description:
Really had a lovely meal here.  Extremely well-made nigiri.  Uni sashimi screams fresh.   Love the vibe of the restaurant.  Modern contemporary setting yet authentic sushi.  Please order the steamed clams the broth was amazing with some sort of spicy chorizo diced up to give the kick to it.  Did the chef choice menu Omakazse which you can tell the chef to stop feeding you food when you start to feel full -  makes the experience fun.  Cost for food before drinks and tax/tips was around $40- $50.  Great value for the quality you get.

Overall, 4.5 stars.
author: Edmond T.

description: Finally, a decent omakase in the city (maybe there are others? I just haven't found them yet?). LA is much better than SF in this regard. Everyone seems to rave about it, but I come to expect it of any halfway-decent sushi place now. And Ichi is halfway and then some :)
author: Victoria C.

description:
Thanks for reaching out to me.  

We will be returning soon.

*******

Just tried to go here for brunch.  Made reservation for 4 people at 12:30pm on opentable but was extremely disappointed because they are closed due to equipment failure.  The 2 stars is and average score of 4 for the dinner I had before and a Zero for not turning off opentable reservations when not open.
author: David L.

description: This restaurant came highly recommended but I can't say I'd recommend it myself. Without getting too much into the details - the fish was subpar (and we ordered Okaseme so what we should have had was the best!), and it was extremely overpriced ($4-5 per piece of nigiri). If you're looking for good fish, at a good price, with an authentic experience - try Okoze in Russian Hill instead.
author: Roya P.

description:
We read that this place was one of the top sushi places in San Fran, but we were greatly disappointed with the service, as well as the poor selection of remaining food.  

First of all, they had not updated the address on open table so we went looking for the old place and had to turn around.  It's fine if you don't post an address, but don't give me the wrong one... Wouldn't this be one of the first things you change when moving to a new location?!

So we get there and we are sat at the bar. However, our drink waitress forgot about us. Then the sushi chef (from behind the bar) comes by to take our order, so I ask him about the saki, but in broken English tells me "we don't have that here" and walks away. Ooookay.  Finally our actual waitress comes by and now we are able to get some saki... We have been sitting for 15-20min by now. 
Another 10min go by before the sushi chef comes back around. We order the red tuna (best thing we had) and tuna belly (also very good) to start along with 2 hand rolls (awful- hardly any fish and all rice). 
However, for our next order they are all out of the tunas as well as several other menu options. We tried the ocean trout and the Japanese barracuda, both of which were so-so. 

Overall, terrible disorganized service, wrong address, and lack of remaining menu options led me to the 2 star review.
author: Aaron S.

description: Omakase all the way.  If you're OK with spending a pretty penny, it's the best bet to get a little taste of all the flavors offered at Ichi Sushi + Ni.  Every piece of nigiri that came out was delectable and carefully crafted with the right combination of flavors.  Our server was good and very patient with us while we waited for the 4th member of our party to arrive.  Drinks were delicious per those who ordered them.  Overall, pretty decent for fancy sushi and nigiri.... and that exotic fish head type stuff if you're into that.
author: Reena P.

description: When our uber took us here I was sort of skeptical due to the location but the food was amazing. Sushi was divine and tasted extremely fresh and service was on point too!
author: Chris P.

description: Loved this hidden treasure. Tried the Omakase and was amazed. The flavors were unique and delicious. The staff was attentive and extremely nice. Yes it's pricey, quality sushi always is. Will be taking friends back next time I'm in town.
author: M.J P.

description:
I don't expect much from most sushi joints in the city except for my die hard faves. But this place has gotten even worse since it's newest locale. Mediocre sushi at best, served by an over entitled staff. Chewy seaweed, tiny portions- is there fish in that roll? Couldn't even tell. The sushi rice had the wrong consistency. After spending 60 bucks on two half sized rolls in which the fish and avo were non- existent (and that was the name of the roll), a small portion of miso soup and smaller sized dry seaweed salad and uni nigiri in which the uni portions seemed half the size of any place I've ever been to. Not happy- unsatisfied- not paying
For quality- the place looks like a chipotle.
author: Sabine L.

description:
Decided to try this spot for dinner. We arrived about 20 minutes before opening and were first in line. By the time it opened there were about 8 other people in line behind us.

- Pork Belly Appetizer: tasted more fatty than other pork belly I've tried.
- The albacore and salmon were the best and most fresh tasting fish out of everything we ordered. Definitely recommend the albacore.

We also tried a few rolls and other nigiri - they were good, but nothing memorable. Food was nicely presented and the service was fine. The decor is modern with seating for about 30 (including the bar). We sat at the table closest to the window - the seats have no backrest and there is no place for your coat or purse. There is no signage on the building so you'll have to look for the black/dark grey unit.
author: Josh L.

description:
BEST SUSHI IN THE CITY.

For reals nao. If you rated it less than 5 you've never had the real real. When Martha Stewart came to town this is the only place she wanted to eat at. I've had many a great meal here and I also love their oyster bar across the street. Highly recommend you make a ressie beforehand b/c this place is poppin off.

They do these great happy hours too with WANGZ. Tangy, tangy, wangz!
author: Lisa Q.

description:
Came here since it popped up on a list of best sushi places around. Definitely good, but a top place in the US? I'm not convinced, but definitely one of the better ones.

Some friends got together and we all did the Omakase dinner. The preparation definitely reminds me more of Japanese style sushi places where you're served one dish at a time catered to your tastes. There were some very interesting style dishes and I enjoyed the fact that they had pre-sauced/garnished each of their dishes. Some seemed to have a light ponzu or light glaze of salt which is definitely a nice change from the usual soy sauce flavors.

Service was attentive, and the server even took one dish back (before serving us) when he noticed a lack in the garnishment on one of dishes.

Overall... a decent price of good sushi, preferable for small groups, but I wouldn't recommend it for groups larger than 3.... maybe 4.
author: Justin L.

description:
Yay! Was able to walk in without reservations on Fri at 6pm. Although we were told to get out by 7:15pm sheesh...

The food is super fresh tasting. We were so hungry, we wolfed everything down. We had the crab roll, the spicy halibut roll, got some Japanese eggplant which is to die for!!! There weren't anything extra creative that makes them different from other sushi places. I mentioned to my friends that that sushi in Hawaii, they get so creative and different with the rolls. You know, like a signature roll that they created/invented.

Order bit by bit cuz there were the 3 of us and couldn't fit all the food. Small table, ya know?

No desserts, boooo...not even mochi

Service is excellent! Food arrived promptly.
author: Spooky E.

description: Good service, nice location in the Mission next to a lot of bars. Tad overpriced, didn't have salmon sashimi which for me is blasphemous.
author: Aarya K.

description:
From the moment I walked up to the bar, Ken had me! He knew his wines and happy hour dishes!! He then later set me up to sit at the Sushi Bar, where I met Daniel!! 

Daniel was beyond amazing!! Funny, appeasing and creative! I will most DEF be back!!
author: April H.

description:
Going Downhill...

This used to be my favorite sushi restaurant in SF. The first time I came here, I felt the traditional sushi menu had a wide variety of generally sustainable fish that was extremely fresh. I was so wowed by the quality of the fish, that it topped the list of go to sushi restaurants in SF. When my sister came to visit from Chicago wanting some good sushi, I chose to take her to ICHI. We ordered about 8 different fish, and almost ALL tasted fishy and old. I was extremely disappointed by the quality of fish that was served. It even tasted dried out like it had been sitting around for too long. In fairness, the albacore with onions was delicious (I think since there was a marinade it was not as necessary to provide top freshness). They have the right approach, just really need to address the freshness issue with the sushi. Unfortunately I'll be looking for different sushi spots, and will not be returning. Very disappointed, and I really hope that the management addresses the issue and gets back to the core of first providing fresh fish for the sushi.
author: Heather U.

description:
Dining solo. Had no idea I live so close to this amazing Sushi place. Just had an orange ginger dry hopped mead and now working a Sochu drink made from Sweet Potato. 

Marie at the bar was soooo nice and great at explaining the drinks.
author: Denise D.

description:
WHAT! When it comes to having the most elegant, authentic, sushi experience in SF, you go to Ichi and you make sure you make a reservation in advance.

This is the only sushi spot that I can recall where the establishment says 'no soy sauce' required. 

Sit at the sushi bar and the sushi chefs are very knowledgeable and you're in good hands. Speaking of which, you eat with your hands, no chopsticks required but is offered.

I went with a friend and we did the omakase and a bottle of sake. All in with tip we each individually paid about $130 each.  Yes it's pricey, but so worth it, and I can't wait until my next visit!
author: John M.

description:
Man Alive! I love Ichi. I think that everyone does. A little surprised to see the 3.5 stars. 

The fish is super fresh. But a lot of spots have really fresh fish (Sushi Ran, Zushi Puzzle, Ebisu). 

It's what Ichi does with their fish. They're Nigiri are preseasoned with lots of different salty, spicy, citrusy hints of flavor. These flavor bombs are both tucked under the fish and delicately brushed upon said fish flesh.  UMAMI, son!!

The small plates here are really delicious too. Pork belly, fried chicken wings and little skewered chicken meatballs to name a few.

Their Omakase is the best I've ever had.  

Love their white wine list (mostly from draft) and the beers too. Amazing service and a really fun feel to the spot. It's a bit of hike for my suburban ass. But, I think it's worth it. 

Congrats on your @7x7 cover, @IchiSushi !!

Will be back soon.  It's up there on my favorite list for SF.
author: Dusty B.

description:
I came here to get omakase with my roommate and my friend. We're talking about a swanky restaurant that has the feel of a bar and a sushi diner all rolled up into one, but one thing I will say is that you can't have both. As much as I liked the ambience at this restaurant, it lost some of the old school Japanese feel to it. You know what I mean? The one that makes you feel like you can wield a samurai sword and slice all the freaking fish in the restaurant on your own! ALL ABOUT THAT ACTION BOSS.

But lets get down to the nitty gritty stuff. Let's talk food. This place was pretty damn good when it came to the omakase. We ate until we were stuffed and you know what?! No "REGRATS". Not even one letter.

The place was awesome and the fish was fresh. Most definitely had my fill and I loved every single bit of it. I would definitely recommend getting there early though and putting your name down. You can easily put your name down and sit at the bar in the back to wait. That was pretty awesome. You can also just walk around outside if that is your cup of tea. Good thing there are a lot of random restaurants and stuff to look at outside! But anyways if you ever get a chance, definitely check this place out.
author: Nathan L.

description: Ordered a few different types of rolls and nigiri. The fish was not fresh, and I didn't enjoy the "seasoning" on the nigiri at all. The salmon roe was doused in sake. I don't mind trying new interpretations/renditions of sushi, but none of this was agreeable. Server was not very professional either.
author: Haru M.

description: The food is very good but the portions are abysmally small for the price; if you're going to charge $8 for ONE piece of nigiri you should at least try to make it look somewhat substantial. The same goes for the various non-sushi dishes; the ones I tried were very good but again if you're dining with someone and sharing everything you'll each get about one to two bites in per dish. If you have $100 to spare (what it will take for you to get full, per person) then this is the place for you and you'll enjoy a great quality meal here.
author: Kerri Y.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, based on what I've long heard about it.

On the good side, the staff are very friendly. The sushi is also generally the star here, with the emphasis on the core ingredients and less on dressing it up (or disguising inferior fish). And there is a good emphasis on the daily specials -- since when it comes to fish, it's always about what's freshly caught.

They have many Japanese varieties you don't always see in SF sushi joints. And what you don't see are many of the unsustainably fished staples at most sushi restaurants, such as unagi, etc. You can also go full on omakase here, and the sushi chefs will take care of you with a variety of things to try out. This can get pricey, however, as I would call this place a little more expensive than the norm for SF sushi (especially given their smaller nigiri sizes).

They have some nice sake options (cold, of course) on the menu as well.

What wasn't so great about ICHI is that the sushi didn't shine here - for being the star attraction. The service is a bit discoordinated, as it's easy to order dishes that come completely out of the order you requested. There are also often long or short gaps between plates, as it is not well-metered out. Then comes the weirder stuff.

I didn't mind the gentle lecture on the proper way to prepare and eat nigiri, even if being told what you already know is a little like being a scolded child. So I get that any wasabi or soy added to the nigiri is at the sushi chef's discretion of taste (unlike the rolls).
