But if you're going to give me that lecture, you had better deliver wonderfully flavorful sushi where I wouldn't be tempted to change a thing. That did not happen, and the sushi fell a little short.

Between that and a conversation with one of the wait staff about their cold sake ("we could make one hot for you"), I got the strange sense that ICHI is lost somewhere between sushi newbies and sushi patrons who know what to expect. And that's OK -- there's nothing wrong with teaching or learning a few things.

But there is a fine line between honoring a cultural tradition and parodying a cultural stereotype. Here ICHI seems to follow a number of paint-by-number superficial details of what makes a Japanese sushi bar while missing out on creating its soul. You get the "irasshaimase" greeting, but all the sushi chefs look like skateboarders from Orange County. As if they got together at a Vans-sponsored skate park and decided, "Wouldn't it be cool if we acted Japanese and started a sushi place?"

The rest of the wait staff is whiter than a Walnut Creek Cheescake Factory, thus it begs a question: how would you feel about a soul food restaurant run entirely by ethnic Chinese where they spoke in ebonics and lectured you on how to properly prepare and eat collard greens with grits?

Asking for something a little more authentic of your sushi, whether it's steeped in Japanese tradition or something decidedly Western, shouldn't be a stretch. But hedging by trying to accomplish both is a recipe for failure. It might fly in Norman, OK, but not when you're just a couple miles from SF's Japantown.

With so many better Western or traditional Japanese options in SF for sushi, I won't be back.
author: Teddy B.

description: Awesomely delicious - a legend in it's own time. Modern decor. Amazing authentic food with top notch ingredients. The sushi rice is spectacular. Run there for their omakase! Also, great service. Very accommodating.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Unbelievably sublime! 
Had the chefs special plus some regular menu items & I was floored. Best sushi I've ever had (& I've had ALOT.)
The saki menu rocked as well. Had one that was phenomenal-the name was Dragon something (sorry, can't remember).
The service was unparalleled as well-the woman who served us was genuinely friendly, informative & unpretentious-so refreshing & welcoming.
We will be return next time we're back in my hometown.
author: Elle S.

description:
I've read that this place was one of the top in the country for Japanese, and being a fiend for that cuisine, we had to try it a few times. We opted to experience Ichi through the Sosh Concierge service - I've tried both the 15-Course Omakase and the 7-course Izakaya and they were phenomenal experiences - with both the supreme quality and delicate, sophisticated approach that the Ichi team has seem to mastered with their craft.

Their whole team is knowledgeable, passionate, super friendly and you can just tell they really love their jobs. Ken is a pro at the Ni bar and paid us great attention when describing our shochu & sake flights, which really tied the whole experience together with the seamless service.  

Plus, the sashimi! The oysters with tobiko! That pork and clam soup! The skewers! The freshness and flavor are incomparable to anything I've had stateside. My first job was at a sushi restaurant, which, (we thought) was high-quality for the region. But nothing even comes close to that raw fish from Ichi (typically flown-in from Japan). It's like Neptune himself threw his trident and bestowed us with these gorgeous, pearlized, perfect filets via Ichi Sushi. 

Prepaying for the meal and drinks through the Sosh app made the whole thing really simple and straightforward, plus, I felt like we got a more personalized and special experience all-around. Though, I may have to go back soon to get a refresher on that shochu lesson. ;)
author: Marina M.

description: The service and food was phenomenal. We had the chef's choice, which did not disappoint of course. The only issue we had was some grilled beef we ordered tasted of butane gas, but that was minor in total.
author: Pico S.

description: I came here for restaurant week thinking it would be a good deal ($65 for a 5 course meal and 1 drink), but was pretty disappointed. The decor is very hipster-ish with dim lighting and I actually really enjoyed the background music, which was 90s hip hop. The food was bleh...the best courses were probably the sashimi and dessert, only because I'm a sucker for fresh fish and green tea ice cream. There was supposed to be a hot entree with clams in special broth, but they ran out and gave us flash fried trout instead. The "chef's choice rolls" were very underwhelming - spicy tuna & california rolls. The service was great, but there are definitely better options for sushi in the area so I won't be back.
author: Chinh T.

description:
Sushi is something that must be eaten correctly. Or at least that's what they expect from you at Ichi. The walls tell you to eat this way because the fish is the best and because it's the best it's super expensive. The walls make no mention of the prices that's on the menu. 

Honestly I didn't realize that sushi is meant to be eaten upside down and without sauce until a Japanese friend told me years ago. And that's cool. But I like soy sauce with my fish. So paying gobs of money for a morsel of fish isn't my thing. Which is to say Ichi clearly isn't for me. And that's fine.  

Yes this place is more expensive than than most sushi spots in SF. But it's authentic....ok. So does authentic equal expensive. Here it does and maybe that's because they are in a foodie area.

Whatever the case the food is good but you will likely be hungry after leaving.  So come with a fat wallet and leave with an empty one.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Had the Omakase several times and ordered off the menu as well.  Ni Bar is a hidden gem with no reservations needed.  Sapporo on tap and great food selection.

Will find plenty of small white fish you frankly will be hard pressed to find anywhere else, not just in the bay area.  Prepared with care and super knowledgeable staff.  Sit at the bar and talk to your chef.  That's true anywhere, but especially here.
author: Tobin J.

description: I lived in Japan for 2 years and ate sushi and ramen as much as I could...with that said, go here and go hungry! Sapporo and dealers choice is how we had dinner, $200 later I would have spent another $100 that's how AWESOME our meal was. Our server selected all of our food & it just kept coming and I just got happier and happier with each selection. Go here, trust the staff they are well educated & dedicated in the art of Japanese cuisine. See other reviews for the specifics, I'm still in a food coma!
author: Jeanine S.

description: Many thanks to Nicole Selvig and everybody who helped make our meal memorable.  Delicious sushi and saki. We let our wait staff bring us pairings of sushi, nigire and saki until we surrendered. Every bit of food was fresh and so well-seasoned by the chef that we didnt need soy sauce or wasabi. Lots and lots of unique and tasty seasonings. The space is intimate and fun, very busy but service was not affected. Will be returning soon, I hope.
author: Alice M.

description:
Did the omakase as fellow Yelpers suggested.  Really fresh, high quality fish.  Solid sushi, so 3stars.  Just wasn't wowed.

Also tried the skewers, which were very good and flavorful.  I recommend you get those and order sushi a la carte, not omakase.
author: Riz W.

description:
Awesome service and nice sake but I've had better and the price is so not worth it. Also the decor makes me sad and I hate the sushi eating tips on the wall. Fun music but sterile atmosphere. I'd would have to say this place confuses me. Koo and Ryoko still have my
Vote!
author: Mel M.

description: Absolutely loved this place! Lined up outside their door right at 5:30 pm because this place gets crowded super fast! Would definitely recommend it to all the sushi lovers out there! It's pricy but definitely worth every penny! High quality sushi and would definitely go again to try the happy hour oysters!
author: Eva L.

description:
Ichi is MY FAVORITE place for amazing people, food, sushi, drink and perfect meals!  i am so happy each time I sit down at the bar for delicious OMAKASE...  It make sme so so very happy to be with amazing chefs as I dine and enjoy all the flavors they create for us.  
I am also a huge fan of their wonderful Happy Hour tasty bits & drinks.  I can't believe how great it is to just sit & enjoy the bar and the comings & goings of everyone.  
I have discovered some great reasonable rolls & happy hour specials that have made this a regular go to mid-week dinner stop!  

I look forward to seeing some of your around the Ichi!
author: Paige B.

description:
Ichi Sushi + Ni Bar + San Friends = Awesome Friday Night

Walked in with no reservations on a Friday night with two good buddies and got told that there will be a 40 min wait but no worries because they have a Ni Bar for people to hang out and grab a drink till your table is ready. We ordered Kusshi oysters, the rare yuzu beer, along with the famous fried chicken. 

Oysters were a bit expensive but fresh and sweet. Fried Chicken was good but in a subtle way. It was not dry and light in flavor, which I'm not quite used to, I'm used to the salty flavorful fried chicken. It's not bad, but different.

As we move to a table at Ichi Sushi, we ordered some nigiri and sashimi. The dinner menu is a bit sheer, but simplicity at its best. We ordered spicy scallop and spicy yellowtail, along with Uni, Amaebi, Tobiko and the best one of the night was the Tai, Japanese Sea Bream. Everything was fresh and mouth watering. Now I know next time to save my stomach for the dinner menu or omakase rather than the bar bites.

A star for the awesome decals on the wall and great hip, urban feel. Overall great experience, friendly host and waiters/waitresses. Ichi sushi, you have become one of my fav spots when I have an itch for sushi.
author: Christina W.

description:
I think this could be my favorite sushi place in the Bay Area. During my last visit, the fish was fresh, our server was friendly and she answered all of our questions. 

Finally, they played 90s hip-hop all night!

Where is the 6th star for the 90s hip-hop?!
I can't wait to go back.
author: Menandro M.

description:
Showed up right as they opened and were granted seats at the bar.

+Sake shiso maki: small rolls with salmon and shiso. Simple. Shiso, typically known as the wasabi receptacle (you know, that leaf), is insanely delicious in a sake roll; the leaf makes it almost refreshing. 
+Inari nigiri: deep-fried (kinda sweet) tofu stuffed with rice. Tasty as a dessert.
+Umi masu sashimi: three slices of ocean trout goodness. Incredibly delicious and sustainable. Gluttony sans the guilt, can't get any better than that.
+Spicy yellowtail specialty roll: simple, but with a spicy green sauce drizzled on top. Pretty good.
+Miso soup: basic. Did I detect a hint of booze in there? Weird.

Cute joint ensconced in a not-so-cute neighborhood. Great service and fair prices (for the quality of sushi). Definitely give it a try if you're into basic, but delicious, sushi.
author: Adena B.

description: What an over priced crap place! Visited this place yesterday and was very disappointed!! This is not your typical sushi bar, in fact they have very little sushi. Had the California and spicy tuna roll, both were tasteless and the presentation was meh. The seaweed salad was good. Also had chicken wings and four of the skewers which were ok, but nothing special. Ordered a large sake which was $20.. Seriously wtf $20!!! Spent a total of $100, my friend and I left hungry and annoyed that we spent that much. Service was friendly so I'll give them that, but will never return!
author: Erica B.

description:
Showed up and put our names on the wait list, because they don't take reservations.
Waited 2 hours, and at the end of the 2 hours they told us the restaurant was closing and they wouldn't be able to serve us.
Wow.  I mean....
Wow.
author: Kit T.

description: So pleased to be back at the intimate original location. The fish was very very fresh, the rolls excellent and our server made fabulous recommendations. It was$70 for 2 without wine which I felt was a steal for this quality of food.
author: Pia C.

description: I was not impressed. When we walked in as the first customers it was freezing. The fish seemed fresh but lacked flavor and the cut was just okay. The nigiri rice was lacking in authenticity. The service was friendly but a little disorganized. The fish kama (collar) was literally just a fish head with a few tiny bits of meat.  My jaw almost dropped on the table as my husband inspected it to see if there was anything edible. The yakitori was decent but nothing to write home about. Overall, this place lacks heart and flavors are bland. I don't mind if a place suggests that you should not use soy sauce on your nigiri when the chef has already seasoned it, but in that case you should be able to tell it was seasoned and it does not need to be mandated. We were ready to have a nice dinner and were willing to pay but instead we left very disappointed and felt it was a waste of $100 we could have given to the homeless guy staring at us through the window as we ate.
author: Speak F.

description:
We went there Friday night. It was definitely busy; and since we haven't made reservation,we couldn't get a table at ICHI Sushi; however, it was not a problem and we were seated at NI Bar. The menus are different; we couldn't get nigiri through the bar. We got some sahimi (no the greatest quality), and some other appetizers. NOTHING SPECIAL. The food that we got wasn't worth of what we paid.
Unfortunately, I am not too eager to come back.
However, it doesn't mean you shouldn't try - everybody has different taste and definitely experience.
author: Jenna F.

description:
Meh. It just okay. 

We ordered appetizers - fried chicken wings, picked veggies, chicken thigh skewer, pork belly skewer,  clams in miso and two omakase sashimi dinners (6 piece and 10 piece) and 3 glasses Chardonnay. 

The price isn't the issue - bill came to $153 before tip. Which is not too bad for two for sushi.

My gf and I were underwhelmed with the taste. Sashimi slices were short and thick and served really cold. Wasn't able to taste the fish. We are sushi snobs so really want to taste the flavors.

My favorite sushi restaurants so far are Saru, Wako and Maruya.
author: Kim T.

description: Very disappointing. Made a reservation weeks in advance.  They put 4 of us at a table for 3, someone had to straddle the corner, although there were open tables available.  We did the omakase, not that good, waited forever between servings. The service was terrible, had to flag the server down to get another drink. Although they made a point of asking about allergies etc the egg allergy was disregarded when it came to the dessert.  And WOW talk about overpriced. We will not be going back.
author: Marie H.

description:
straight crack. probably some of the best prepared sushi ive ever had. omakase for the win

Foodie tip****  try everything
author: Alex R.

description:
I had so much fun here.

Review for the Ni Bar: I did a 7 course meal here with a sake pairing and was so pumped to learn about the amazing food and drinks.  The owner eventually came out and was so friendly and gave a list of places to visit when I go to Tokyo!  Highly recommend for a neighborhood type treatment but in a fancyish place.  This spot is definitely what you make it.
author: Reyana F.

description:
I had dinner here and thought it was just OK. 

It was very busy and very loud. 

The waitress was fairly attentive but didn't have the most friendly vibe. 

After eating, I had a strange sticky taste in my mouth. It made me wonder if they use too much sugar or some kind of other sweetener in a lot of the dishes. I get that same taste/feeling in a lot of cheap Japanese restaurants, not at the top end restaurants. 

The fish itself was good, but not great. 

So, overall, it was fine, but I've got no desire to return.
author: Eater S.

description:
My two friends and I had a great meal at ICHI Sushi. Even on a Wednesday night, we couldn't get a reservation until 9:30, but we had a drink at the bar and ended up being able to get seated earlier. We were at sushi bar the whole night, so pretty much all of our interaction was with the sushi chefs. They were great - personable, funny, and they were good at choosing and explaining the sushi.

We ended up deciding to let the chef choose 5 pieces of nigiri for each of us to try. The fish was really fresh and delicious, and we all got to try things that we may not have ordered ourselves. One of my friends is a little pickier and he catered to what she said that her dislikes and likes are. We ordered a couple of rolls and the pork shoulder as well, which were all good, but the nigiri was definitely a stand out for me.

When the bill came, we were all pleasantly surprised that the price matched up with the quality of food and experience. Especially since we let the chef choose and he did give us things that are usually more expensive like toro and uni. It's so nice to find a sushi place that is actually good and not outrageous!

The reason why this place is getting five stars is because once I left, I knew I wanted to come back. I wouldn't say this was the best meal I've had in my life, but it was great, and the sushi chefs, atmosphere and price make ICHI sushi a keeper. I realized how rare it is to leave a restaurant knowing you want to return (even when the food is fabulous). ICHI must be doing something right (:
author: Alison B.

description:
Man, I really don't write bad reviews of places anymore and this review is late but I recently read something about Ichi and was reminded by the great bursts of red clouding my vision about why I will never eat there or recommend it to anyone I know ever. 

Basically, Ichi was responsible for my  super-bummer of a birthday a couple of years ago (2012). I'd heard so many great things about the place that I definitely wanted to celebrate with delicious sushi on my birthday.  When we got there, the hostess quoted a wait time of 45 minutes which was cool, so we went next door to drink margaritas. 

An hour and twenty minutes later, she still hadn't called so I went back over to check and she told us that they wouldn't be able to seat us before the they closed so we were, pretty much, shit out of luck. In sum, the hostess couldn't even be bothered to call and tell us we wouldn't get a seat and had us sitting around for almost an hour and a half waiting to not get seated. 

Even if it hadn't been my birthday, it was a pretty dick move, so I celebrated at Emmy's where the hostess was far more competent and accommodating even if it wasn't exactly the celebratory meal I had been hoping for. I mean, I guess they've probably replaced their hostess by now but that experience is something that really ruins restaurants for people forever.
author: Laura T.

description: So this place was interesting. Their shtick is the omakase which ranges in price from 60 to 100 per person. We decided to try it for the experience. We had about 16 prices of nigiri, a couple light salads, some fried shrimp heads and 2 hot courses. Everything was good but nothing was exceptional. The nigiri were prepared meticulously but to me they were a bit pretentious - marinaded in this, sprinkled with that, a shiso lead here, a shiso lead there, etc. the flavored were ok, but I found the fish to rice ratio unacceptable and with the variety of flavor a being added here and there I really didn't get my favorite part about eating sushi - tasting the fish. Also, fish portions were wildly thin which didn't help things. Combined with the high price point I left disappointed.
author: John C.

description:
Modern new set up here....I like. Food....great as always but it seems to me that the portions might have shrunk just a bit (but that just might be me :). The chefs are great...socially adept and skilled. The service..it was alright. I would like to give ichi 5 stars but the service portion is what's keeping them from it. Couple of things noted regarding service: No call back when leaving voicemail for reservations, spoke to employee on phone and was informed that she would call me back....never did, flexibility with customer requests and the level of attention to customers in general could have been better.

Even tho....I would recommend and say that this is one of my favorites in the city. In time, I can only hope that the service will improve.
author: .I I.

description: This place is good: the atmosphere, staff, quality of food.  I'm glad it's in my neighborhood.  But a high quality sushi establishment with superb attention to detail, it is not.  At best it is a really good albeit expensive neighborhood izakaya.
author: Robert Z.

description:
If there's a place to do omakase, it is here. 
 
It was so hard to get a reservation during a normal dinner hour! Book early. We came and sat at the sushi bar and had the omakase. Try out one of their barley Sochus, they're like a smoother, lighter whiskey. 

I'm no sushi expert, but I'll tell you what we had, much of it came with green tea salt which was heavenly. 

-Kakushigura: Barley sochu
-Nanban Zuke: Fried fish in vinegar with onion 
-Cucumber Salad: Raw cucumber with sesame & peanut dressing
-Kampachi Kama: Yellowtail
-Maguro: Bluefin tuna
-Kisu
-Tai
-Inada
-Aji
-Shima Aji
-Hotategai
-Umi Masu
-Shiro Toro

The sushi chefs were very nice & talkative and wanted to explain and share with us what we were eating.

For the above + a beer and two glasses of wine we paid $156 total. Not bad.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
My 2nd favorite sushi place in SF. I was scared to come here because I heard the hype, but the reviews weren't too good and that confused me. The bad reviews are a lie!!!

Things to note:
- Always expect a wait. For two people at dinner it was like 45 min which wasn't bad. They text you when the table is ready.
- Such fresh fish it's unbelievable... order the shrimp nigiri and you get a fried shrimp head!

Some bad things but not enough to let me remove a star:
- Why is miso soup $3.50?
- The decor is good, but then also slightly reminiscent of a Chipotle?
author: Carleen W.

description:
The restaurant was packed on a Thurs night, so we headed to the back bar and drank while waiting for two seat a the sushi bar.

We were sat at the sushi bar and after talking with a chef decided to go exploring the chefs menu. It was a tasty adventure of the Japanese seas. The chef tailored his offerings for our tastes but still helped us try new things, and explained each of the fish and combinations of nigiri.

The miso porkbelly skewer was over-done but bacon always tastes good.

Staff was nice, and happy to move our drink orders from one bar to the other.
author: Ryan U.

description: The fish is extremely fresh and tasty. I always order sashimi, which can be a bit pricey. Overall I highly recommend this place!
author: Brit K.

description: Had an awesome omakase experience for our anniversary dinner! 15 delicious dishes, paired with a sake and sparkling wine (never mind the hangover next day), expertly delivered by Darren and his colleagues. Favorite item? The uni was sublime, but the seared snapper belly may just have taken the top spot in this lineup.
author: Eirik O.

description: mmmm best amaebi I've ever had.  They fry the head and then put it on top of a corn soup that blew my mind.  Sushi was pretty good - If i can remember correctly, I had the squid, tuna, albacore, scallop, salmon, uni, and they were all o so very good i had to order the second piece for every single one.  Dollar oysters and the yellow-tail kama was also great for happy hour.  hmm debated giving them 5 stars for allowing the half order of nigri (1 peice) but if i come back and still love this place then ill bump it up to a 5.
author: Vince L.

description:
I was really excited to try ichi after hearing it as a recommendation from some other people as a good sushi place in the city. I understand that this is a new location and the menu has expanded and changed.  

We came in on a Wednesday night for my sisters birthday.  The location is a bit meh, a bit far from us and parking was not difficult but not super easy.  There is this weird dead end street that did not have signs and our only option was to back up.  The space is nice!  Love the paint color and cartoonish wall and decor and furniture.  The service was also top notch.  The staff is super friendly and helpful.

We had the cocktail which was a surprise.  it was called a cats meow. salted plum, shiso and other stuff. salty, not sweet at all.

Onto the food.  I was not impressed to say the least and dont feel like I would want to come back here.  Good sushi for me is really hard to find.  I want quality - fresh fish.  I also want a semi-authentic experience. I say semi because who i am i kidding here? Its california, not japan.  I also want value -  i dont want small ass pieces of fish on small ass pieces of rice.  I want simplicity - fish on rice.  nothing fancy.  no bells and whistles.

I think maybe part of it is expectation not meeting reality.  When this place was recommended, i thought it was an authentic japanese spot for sushi. That is not what i got.   japanese people dont come here.  

we started with oysters.  they were fresh.  there was a sauce on them. dont get me wrong, the sauce was good. but sometimes i just want to taste the oyster.  there was no option as the sauce was already on there.  We selected a few things from the regular sushi menu and these were good as well - ikura, tobiko.  Then we went to the specials menu and thats when i started noticed that almost everything we chose came pre-sauced.  we also tried the somen with shiso pasta and also seared pork belly.  it was not seared.  it was deep fried.  why would you call it seared if it is deep fried?  confusing ....

damage was $100 per person

I appreciate what they are trying to do here.  Put a new spin on sushi.  Its just not for me.
author: claudia y.

description:
This place is not your traditional sushi restaurant. Very modern-ish type of style and decor. There's a huge painting I guess you could call it to show you the appropriate way to eat nigiri (with your hands!) we came here for SFRW had reservations at 9 party of 2 on a Wednesday night.The place was pretty packed and LOUD! We were sat at the sushi bar (too close for comfort), a little too high and uncomfortable chairs. 

We had the prefixe menu which came with drinks(a cocktail, Sapporo and a generous amount of cold sake which came out at different times according to how far along we were on the prefixe menu). First we had maguro sashimi. I typically don't like Maguro but this sashimi was delicious! 
Second, we had 3 peices of nigiri. The two that stood out to me the most was the ocean trout (must try!!)  and the seabream! A pesto wheat noodles dish came out which was also pretty good and refreshing. A little salty, probably needed one more squeeze of lemon to balance it out. Next we had chicken, pork shoulder and steak on skewers. Chicken was nice and juicy with a kick of spicy. Pork shoulder was a little dry. Steak was juicy also. We also ordered wagyu beef nigiri and toro nigiri. I liked the wagyu but it was a little tough. Last dish was slightly fried trout in a broth and that was just ok, didn't knock my socks off like the nigiri version did. 

Last but not least! Dessert!!! Fried banana with vanilla ice cream and caramalized something drizzled all over. So good!! Banana perfectly battered and fried...just wish there was more banana

Overall I had a good experience here. The sushi chefs are not Japanese but they are very knowledgable of the fish and where they come from and gave little blurbs on each peice that was given.
author: naviee P.

description:
This was one of the most disappointing meals I've had in San Francisco and I eat out a lot. 
 1- "chef' ONE STAR   
 2-Service  0000 
 3-Price    00000
 4-Music  00000
author: Sanfrancisco O.

description:
SUMMARY: Sushi - meh...not the freshest.  Drinks - beer (5 types), sake (8-10 options?), and one cocktail on the menu - meh.  Customer service - harmless, but meh too. I wouldn't go back.  If I lived closer to the place and if there were other things to do in the area, then I might eat there again out of convenience and proximity.  I would not go out and actively seek dinner at Ichi Sushi + Ni Bar.  I also don't understand why it's called Ni Bar - they only had one cocktail on the menu and about 4-5 beers on the menu as well.  I was expecting a more selection of cocktails and Japanese beers.  Echigo beer needs to be added to the menu!

We were very excited and eager to eat here and put in a reservation on a weekend that we felt like celebrating something - it was our menniversary.  So...being super excited to eat out and have good sushi, this may have raised our expectations...maybe - trying to be fair here.  If you wanna read more details see below...

SAKE: The waitress we had was friendly, but she wasn't very knowledgeable on the sake. We were hoping to have a flight of sake - but this place did not have such a thing.  (*note there is no unfiltered sake here). We ended up getting the Cat's Meow ($9) which is an ume, shiso adult beverage.  It's not like umeshu - so don't get it if you are thinking it's similar and sweet because it is not.  

APPETIZER: Shishito peppers DELICIOUS!  So good!  Could have been slightly salted more, but it was tasty.  Love those little things.  Albacore tataki - the fish wasn't that fresh - and i felt it wasn't that flavorful.  I have had tataki at many places, and this one was just alright...dry almost.  It wasn't bad, but it is probably something that I wouldn't order again.

SUSHI: We ordered nigiri (magurgo, amaebi, and seared shiro maguro).  Waitress suggested that we NOT use wasabi or shoyu on the nigiri as it had other sauces/flavors added on it.  We were excited by this - nothing beats a good piece of raw fish that doesn't need soy sauce or wasabi to mask the flavor.  Maguro was definitely fishy...needed soy sauce on that one.  Amaebi was sweet - but it was a weird texture - mushy, creamy, and slimy...did not taste fresh.  I have had really good amaebi where the texture was light, crisp, and refreshing.  Seared shiro maguro was okay - nothing to write home about.   Inari was inari - good old simple sushi - you can't screw that up.

MAKI ROLLS: Vegetable futomakiwas good - again, nothing to write home about. It had gobo inside and I love the crunch of gobo.  Spicy albacore was the best maki roll that we had - and probably the best sushi we had that night.  I recommend.

AMBIANCE: Trendy.  Was definitely nice, hip & cool.  I like the mural on the wall that explains how to eat sushi.  Wasn't too bright or dark in there.  The old school hip hop music was awesome - had a "name that tune" competition with my boyfriend during dinner.  What is it with hip hop and sushi?  Why are they paired together like that?  And why do I enjoy the combination so much?!
author: Tara K.

description:
Super tasty. I came in for some nigiri at the bar and it was all delicious. 

My menu:
Tuna belly
Maguro
Scallop 
Amberjack
Shrimp (raw) with fried shrimp heads

Definitely on the pricier side but good ambiance when you're in the mood for a treat. I want to check out happy hour.
author: Melinda C.

description:
Some reviewers mentioned pretentiousness, I see it as entertainment. It is a little difficult to take young(er) people following "traditional rules" seriously. If there was a 90 year old chef at the counter threatening to boot me out for asking for soy sauce, I can go with the flow and shut up. When someone much younger does it, hell yes, I'm going to ask for soy sauce just to see what will ensue. 

This is not a giant piece of fish on a giant slab of rice place; the flavors are delicate and layered, the rice is compact and well-shaped, the flavors can be unexpected, just enough to wake my senses in the middle of auto-feeding to say, "hey, slow down, something special's going on here." 

Back to the soy sauce, there aren't any on the tables, there also wasn't a lump of wasabi with every plate--things I've gotten used to seeing in sushi restaurants. When asked, we were told each piece was appropriately sauced/wasabi'd as the chef intended--fair enough and I agree. But, upon further pressing to different table attendants, we were given the tiniest pencil eraser size ball of wasabi and a bottle of soy sauce that was soon taken away from us by another server while we were distracted. Asides from the excellent pork belly, flavorful barracuda nigiri, and scrumptious skewers, acquiring and losing that soy sauce bottle was pretty good entertainment for the eve. In retrospect, maybe the beer influenced our amusement. 

We arrived at 5:30 on Monday once the shop opened, it was fairly full by 6, but had plenty of walk-in seats in the rear for small groups. The crowd and the styling of the place leans to the young, but the food quality will satiate all fine sushi fans. It can get a little loud when full, very attentive staff. No desserts on the menu, but Mitchell's Ice Cream is around the corner. A solid place, a good place to eat on your own so you can focus on the flavor. The restroom has hand lotion, nice touch.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Wow. That is all I have to say. Wow. Words cannot explain how good ICHI was but I will do my best to describe the deliciousness-y, goodness-y heaven I infested tonight. 

Let me start off by saying I love sushi. And not the spider roll, fried sushi kinda sushi. I'm talking salmon roe with quail egg and monkfish liver kind of sushi. I had read about ICHI in 7x7 and how it was voted best sushi in the 2014 Eat + Drink Awards and I knew I had to try it. I can say with certainty it was the best sushi I've had in San Francisco. I even overheard (ok, let's be real, I was totally eavesdropping) a chef saying that the fish was flown in that today fresh from Japan and will have another delivery on Friday. Talk about fresh! Right when you walk in the door, you're greeted and hit in the face with fresh fish smell.

We had 10 different things that we ordered, but I'll talk about the highlights. The first thing we tried was on the daily special sheet, the Samekawa Karei (aka Japanese Sharkskin Flounder). Wow. I think this was the best tasting piece of sushi I've ever had. They quickly cooked the skin with a blow torch and placed it on top of the fish. Wow. You could taste every little flavor that was on that piece and it was amazing. The Kampachi Kama (salted Albacore collar) was mouth watering-ly good. I'm sitting here drooling just thinking about how good it was. Came out hot (which is huge in my book) and so absolutely tasty. It's so hard to describe, but just trust me when I say to try it. The Ikura (Salmon Roe) was also the best I've ever had. I make it a point to try it at every sushi place I go to and ICHI had by far the best.

We had Daniel as our sushi chef and he was wonderful. I will be for sure requesting to sit in his area every time I go here. Not only did he know what he was talking about but was able to make great sushi (which was a given I'm sure but he seemed better than everyone else!). Two times I asked him to surprise us and he did not disappoint. First we had a roll with eel and cucumber which was still warm from the freshly cooked eels. NOMS! Then he made us uni with cucumber and salmon roe and a fish crisp to start. Everything worked together so perfectly I wanted another one but resisted.

Overall, I recommend this place to true sushi lovers. I can't wait to go back and try all new things because I know that it will not disappoint. Thank you Daniel for the wonderful experience and looking forward to your new treats!
author: Sabrina D.

description:
The quality of most Fish here was very good. (I didn't try tuna as usual because most places in the US have awful tuna. Toro is OK mostly but "Akami" in the US just sucks. I stopped eating Tuna after moving here from Japan.) 

Why 3 stars if the quality of fish is very good? I didn't agree with "chef's choice of garnish/sauce" on a lot of nigiri pieces. It is sometimes simply better with a touch of wasabi and soy sauce on nigiri than Yuzu, etc. I appreciate this restaurant is showing that sushi or sashimi is not supposed to be over-dipped in excessive wasabi and soy sauce but I also want to enjoy my nigiri as the best way possible. They seem to use a lot of Yuzu on nigiri but some fish really just call for a touch of wasabi and soy sauce instead of Yuzu.

Would I be back? Maybe. If I figure out how to ask for a little wasabi and soy sauce without offending the chef. I'm Japanese and I never use too much wasabi or soy sauce but just a touch of it on some nigiri so that it taste even better...

Other cooked items were just OK too.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
Tried Ichi sushi recently, during restaurant week, and we were very underwhelmed relative to the glowing reviews some websites have given them. "One of the best sushi bars in the US" Really!? Nope, sorry, can't agree. I've had sushi at 9am at Tsukiji market in Tokyo, I feel like I know what I'm reviewing. 

As with any hipster SF joint our table wasn't ready when we arrived on-time for our 7:45p reservation. 30min wait. Kind of par for the course, unfortunately. We had one restaurant week menu and sampled other items a la carte for more variety. The chirashi was good, as was the restaurant week bincho tataki. The rest was ok, but nothing to write home about. The miso clams were downright disappointing and the sashimi or rolls, though the fish was expectedly very fresh, didn't blow my mind. 

The bottom line is, my neighborhood sushi place does better, with as fresh of fish, and we usually walk out having eaten loads for $65 (price of the Ichi restaurant week menu) for 2 people. Ichi was priced too high to not wow us, and it did not wow us. We won't be recommending it or returning.
author: Kendall G.

description:
I ate at ICHI last night, and it was wonderful.  We sat at the bar, and enjoyed omakase from Eric.  Everything he served was delicious, truly as good as could be.  The waitstaff was very friendly and nice, and kept me plenty full of ICHIbier (which you must try - it is lovely).  I will be going back to ICHI soon, and will likely become a regular there.

For full disclosure, I'm a sushi snob.  I'm used to eating some of the best fish available, and as such, have insanely high expectations.  It is rare that I find a place that hits my five-star-sushi rating.  ICHI is just such a place.  Do read some of my one-star-sushi reviews if you're looking for some color on what a bad sushi experience feels like to me.
author: Cj L.

description:
WOW! I don't know why people write such bad reviews here, but I had a lovely first time experience. 

Party of 3 and we got the the restaurant around 7pm on a Tuesday night! We didn't have any reservations but decided to try if we can get a table. Lucky for us we got seated right away in a little corner booth! Since we were going to do the omakase.. I guess sitting at the bar is better! We asked the waitress if we can sit at the bar instead and just our luck, 3 bar seats opened up! 

Our chef was amazing! super friendly and very informative of what he was serving us! We never had to wait long for our sushi it just kept coming to us in a timely manner! our waitress was very attentive and always walked by to see if we needed anything extra!

Everything we had was wonderful! every bite was a burst of different flavors that all went amazingly well with each other! I've never experienced eating sushi like this and I love it!

Bonus, chef's are fun to look at and Mitchell's is right around the corner for dessert! :)
author: Jenn T.

description:
My wife and I had been to the old Ichi before, but in our first time at Ichi's new space, we had a similarly great experience, only with less wait, since it's much bigger now. We went in on a Friday night around 7, and they quoted us 25 minutes to wait, and almost exactly 25 minutes later, I got a text from the hostess saying that a seat at the bar was ready. Even though we didn't wait there for the 25 minutes, I appreciated that we could've hung out at the bar in the back while waiting for the table. 

I agree with all of the other positive reviews saying that you should go with the omakase, although what I appreciated most if that the sushi chef asked us to order some things we liked, and then he could add some sushi that would complement what we ordered. It wasn't that we just had to pay a ton of money without any control -- instead we were able to tell them what we liked and didn't like and ordering a bunch of other interesting things at the same time. Everything the chef prepared for us were delicious and fresh, and the only things we didn't like were the things we ordered.

Unfortunately, two of those things that were not great were the two beef dishes we ordered. The beef tataki was a bit on the tough side, perhaps just a bit overcooked. Also, the wagyu nigiri had a great taste to it, but was also a bit on the tough side. It didn't melt in your mouth like other similar dishes I've had at other high-end sushi places. All the fish was great, but the beef necessitates a one-star "penalty." However, that won't stop be from getting great sushi at Ichi in the future.
author: Pilan C.

description:
Came here for restaurant week, ordered from the regular menu instead: a selection of nigiri and cold and hot dishes. 

Pros: Fun atmosphere, fried chicken, they try real hard. Awesome waitress. 

Cons: Inconsistent fish textures, heavy reliance on vinegar, disappointing overall.
author: Jessica D.

description: I'm sure the sushi tastes good... If i had a chance to try it. They need to learn to stock their kitchens better because they were out of all yellowtail dishes, shishito peppers, the poke roll, and the ume roll... Basically everything i ordered. Not fun.
author: Veronica G.

description: Fun and inviting place-- excellent sushi, it's really a different experience than what you typically get in america. Personally, I'm more into cheap, overly fancy roll type sushi like at Crazy Sushi across the street (and the plain stuff at the grocery store even). And if that's what you like, you may not like ICHI. If you are looking for a new sushi experience or want to up your sushi game, check this place out, well worth it. Let the wait staff order for you and take the specials too.
author: teddy w.

description:
Service by staff was okie - 3.5 stars 

service by sushi chef - was fabulous 5 stars 

atmosphere - very nice and modern 

food quality - very fresh and well prepped 

food presentation - good 

Overall - had a good time! will come back and recommend!
author: S S.

description:
we decided to check out this place, because we have to wait at emmy's for 45 minutes and we are famished.

noticed that our server was not friendly.

they mixed their tobiko with the spicy tuna roll and you have no choice or option not to have  the tobiko with your roll, so suck it up! and if your allergic to it, you just do not order.

the guy who brought over the okonomiyaki was being nice (or yet annoying) telling us what was on the pizza and how to use the mini spatula, really? 

it took for the server to gave the glass of soda that was ordered. server was reminded twice. 

yakitori was on the dry side.

the rolls that was ordered was good. we had the avo w/ ginger, spicy tuna and trout skin rolls.

during the chow down, we were betting on how long this establishment will last.
author: Nelle A.

description:
I really enjoyed the sushi Nigiri however this is definitely a place you want to come to on a half full stomach, or plan on spending a lot of dough.   The quality of the fish is VERY high, the types of fish available is also abundant.  The Nigiri comes already lathered up in various oils, soy sauce, scallion topped, ginger, etc... Just eat up!  No need to get additional soy sauce and gobs of wasabi to create a soupy muddy slop to dip your fish in, the bite-sized Nigiri is delicately prepped for your enjoyment.  
They have Hip Hop playing in the background and the people who work there were very cool.
I've eaten similar quality fish for less, but this is definitely a place to show guests a good time and celebrate!
author: Jaime P.

description:
Pricey but if you let the chefs set what you eat you are getting some of the freshest and best prepared fish in the city.

It was the best sushi experience of my
Life.

This is for the fish lover who appreciates nigiri 

Pricey but worth it if you have the means.

However not in the greatest part of town.
author: Daniel D.

description: The food experience is amazing, specially when you have Omakase. The chef takes you to different flavor experiences based on fish and other ingredients. Wasabi comes in the right portions and tuna is definitely a must here. Will come back for sure. If you come, please stay in the bar as you will have multiple food experiences
author: Max M.

description:
Just terrible. Seating was awful in the bar area. Sushi was terrible with very little fish and mostly rice and fillers. The restaurant was fairly employ on Thursday night and they asked if we had reservations which we did not. There were so many empty tables in the main dining area but they said they couldn't seat us there had reservations for those (the tables were empty the entire time we were there). 

Very disappointing. Don't understand the 3.5 rating and the 5 star rating from some folks; I don't think folks in that area have had really good Sushi. At three $ signs, I expect a far more upscale experience; just look at other restaurants with three $ signs in the city. 

Never to go back here.
author: Rohit R.

description:
Very high quality fresh fish. This is the best of the best. Sit at the sushi bar and order the Chef's choice. We had Darren as our sushi chef and he was amazing. The tuna belly was my absolute favorite. The miso clams are delicious as well! 

This is definitely a special occasion dinner as it's on the pricier side and more of an actual dining experience than just "grabbing a bite to eat."
author: Ange M.

description: Underwhelming. I loved Ichi when it first opened across from Safeway. It was amazing. It's been downhill since then. I am also extremely irritated at being told how to eat my sushi. I know. It feels condescending. I'm paying and I'll eat it t how I want. Once or twice a year I cave and go back because I'm craving sushi and it's close to me but I usually regret it.
author: Rude G.

description: Omakase is the only way to go. Nice atmosphere, good sake, great food. I'll be back.
author: Milad S.

description:
This place! So much going for it! 

I would highly recommend doing the chefs choice, it was pricey but one of the best meals I have had in recent memory. I would definitely recommend it if you want to have a really nice dinner.
author: Jourdain D.

description: Thought there would be more artistry involved in the yakitori, but found that most of the skewers came out at a tepid temperature and probably could have used another 5-10 min on the grill.  I think they also tend to use a lot of heavy, dark sauces to mask the lack of flavor in the food too.  Not really like the old school Japanese style places you find in Tokyo.  Not going to be heading back and prefer other more authentic places in SF.
author: Fred H.

description: No wait...probably because the Warriors game was on! Sat at the bar. Ordered sake, shishito peppers, cucumber salad, and a bunch of rolls and nigri between my friend and I. The sushi chef explained everything and the staff was on top of service. Will totally be back during another warriors game so we don't have to wait. Super fresh - super amazing.
author: Parichehr M.

description: Gave it another shot at the insistence of a friend.....Nope... Eh service... Eh selection... The emperor wears no clothes. This place is way overpriced.
author: Sebastien R.

description:
Good quality fish spoiled with copious amounts of yuzu sauce. Just serve the fish with some soy and wasabi.

Our server was nice and suggested what to get. The girl working the "ni bar" was in a terrible mood and wasn't pleased to help. 

Music is too loud and you need to yell over it. 

Price is ok, but there are other higher end places that cost about the same but give a much better experience.
author: Dima S.

description: Loved this experience! The mix of traditional sushi nigiri and maki with more mixed 'fusion' style salads and appetizers is fun and everything is expertly crafted. Sit at the bar to watch ;) I can vouch for the hijiki salad, ume shiso maki, and matcha panna cotta all being fantastic. Look forward to returning for nigiri. Also their cat theme totally stole my heart.
author: Sam F.

description: Awesome Sushi, and great service.  Highly recommend the Chef's choice Nigiri and Sashimi.
author: Alexander B.

description:
I think the sushi is just ok but very expensive. 
You can have very fresh fish like Tekka on balboa for that price.
Its really over price here.
author: Che K.

description: Amazing!!!! Had the omakase and highly recommend it. Sit at the bar and let the chef work his magic!
author: Natalia C.

description: If you want to pay a premium for a mediocre experience then go here. We had a reservation and were seated 45 minutes after arriving. While waiting, we tried to sit at a table in the bar area, and the waitress gave us attitude for ordering drinks only. The host complained that the previous diners "took too long", hence the wait. But when we were seated it became apparent that they likely took so long because the service is garbage! It took forever to get a drink. We ordered omakase and it was totally average tasting, at a 200% markup. The dishes were completely forgettable and came out way too slowly. We will never be back.
author: Tyler J.

description:
First, I found the set up of this place absurd. It was divided up into the sushi section and the hot dish section. I had to pick where I wanted to sit and couldn't order food from the other section. Because it's Friday evening and the sushi side was full, we settled in the 'hot dish' section. 

What was strange about the hot dish section was there was sashimi (raw seafood without the rice underneath) on its menu. So it wasn't hot dish only. The whole point of divvying up the restaurant into raw and hot sections was moot? (Not to mention I have never been to a 'Japanese' restaurant that has this kind of set up) To add to confusion, I tried to order the one and only (sake) cocktail on the menu and the waitress had trouble knowing if it's available and took her more than 15 minutes to check both sides to find out. If you had only 1 cocktail on the menu, you better frigging know if you are serving it or not.

As for the food, the quality to be fair wasn't bad but just of tiny portion. Real Japanese portion. So the sticker price may not seem much, it adds up when you have to get full. In the end I paid $75 for food and a couple of drinks and was still kind of hungry. 

I always lament the fact that there aren't many good Japanese (or Asian) restaurants in the city (given its reputation as a foodie haven) and this is another shining example of this inadequacy. Stay away unless you have no better options.
author: Ernest Y.

description: I've been recently to this sushi place on my trip to SF. When I walked in to the restaurant I really liked the ambiance. Comparing other sushi bars, this place has a large space. Really good for groups of people. The staff were friendly and I can't complain anything about it. We had several entree and rolls. The miso soup tastes great. It's a must to order before your food. I wasn't satisfied with rolls. They were missing something maybe too dry for me. I loved their oyster selection, was pretty amazing. They also had an appetizer with eggplants which was great.
author: Foodlover A.

description: Expensive and not good at all. We got spicy tuna roll and hamachi roll and pork belly and eggplant skewers. The sushi had no fish and to much rice. The pork belly skewer was super porky...tasted like the pork was frozen for a long time. The eggplant was really gross and had a bad texture. I left still hungry and really unhappy.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Probably the best sushi I have had in the Bay so far, though I haven't been to that many, in full disclosure (I'm from NY). Ordered omakase at the sushi bar and loved every piece. Very bold flavors. Not super traditional but delicious! Had a great time with the sushi chef also, who was very friendly and entertaining. Reasonable prices. Omakase for two ended up costing us around $130! Will definitely come back again.
author: Tansy W.

description: I have been visiting Ichi Sushi ever since they opened a few years ago in my neighborhood. We are lucky to have such an amazing place that we can walk to and we are never disappointed. Every meal is always delicious, using very high quality ingredients and the service is impeccable. Reservations are a good idea but I can usually find a spot if I just walk in. The chicken wings! Don't miss 'em!
author: Stephanie H.

description: Super fun, lively, street-style sushi place. Delicious and interesting! Not classic Japanese, but a good descendent of the Tokyo Go-Go sense of joy in sushi.
author: Michael G.

description:
First and foremost: I am a vegetarian who will occasionally (i.e. twice a year) eat fish. So, I am not a sushi connoisseur. That's what my boyfriend is for. So, after being featured on best-of lists, I thought it would be a great treat for him and I to experience a new sushi spot. The reviews would lead you to believe that this is the Holy Grail of sushi in San Francisco, and while this is better than Barracuda (sorry, neighborhood sushi spot!) it also wasn't as mind-blowing as expected.

We arrived a bit early (how did MUNI get us to our destination early, I'll never know), so we sat in the back of the restaurant, the NI Bar, as it were. I was half-expecting this place to be overrun with people, given how highly-publicized this place has been, but it was actually comfortable for a Friday night. The decor was very simple and, in actuality, left a bit to desire. I felt like it was very "Ikea". Perhaps I am used to my sushi joints being a bit more 'divey', but this felt like it was trying to be elevated, but didn't quite hit the mark. 

Our reservation time came and went-- we weren't seated until 30 minutes after our 7:45 reservation. The host seemed a bit frazzled-- she couldn't remember names (not really a problem) but we didn't get much of an apology for the extra wait. Again, not much of a big deal, but reservations usually mean avoiding some wait.

We were seated at the bar itself, which was not a problem for 2, but could be for larger groups. The dining area feels a bit tight-- I wouldn't recommend this place for large groups (which can be great, as there weren't any birthday parties doing sake bombs..)

We placed our orders directly with the chef, who was friendly and knowledgeable. The man next to us seemed to be going through an extensive run on the menu, receiving piece after piece, causing a reaction that led my boyfriend to describing it as an "O-face." Needless to say, I didn't have the same experience, but this is where my aforementioned lack of sushi-eating experience may make me biased. 

However, everything I did have was delicious, and despite pondering aloud what we would eat later in the evening, we left pretty full. Highlights included the Spicy Albacore and Vegetable Futomaki. I did not partake in it, but my boyfriend loved the Tuna Tataki. We also opted to start with the Shishito Peppers as an appetizer, which were roasted with great flavor.

So, in the end, it was a pleasant experience, despite an underwhelming decor and delayed service. I don't think it will be high on the list of places to return to, but perhaps this is the place for you if you are true sushi connoisseurs.
author: Bryan B.

description:
This place is definitely good for their Nigiri sushi. They are confident that it's prepared and seasoned just right so there is no soy sauce on the table for you to kill the flavor with.  Cold and Hot plates were good too but don't  bother with the rolls.

+ Toro Nigiri (Fatty Tuna) *****
+ Butterfish ****
+ Hotate Nigiri (Scallop) ***
+ Squid Salad  *****
+ Miso Clam Soup ****
+ Nice Modern Clean Decor with Fun Wall Mural
+ Service was great but we also went early on in the night


- Rolls **
- Seating Space (Reservations Recommended)
author: Manohak S.

description: ZOMG amazing. You need to do the omakase. Incredible quality fish in a beautiful environment and atmosphere. Super fun rolls but nigiri is where it's at - go ahead and taste things you never would have picked! So fantastic. We feel lucky to live in a city with such a top restaurant!
author: Lis W.

description: Bland rolls, average yakitori and super annoying wait staff asking if we really want water while it's 95F inside... I really don't get the hype either. Saru in Noe is a million times better than this.
author: Guillaume R.

description: Party of 8 on a busy Saturday night -- service was exceptional. Tried about 9 different dishes. Favorites were the Yakotori Chicken, Fried Chicken, Noodles, Kobe Beef and Nigiri.
author: Rae Ann D.

description: Lunch on Sunday, half empty restaurant still took 90 mins in/out unfriendly waitress seemed more interested in chat w coworker then serving customers food was ok. Nothing to write home about. Too many options in the city to return.
author: Andy P.

description:
I have yet to find a better sushi place in San Francisco. I have been here a few times now -- mainly for the omakase and the excellent sake selections -- and have never been disappointed. In fact, whenever I am entertaining an out-of-town client I suggest ICHI and they always rave about the experience as well. Went here last night and our group must have tried 12-15 pieces of nigri each, as well as shared a couple of the hot dishes. Everything was delicious and flavorful.

I see some reviews complaining about the prices at ICHI, which I will readily admit are on the higher end. But you have to realize you are not going to get a 5-star meal for a 3-star price in a place like San Francisco. I suggest ICHI for special occasions and going with true sushi lovers.
author: Joshua L.

description:
Ok, seriously I don't know what I just ate. Ocean trout, pork belly, noodles.
I'll never understand what nigiri, sashimi and all that is. 
But, shit, this is good!!!
Amazing food!!
The wifey ordered everything, she's the sushi pro....even baby niko got his own avocado.
Highly recommend you try this place!
author: Anett R.

description:
This place is very good. I would say that this is my 2nd favorite sushi place in the US, right behind my beloved Yasuda in NYC. The fish here is amazing and the variety is great. Also the waitress was extremely knowledgeable about the fish and the tastes, I had asked her for a few recommendations and picked amazing fish. I didn't try the rolls I am more of a nigiri type of guy so I ate that. I was also really surprised with the price extremely reasonable, I had a party of 4 and we ordered a ton and we repeated many fish and had an $80 bottle of sake. The bill came in just north of $250 with tip. This to me was not bad at all. When I go to yasuda in NYC I spend that much for a party of 2 and with no sake. 

I will definitely update this when I go back,  hopefully in 6-8 months. I live on the east coast so I don't get out there too much but would recommend this place and for a first date is good too as long as the person you take really values good fish.
author: Emiliano B.

description: Very over rated restaurant. I'm not sure what the fuss is about and why this restaurant is being the attention it's getting. I think it's decent sushi and sashimi but there is nothing great about this restaurant. I continue to believe that San Francisco just doesn't have great sushi. LA in my opinion has basically the best sushi in the US. Try sugarfish in LA. Beats basically all sf sushi places including Ichi. Fish was fresh here but look that's a given - give me something interesting and exciting. Do something new. Surprise us with a medley of interesting and complex flavors. Shock my taste buds - wake us up and show what you can do with your rice. Please don't give me cold rice - it needs to be room temperature or warmer. Anyways, I'm not going to say don't try but I will say I don't understand the hype.
author: Sean K.

description: Worst sushi and Japanese food I've ever had, and I'm not a picky eater at all. This place is just a dump, the sushi was very amateur- low quality rice, CHEWY seaweed. The clams had sand in them, some deep fried thing we got was cold and way too greasy. Granted we didn't get their set menu, but if they screw up the rest of their food this bad I feel sorry for the schmucks that drop $100 on their fish. Bad part of town, bleak interior and failed hipster vibe. They also appear to have charged my card twice.  Maybe the original founders had a decent intent for the place when they opened, but as of now it's horribly executed. I write restaurant reviews maybe once every couple years, but this place deserves special attention for the sheer embarrassment I had to endure when I took a friend here.
author: Harry E.

description: When you walk in, you feel like you aren' wanted... the ambiance and service is very cold, ambiance is noisy.  We ordered quite a bit of tiny portions, but paid WAY too much.  it's the kind of place you leave feeling hungry.  I used to go to the old Ichi all the time, it was small, funky, and really good.  This new Ichi feels unwelcoming, overpriced and snobby.
author: john s.

description:
Love the larger, slick, new space.  There's not much more to be said about ICHI other than the upgrade has taken something already great and made it even better.  There's really only one way to eat here and that is ordering omakase at the sushi bar.  The benefit of eating at the bar is that you have access to ordering from the izakaya menu as well, but vice versa is not true.

My sushi partner and I were lucky to snag bar seats without reservation, but only because we were the first to arrive.  We didn't know they took reservations now, so we were lucky with our gamble. Don't take that risk and make one... and again always opting for seating at the sushi bar.

Head Chef Erik again masterfully creates course after course of awesome nigiri. Really, there was not one bad thing we ate, and we packed away over 20+ pieces.  From the izakaya menu, we went for the steak and chicken thigh skewers, both were juicy and tasty.  Also picked up an order of miso clams in some sort of spicy sausage broth, which we enjoyed too, but probably will skip next time... need more room for sushi.  I recommend the ICHIbeer too, which went very well with the meal.  Overall, we left full, satisfied, and still wanting more.

With both the service and food being spot on, ICHI lives up to its deserved reputation. We'll definitely be back... but just need the wallet reserves to recover.
author: Mercutio k.

description: I'm afraid this place has really gone downhill of late. I used to always think the fish was fabulous, but lately a bit bland.  Worst of all, I ate here a couple of nights ago, and the sushi chef refused to give me any soy sauce!  They have their "rules" about how to each sushi on the wall, including no sou sauce, but really?  Even if the customer asks?  Ridiculous SF restaurant "attitude" strikes again!
author: Eric W.

description:
Great sushi and great service. 

Dinner for 2 was very reasonable (you can get by with around $40 per person).  We got some nigiri ($4-$12) that were well seasoned and fresh.  Also got some carpaccio with apples, grilled fish collar (yum! but shockingly came with a whole fish head, not just the collar), chicken skewers (would pass on this next time, didn't have the fragrant charcoal flavor).  For dessert, the soymilk panna cotta with yuzu gelee was refreshing and light.  Waitress noticed that we had ordered too much food and stopped by to ask before firing the okonomiyaki (because she says it's very large).  That was very nice of her, and we were indeed too full to order it.  Would definitely come back!
author: T Y.

description: Ichi kills it in every arena. Super fresh, thoughtful presentations; a perfect balance between classic and creative. Can't wait to get back to SF to feast again.
author: Bird C.

description: The fish is fresh and the service was very friendly.  The sushi was a little overproduced to my taste. For example they do things like put a small amount of shiso between some fish slices and the rice. For another example, in some cases the edge of the fish had been seared. With fish of this very high quality I would prefer a more standard treatment and a saucer of soy.  So five stars for service and quality of ingredients 3 stars for preparation.  Average four stars.
author: Matthew A.

description: I live in Bernal Heights and have been going to Ichi since they were a small hole in the wall. Unfortunately, I was completely turned off this week by their new policy requiring a credit card for any reservation and will charge $25 per person if you cancel within 24 hours of your reservation. I can understand this for large groups, but I have never heard of this for dinner for 2. If cancellations is a problem, maybe they should start accepting same-day reservations. I've been going to Ichi since they were the neighborhood sushi place and it's a shame to see the changes Tim and his team are making. Yes, their sushi is good but there are a number of other great sushi restaurants in SF like Tataki South down the street.
author: Dan M.

description:
Sure the vibe is cool and the fish is fresh but what's missing is taste.  I'm guessing the rice to fish ratio was a tad bit in favor of carbs.  I also think there could have been some creativity in putting together these rolls - adding spices, playing with textures, etc.  Of course, I'm comparing all sushi joints to my dining experiences in LA.  Food just tastes better there.

The positives:  the Toro hand roll (not on the menu) was delicious and came closest to satisfying my tastebuds.  The soy sauce was special.  And the yellow tail melt in my mouth.

I can't see myself going back here when I have Sushi Tomi down the street.
author: Arash M.

description: Saturday night, no reservations, we sat at the bar in the back. We were greeted by Ken the bartender who recommended Sake new to us. It was wonderful, sort of cherry blossom-like. He also recommended items from each category on the menu. He spent time talking w/us as though we were his only customers while pouring us samples of other Sakes and touting their virtues.  One of the best dining experiences we've had.  Will definitely go back and recommend it highly.
author: Dori R.

description:
The food was good -- good enough for my friends and I to enjoy while we catch up. Yuzu fried chicken wings were my favorite (in addition to pickled cucumber)! The sake was very smooth -- I definitely wanted to try some more.

The only thing that annoyed the entire dinner was that you cannot order food from Ichi Sushi if you are seating at the Ni Bar (even though they are not really separated). It could have been very nice if the host told me that there are separate menus before I cancelled the reserved table.
author: K C.

description: Best sushi I've ever had.  Sat at the counter for omakase and it was truly amazing.  Really delicious sushi. Well crafted sushi rice for the perfect complement. My server/chef was chatty and really tried to figure out what I'd like best.  Interspersed with the amazing nigiri were some wonderful special items like broiled fish collar.  Great sake suggestions.  This would be a great place for a date or a business dinner.   Every member of the staff made me feel welcome.  Fun, hip decor.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Erin W.

description: If you want to have a plate of rice for $20 - this is the place to go. Service is ok but their chirashi don is such a ripoff. Plate of rice with a couple microscopic pieces of fish, some roe and cucumber. Doesn't worth $18 price tag at all.
author: Roman S.

description: I absolutely love this place! Fresh fish and the service does a great job with recommendations. The one thing I don't like is the waiting (my bf and I waited once and hour for a table on a Wednesday night, it's always packed) and reservations are not possible. But everything else is amazing!!
author: Julia K.

description: This place was an amazing mix of fun lively atmosphere and amazing sushi. It is about the sushi served very simply and elegantly because the fish and the flavor is the star. It's packs and very trendy but the food served is not trendy it's amazing and simple and good and fun and all the things it should be, it's a nod to the fish. Eat with your hands, fish down on your tongue and experience the flavor, the texture, and the bite.
author: Jill T.

description: Sat at the bar in the back at Ni and had a delicious glass of Almanac Gose and a chef's choice skewer plate (one each: mushroom, beef, pork, chicken). Excellent late night snack.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Best Sushi place in town! Great fish, great izakaya, great drinks, great people, great vibe.

If you can't make it in at the dining room, try the Ni Bar in back. It's not the full menu but there is still some sushi and fantastic appetizers.

We go almost every week!
author: Tony P.

description: The sushi at ICHI is overall okay albeit on the pricey side. The fish selection is good, of high quality, and the portion size of the negiri is correct (one bite). Kind of surprised that they don't offer an oshibori (hot towel) before the meal. Or perhaps they ran out the night I ate there? The sushi rice was, unfortunately, the big flaw in their sushi. The sushi rice was cold (grabbed from uninsulated containers), and a bit too much pressure applied when forming the negiri. Sushi is sauced (soy sauce) by the chef, and patrons aren't given access to additional dipping soy sauce. Only at the top sushi places in Japan do they engage in this method of sushi presentation, and I think it's pretty arrogant of ICHI to ape this practice. Overall, though, probably the best sushi available in Bernal Heights/Mission.
author: Theo K.

description: an amazing deal for omakase; definitely sit at the bar! great quality, fresh fish & very friendly sushi chefs. trendy & fun environment.
author: Parastou B.

description: The name Ichi Sushi might sound funny to some people but not to a sushi lover like me. Never have I thought that I will experience with such an amazing new style of sushi in my entire night. I couldn't even keep a count of the total number of sushi I had last night. The chef had his very own version of the nigiri which is by far the best one I have ever tried.
author: Pancho M.

description: I've had Omakase three times now and each has been an incredible experience. The nigiri is perfect and the small plates are great. Get a reservation a few weeks in advance, sit at the sushi bar, and let them amaze you!
author: Max E.

description: Meh. Paid $100+ per person for Omakase. It was decent with some great pieces, but overall wasn't impressed. This said, you get a lot of sushi so that kind of makes up for it.
author: Dwight C.

description:
Finally got reservations here!  We haven't visited since they moved and expanded to Ichi Ni.  We had super fond memories at their original location, in fact I went around telling friends + others it's the best sushi in SF.  Well...Ichi Ni isn't quite how we remembered our experience but I would like to say the sushi is fresh and different from what you'd get at your average Japanese / sushi restaurant.  We were fortunate to sit at the sushi bar and had to order the omakase.  We had 12 pieces - baby yellowtail, amaebi + mackerel from Japan - probably the best fresh mackerel I've ever had, Hokkaido uni, and it goes on were the most unique.  Something about the rice didn't seem on par - I couldn't put my finger on it.  I wish there was more seasoning on some of our pieces like how I remembered at Ichi.  We tried 2 hot dishes - sea bass collar which was pretty basic but the sushi chef recommended it.  I probably wouldn't order this again.  The 2nd was the chicken meatballs that you dip in a egg yolk with green onions and this was on point.  Super moist and really tasty - I recommend trying.  

If we ever do make it back I hope to see in Tim's corner.  I think this would make the experience more enjoyable.
author: Meredith K.

description:
SUSHI:  4-stars.  flavorful and fresh.  but incredibly pretentious sushi chefs who are quick to judge you for not eating it exactly as they would prefer you to.

SEATING:  2-stars.  hostess says the wait is 45 minutes for walk-in and they will text when the table is ready.  we comply and walk out to grab a beverage and prepare to wait.  a phone call comes in 10 minutes later informing us the table is ready.

BAR:  3-stars.  awkward bartender.  limited selection.

SUSHI CHEFS:  2-stars.  quick to judge and roll their eyes at you if you don't follow the unwritten rules of sushi eating.  not welcoming, uncomfortable, forced conversation.

SERVER:  2-stars.  only approached us three times; 1)  mid-meal to ask if i needed another beer,  2) refilling the water and nearly spilled the whole bottle on me, 3) when handing us the check.

MUSIC:  1-star.  insanely loud, inappropriate.  the sushi chef couldn't hear our orders and missed several items.  i think they even played "hot in herre" by nelly?

AMBIANCE:  2-stars.  i really don't want to hear all the employees shouting "irasshaimase" every time someone walks in.  the decor is clean, modern but very sterile and uncomfortable.

TOTAL AVG:  2.3 stars
author: E. R.

description: I've finally had a chance to sit at the new sushi bar a few times and the food and service is just as good as ever. The best way to experience Ichi is to sit at the bar and order omakase (the chef will choose your meal for you). Also, the yuzu chicken wings are a must try.
author: Aaron V.

description: Nothing short of amazing. Sushi is one of my favorite treats and Ichi takes it to a whole other level. Sit at the bar and order the omakase, it is not to be missed.
author: Kristofer J.

description: OMG! I admit to being 1) a gavon who will eat almost anything salty, and 2) A friend of the owner, but DAYUM is that food good!!!!! Even the simple things like Shiitake skewers and the cocktails which compliment the food are above par. I live only to eat there once more.
author: Jim F.

description: Just got home from a meal of mediocre sushi and crazy over-priced sake ($18 for house hot sake - yeah, that's house hot sake we're talking about). Atmosphere was lacking. The service was friendly but a bit slow. There are many other options around the city that give a way better performance for the amount of money spent. All in all, a disappointing experience.
author: erin l.

description: This seems to be my first review on yelp. It was so bad that forced me to post something here. We found this place on a 100 restaurant list(obviously). I suppose they spent some money on the marketing. the food was so so.  the waitress were okay. But the waiting part was horrible. And it's sooo expensive.. How dare they charge so much with such bad service? We were waiting there for about more than two hours just to got a few pieces of sushi.... If you are hungry you would be starved there. This is the worst part of my pride weekend!!!! I highly recommend you not to go...
author: Wenyuan F.

description: Came here on a Thursday night and it was pretty busy.  We ordered a few nigris and sashimis which were very good.  In particular I really enjoyed the Ocean Trout, the Maguro and the Toro (The Toro was excellent and by far the best).  The wagyu was a little dissapointing, it was a little tough and chewy. I think they may have overcooked it a little bit.  The sushi is very fresh and they had a nice selection of daily specials.  If you're looking for veggies, get the eggplant.  Although the sushi was overall very good, I wouldn't say its the best in the city.  Its a great place to go if you're around the neighborhood but I would probably go elsewhere since I do not live that close to this place.
author: Darren W.

description: We walked into Ichi on a random Saturday evening looking for good sushi and were surprised to find there were two open seats at the sushi bar with the head sushi chef. We ordered omakase and the fish was very fresh and quite unlike any other sushi I've tried. Each piece is flavored and seasoned perfectly, and with each one, our sushi chef gave us some tidbits of trivia about what we were eating, which made for delightful conversation with our dinner. Overall, this was the best omakase in SF and well worth the trek out to Bernal Heights to experience it.
author: Kevin L.

description: If you wanted to go out to dinner and find a fun spot with a great crowd and good drinks then let me tell you...look somewhere else. This was one of the most disappointing meals I've had in San Francisco and I eat out a lot. Completely uncreative sushi that all tastes the same, mediocre nigiri and they're too pretentious to offer dessert. There are so many outstanding sushi places in the city, don't even think about coming here. Feels like a poor man's Roka Akor
author: Mike M.

description: Best sushi I've had in San Francisco. Lets start with the draft Sapporo, amazing. All of their sushi is paired with a sauce and/or garnish that really elevates the flavor of the fish. Their spicy scallop roll has a really nice smoky flavor. Unpretentious atmosphere and good size restaurant for groups if you make a reservation. Prices aren't bad for sushi.
author: Jillian N.

description: We had omakase here and, it exceeded all my expectations. My friend said he was there with the owner as their omakase chef, and noted it was better. I can't possibly imagine how much better it could've been. There were some pieces of nigiri with fish that I had never heard of... They were so delicious! I can't wait to go back. I hear their happy hour is pretty rad...
author: Jen H.

description: We went there on vacation because all the positive reviews. For all the hype and people inside saying it was the best ever eating next to us from the area, it was the biggest let down ever and apparently they have never eaten quality sushi. The sushi was mid grade above gas stations and Safeway but would struggle against a good Sushi restaurant if that. we were given warm tap watter in used wine bottles, the music was so loud we couldn't talk,  and overall it was a hipster atmosphere more than a sushi restaurant,  and the bathrooms were so filthy it made us cringe.
author: Michael M.

description: I'm sure this place is still good, but got a little too pretentious!! 1.5 hour wait, seriously?!! Great sushi but not worth the wait!  Think the staff is in over their heads.
