It's one of many good sushi spots in the city, know your roots and keep it real!  Going to some place more real!!
author: Gene R.

description:
It all started in the wrong way. 
We sat at the bar ( awful position for a bar ). The bartender was not looking comfortable at all. After we asked her a suggestion for a sake, she gave it to us but never came back to ask if we liked it (unacceptable from a professional)
The hostess "almost" pretended to be friendly and caring.
Once we sat at the table, we had to wait 9 minutes to receive the menu ( mind that it was not in the rush of service ). 
The food from the kitchen was good. Didn't blow my mind but properly prepared. 
The sushi was absolutely disappointing. 
Definitely overpriced ( even the not so exotic items )
The rice seemed cooked in rush. Or at least I hope for them, otherwise ....
It does happened that if you get super busy, you need to cook rice in the middle of service. Good luck !
Bottom line, seating at the table was disappointing. Wait staff not prepared. Busers very polite. From far, it seems that the sushi men are proper: people seemed entertained. 
I will not go back.
author: Bruno S.

description: If you have cash to drop, go for the Omakase (chef's choice nigiri) and never look back. Next level. Sit at the sushi bar. The chefs make your bites one at a time; you eat your bites one at a time. "No soy sauce required"
author: C. S.

description: I think the mural is weird and the music is too loud but this is the best sushi I've ever had.
author: Cate L.

description:
The fish wasn't fresh. On a Thursday night, our maguro and ocean trout sashimi had that old, fishy taste to them. In fact, we maybe should have guessed from the fishy smell when we walked into the place.

It wasn't all bad -- the beef tataki was excellent, and the hotate and wakame salad were fine -- but bad fish at a sushi restaurant is the cardinal sin. Sorry to say I won't be back.
author: Charlie Bolognese Z.

description: This place is too amazing for words. The omakase experience is a delicious and otherworldly experience for your tastebuds.
author: Jaci H.

description: Food's great here. What isn't is the consistently snobby treatment. Some of the rudest waitstaff I've dealt with in this city, no question. Bad enough for me to just not want to eat here again despite the food.
author: Munaf A.

description:
We were blown away by our experience here. We sat at the sushi bar and did the omakase. 

We were very impressed by the thought and effort that went into preparing each piece of sushi. Each piece had a unique and wonderful flavor.
author: Alissa D.

description:
This place is a great addition to the neighborhood. The space accommodates a lot of folks, much bigger than many sushi places, which makes getting a last minute seat pretty easy. The decor is modern/contemporary, and warm with lots of beautiful wood, black and white. The place has high ceilings and has the chance of being really loud when busy, but it was fine when we were there in early evening.

The food was delicious. My husband had the aji mackerel, which was the first mackerel he ever liked. He also had clams with pork, which he said were delicious. We also had a few rolls, which were tasty -  spicy scallop and yellowtail. The fish tasted really fresh -  always a plus at sushi. We also had oysters. They were only OK- kind of overpowered with flavor so we couldn't get the taste of the oysters themselves much. 

All in all, we will likely be back
author: Erin M.

description: Amazing nigiri and a great experience if you sit at the bar. Our sushi chef Darren was so interesting and talented. Some of the best nigiri we've ever had!
author: Lydia G.

description: If you like typic Japanese place with an American twist, this the perfect spot. With a good sake collection.
author: David M.

description:
Went to dinner here on Saturday. We have a 7:45 reservation but were not seated until  8:15. Wasn't a huge deal because we were catching up with friends and just went over to the bar, but kind of annoying that it took them 30minutes to seat us.

We opted for the omakase and a lot of sake. It wasn't a ton of food, but the bites were all really delicious and the fish was super fresh. For $100/person, I would expect more food though. I really liked the tuna tartare that we stated with and a lot of the negiri was good, but they don't give you soy sauce or wasabi, which I was missing with some of the bites.

It was fun to check this place out, but I don't think I would go back.
author: Jessica W.

description: I was a huge fan of Ichi in its old location (now the fantastic Ichi Kakiya) and this new location is somehow even better.  The highest quality everything.  Incredibly delicious.  Go omakase and don't look back!
author: chris c.

description: Ichi is the best!  The sushi is fresh and delicious and the oysters are near perfect.  They've ruined me for all other sushi.  Damn their deliciousness!  The new space is much bigger than the old one and the place is always buzzing.  They also brew their own beer called Ichibier which is also quite good.  It's perfect with their fried chicken wings.
author: el r.

description: Delicious food with delicious bubbles. Does it get any better? It's hard to want to eat sushi anywhere else after coming here. Three words. Golden eye snapper you are dreamy. That was six words. Oh well....
author: La B.

description:
I really should be giving this place 1 star since at least 2 of us were sick as hell all night following this overpriced mediocre eating experience. But where to start, So we get there my party of 3 waiting on the 4th and of course even though we are on time our table isnt ready. but whatever it is friday night I have been in the restaurant industry for the past 20 years I understand weekends can get rough. We get sent back to the back bar to wait we sit down in a stool made for a thin child crammed together so tight to the table behind us its like playing tetris to sit down. We sit and the lady bartender has her back to us wile she "pours" tap drinks with her cell phone in her hand and doesnt turn around for ten minutes. And the bar is packed she probably lost 100 dollars ignoring her clients whatever I didnt come her to drink anyway. We eventually get saporo's they arent especially cold or good. We get called to our table which ends up being sushi bar seats with even smaller stools i think if thats even possible, they are unbalanced and extremely uncomfortable. It is hard for me to believe some restaurant designer decided to choose these if they actually tried them out ever.
We get seated and our menus, i already know we are gonna get f$%#ed, skewers, hot menu, steak sushi, I hate fusion. The sushi menu is equally frustrating once I realize each order is for a single piece of sushi. Honestly their pricing for single pieces rival real for star places in the bay that never make mistakes and offer you 2 pieces per order. I really regret not sticking up for myself and and ordering individual pieces over the omikase which the other members of my party picked. What is really messed up is that they have no set price for the omikase even at the end everything is individually priced u may as well order individually or the just order for u and all one piece at a time. I work hard all week I dont like to eat one piece every 15 minutes as my end of week reward. 
And of course we get the one white chef, listen I am white I am a restaurant worker I am not trying to be prejudice, but I like a traditional feel from my experience and a white guy who tells me how he learned to prepare sushi by working there and never had any formal culinary training is pretty disappointing considering what they were charging. I also like to my sushi chef to act a certain way. Dancing around and doing the madonna vogue dance when a bad eighties pop song comes on is incredibly disappointing to me and if you dance like this in front of patrons your taste cant be good.
I order a side of rice from the hot food waitress she never brings it, but of course I get charged for it.
The fish selection wasnt impressive, Most had mediocre fresh flavors, I hate when they sear the top i dont understand the point unless its eel, it just makes it taste fishier. They sear a piece of steak for one course and drape it over rice and call it sushi I dont think it is. Its not even tasty. They dont give u wasabi or soy sauce here...I dont even know what to say about that. I dont especially like pickled ginger but I ended up eating three stacks because they sushi comes out so damn slow.
Honestly the best part of the meal is the chef choice skewers we got that wasnt on the omikase menu all that stuff was real good. Also the toro we requested as our last piece of fish was excellent although we had to pick it for the chef who didnt figure to include it our omikase naturally. which makes me seriously question his judgement. 
I could really get into the individual pieces but whats the point. These new hip hop playing fusion spots without any real interior design or traditional sushi  values really turn my stomach even when the bad quality fish doesn't. 
I told my fellow patrons they never get to pick the friday night restaurant again if they expect me to roll with them. I honestly just dont get spending money like this on such a weak experience. I just dont get this town sometimes and what the citizens of it are willing to except....
author: Bob C.

description:
Dropped in Ichi on Saturday night for omakase at the Ichi sushi bar. We had a resy for 9:30 and arrived on time, but had to wait about 15 minutes for 2 spaces to open up at the sushi bar. With open seats at the Ni bar in the back this didn't bother us one bit as we sat drinking a pint of Hitachino until a spot opened up at the Ichi bar. The atmosphere is more trendy than traditional, but the sushi although modernized with their spin isn't just hype. This is not your traditional Japanese sushi place, so traditionalists would probably not like it, but if you want a modernized spin on sushi then Ichi fits the bill. I also respect that they don't give you soy sauce and a bunch of wasabi at the sushi bar so you can make some horrendous concoction of wasabi soy sauce to overpower your sushi. People who are complaining about how the sushi chefs want you to eat the sushi the way they have prepared it make me laugh. You want to dress up your crunchy roll go to another spot. 

We started with a cucumber salad and ordered a bottle of Hakkaisan Junmai Ginjo Sake. Every piece of nigiri hit the spot and the combination of flavors and creativity are on point. Our sushi chef Eric walked us through about 12 different pieces of nigiri and one piece of cod collar. I would say the only piece that missed the mark was the tako (octopus), it was a little tough which can be common in octopus if you don't work it before you prepare it. Since dinner resys are hard to come by, I never understand the people that come to a sushi place and order california rolls and chicken teriyaki. The people wearing their scarves inside sitting next to us kept glaring at all the assorted cuts of fish the sushi chef was handing to us feeling jelly that they went with the california roll.
author: Anthony V.

description: Last 2 times I have visited San Francisco we have eaten there. The first time was literally a life changing experience. It was the best sushi I have ever had. Everything was excellent. The second time we went we took the kids and although they like sushi a lot they didn't really like the sushi here. Nothing against ICHI Sushi, just there really isn't anything plain there, so not good for kids, but wow, excellent for everyone else. Can't wait to go again, but without the kids. Everyone is super nice too - Tim the owner, Cheyenne the hostess and Shasta our server. They really made great impressions since I actually remember their names.
author: Niki A.

description: Couldn't have been more pleased!  Everything was outstanding.  The food was amazing!  Chef Tim has brought the art of food preparation to a whole new level - and that's saying a lot when it comes to San Francisco Sushi restaurants.  The staff were friendly and attended to every need.   This place is simply awesome!
author: Bruce B.

description:
Reading reviews here it is hard to know what about many restaurants that attract the diverse and contentious crowd of people who might later post their thoughts on Yelp. Nonetheless, wading through the absolutist partisans and enemies of a place like this one is left with a certain amount of anxiety, even fear; can ANY place live up to the expectations - positive or negative - expressed on a forum like this? I doubt it.

In any case, we dived in, sitting at the bar and going for a joy ride. Our chef (in the station next to the boss man), was amiable, solicitous, and seemingly competent. He asked us if we had any things we wouldn't want to miss or anything we particularly didn't want, and then proceeded to produce a fairly steady stream of nigiri from the fish under the glass in front of us. 

Without referencing any other sushi venue in the city, or indeed without mentioning any sushi place I have ever been anywhere, and even without worrying about anything that the restaurant's owners might or might not have said about the food, their concept, or anything else, but just letting the seafood and rice speak for itself, we can pronounce ourselves fairly satisfied with the experience, and left  with a good taste in our mouths, happy to have taken the time to visit the place.

On the plus side, the fish, scallops, and shrimp we had were served in pretty interesting ways, tasted fresh, and while not truly plentiful in portion, were not stingy, either; the drinks service was conscientious and, as mentioned, the sushi chef was attentive and eager to please. There was lots of good tasting sushi.

On the down side, much of the sushi, despite being fish of different species, for instance, all tasted the same. It is really hard to understand this given that I have never experienced this anywhere else. I have to wonder if it is not somehow a function of the drive to make of the experience eating here some kind of ritual of sushi "purity", whatever that might be. Our chef offered in passing when setting down our first nigiri that it was "seasoned the way it was supposed to be" or something similar; of course, since we had heard that Ichi does not brook the use of extra wasabi and soy sauce, this aside was absorbed without comment, and even with some pleasurable anticipation. But the fact is that all the effort then to make the sushi "special" really just boiled down to applying a fairly narrow range of seasonings (including various ponzu concoctions, a number of spicy or salty condiments, etc. - and none of them bad, mind you) to whatever fish was on hand, without, it seemed, any particular thoughtfulness about why that particular combination might be especially apt. 

Our conclusion was that in a perhaps misguided attempt to pursue something like "perfection" the concept of honest ingredients of the highest possible quality was somehow distorted by a penchant for novelty for its own sake. Our chef was, as far as we could tell, following a playbook as rigid as that which controls every action of a burger flipper at Mickey D's; instead of a spontaneous interaction between the chef, the materials, and us, we got a fussy, preset packaging of the fish of the day which ultimately produced something akin to mass production, even though, I will happily add, it was all pretty darn good.

We thought that perhaps by combining this level of passion and skill with something less self-conscious and more open-hearted, this place really might have a chance of becoming the "best" sushi place in the City, whatever that means instead of a 3+ star novelty with potential...
author: Ken K.

description:
I'm fairly new to sushi and sake and usually order the basic California Roll at sushi places - to play it safe. But....I went to ICHI ready to try new things.  We sat at the sushi bar - best place to sit in my opinion! The waitress came over to take our drink orders and offered sake from their list.  I told her that I wasn't a big fan of sake and she brought me a taste of something that non-sake drinkers like.  The sake I've had from sushi places usually ends up tasting like nail polish remover but the sake she brought me was tasty! 
The chef started us with a cucumber salad which was very crisp, fresh, and tasty!
The chef was very nice and knowledgeable and made us the sushi piece by piece and didn't rush us.  The mural they have fits perfectly in the mission district and it serves as an educational piece about sushi and sushi etiquette.  The colors, decor, style and design were so chic and contemporary.  
I went to ICHI to get an education about sushi and Japanese food and I got one! Thank you for that ICHI! The barracuda was my favorite!!
author: Taylor M.

description:
What an incredible WIN for our neighborhood!  I have always considered myself a 'boring' sushi eater until I let ICHI lead the way.   Our waitress recommended the order in which we should eat the fish, and it was all so smooth.  I left literally wanting more, and almost went back the same night so that my partner could partake.  

The owners and staff are warm, and I'm happy to wait for something tasty!
author: Katie H.

description: What a fantastic place for omakase, and reasonably priced, too! Tadashi-san was our sushi chef, and he was an absolute delight.
author: Karl K.

description: Forget the haters. This is easily some of the best sushi and service you will have in the Bay Area. The food was exquisite, the sake was unforgettable, and the service blew me away. Come here, and come here often.
author: Alexander S.

description: I eat sushi A LOT, and was excited to try this spot after it made the Easter 38 list. What a disappointment. The sushi was SO dry it was uncomfortable to eat. Honestly - it was so unpleasant, my husband and I ended our Omakase order halfway through. Not sure if it was a rough night for the chef or what. I'm really confused, because people seem to love this place. Definitely won't be back (nor will I recommend to any of my friends.)
author: Alison P.

description: expensive for the portions. But good service and the decor and ambience are nice. it's best to make reservations as it gets busy pretty quickly.
author: Xteethx B.

description:
Yes. Ichi sushi! This is my favorite sushi place in San Francisco. it just dazzles. It's fresh and flavorful and simple - no gimmicks or heavy sauces needed. 

Other dishes, such as the cucumber salad, deserve the same descriptors - fresh, flavorful and simple. Worth the drive (assuming you don't live in the neighborhood). Also, you can walk to Mitchell's afterwards for ice cream (and who doesn't want ice cream after a sushi dinner?)
author: D Z.

description: The food was good, excellent even but the service was incredibly slow - 2 hours for dinner...and most of it waiting for the next small plate to come out. Seats incredibly uncomfortable: my wife and I took turns walking around the restaurant after our bums fell asleep. Also, massively overpriced.
author: Tim B.

description: I must say, when I found out that my former favorite sushi spot in the city had closed, I was pretty bummed. Then, I ate here. Honestly, if you like sushi, just sit down and ask for omakase. You will not be disappointed. Everything is super fresh and expertly prepared, and each dish is a journey. Make reservations!!
author: Leland B.

description: Booooh. No reason to go here when so many wonderful Bay Area choices. Paid $100 per couple and still left hungry. Was difficult to find the fish in some of the rolls. $20 house hot sake ..really?! Nothing remotely special about this spot.  Nice space and staff but spend your sushi money somewhere else.
author: S O.

description: Very expensive Sushi Restaurant? Or maybe just restaurant. We had a table of 5 sitting on the most uncomfortable high chairs. We ate $ 50.00 per person and still hungry. The fish was good but the toppings just killed it. The flavors where all off balance.  The skewers had no taste or to salty. Take my advice and save your money and try a different Japanese restaurant.
author: donald t.

description: We came here for drinks and snacks on a Friday and ended up appropriately sitting at the bar in the Ni bar side of things. The atmosphere of the place was less than stellar - a little cold, IMO. The food was good but value ratio a little off. Drinks were okay - selection is on the smaller side. Service was friendly but slow. Would like to come back for dinner to get a better sense of the place, but am not really in any hurry.
author: Megan S.

description: Ichi has never failed us - the fish is always fresh, service impeccable, flavors perfectly balanced, and I would trust the omakase selections any day.  I've had sushi all over the Bay Area, and this place is always one of our very tops.  It's just hard to get in sometimes because they are so darn good!  And let's not forget the proprietors, Tim and Erin Archuleta.  They are amazing.  Love, love, love.
author: Mandy T.

description: Fan-f*ckin-tastic.  I'm unbelievably lazy, so you better believe it takes quite a bit to get me out to Bernal Heights.  The fish was to die, and prices were surprisingly reasonable.  Service was top notch.  Zero complaints.  Actually, one-- they had no dessert.  But it wasn't a big deal bc Mitchell's is literally around the corner.
author: DarkwingDick _.

description: Their sushi is incredibly fresh. The nigiri is mind blowing although the seaweed wraps can be a little chewy. Their rolls are really good too, though same problem with the seaweed. The sake list is amazing, though, and sooooo tasty!!!
author: Caitlin R.

description: READ THE WHOLE REVIEW BEFORE YOU EAT HERE! Really underwhelmed with their service. Ambiance was alright. I mean I really like the food that they served us except my friends and I had one problem, they double charged us with two of our orders. We just noticed it when we got home. We couldn't do anything about but beware guys, CHECK YOUR RECEIPT BEFORE YOU LEAVE. I would recommend one of the itamaes(sushi chef), Darren( I think), was really friendly and nice. He went into detail with every nigiri that he served and he answered most of our questions, and really friendly too! The reason why I'm giving them two stars is because the service wasn't that great, the place didn't even have a sign that says Ichi Sushi + Ni bar, and we got double charged with two of the food that we ordered. BUT THE FOOD IS REALLY GREAT! I had most of the nigiri and it was really good. Their skewers and pork belly was awesome and their trout skin roll and spicy scallops rolls was good. I would recommend this place for their food, but I just hope that their service will improve.
author: Carlos L.

description: I'm on the fence between 2 and 3 stars for this place, however, the price point thats being charged here for mediocre sushi makes me lean towards 2 stars.  Ichi clearly aspires to be a cut above your average strip-mall soy sauce & wasabi california roll factory.  Its a noble goal.  Sadly, they fall pretty short.    Upon entering, my first impression was a strong sense of deja-vu.  The layout felt very chipotle-esque.  It can be quite charming, if somewhat uncomfortable, when the entire staff of a japanese restaurant shouts out greetings in unison.  Honestly, it just feels like they're trying way too hard when a dozen white people do this in Japanese.  Of course, this is all relatively trivial in comparison to the food.  Good food goes a long way.  Unfortunately, the sushi was pretty disappointing.  Flavors tended to be heavy handed, often unbalanced, and all too often totally overwhelmed the fish.  The fish was, at times, of inconsistent texture - soft at one end, a bit chewy at the other.  Honestly, I had low, albeit hopeful, expectations at the outset.  SF is not known as a great sushi destination.  Generally speaking, I like what they are trying to do here.  I just dont think that they're doing it particularly well.  They certainly arent delivering much value at this price point.  Take my advice - save your money, make reservations at Kuskabe and prepare for a truly inspired japanese meal.
author: Alex L.

description: Delicious and fresh sushi in a hipster location.  I loved the fact that most of the sushi was already marinated or accompanied by some sort of spice.  The service was also impeccable.
author: Kingman G.

description: Awesome omakase experience. The prep time and creativity makes this place truly unique.
author: Samantha K.

description: Delicious! So good! Been hearing about this place for two years and it totally lives up to its rep. So fresh and savory -- definitely get the omakase. But please beware of the bartender on weekends. I waited 10 minutes to order a glass of wine and then he was churlish, cranky and cruel. I can't believe such a lovely establishment wouldn't train that man in basic hospitality.
author: Jeremy G.

description: OMG, this is how sushi should always be eaten. My date and I sat at the sushi bar which are the best seats in the house although I'd eat off the ground because the place is so clean. The staff has nothing but class, and I have to add the ichi beer is amazing! We went with Omakase 'chef choice' and it was all mind-blowing. If someone asks you to go..... Go! You won't regret it
author: Keenan J.

description: Sake and fusion dishes not justified by price. Not for the experienced sashimi/sushi consumer. All hype. Much better quality for reasonable price elsewhere.
author: Terry C.

description:
Last Monday was my 2nd time eating at ICHI with my husband. The first time we ate there was a year ago and we brought a friend who was visiting from LA. We had such a good experience and the food was tasty and memorable. This new visit however was memorable for far different reasons. We did not have a reservation, but arrived right when they opened and there was already and hour and 45 minute wait, so the less than hospitable hostess asked if we would like to sit at the bar. We decided yes, but she told us we could not order nigiri at the bar...when we asked why she didn't really seem sure herself. So we sat at the bar anyway and ordered away! The  bartender took our order down (in her head) then came back twice to review our order with us, she apologized and exclaimed "Sorry I am on a lot of dayquil right now." That was an off-putting and confusing response. We also asked her why we couldn't order nigiri at the bar and she said "because the sushi bar can't keep up with the orders." 

The food took ages to come to our table and finally we asked our dayquil sedated bartender if our sushi was coming..She then ran to the sushi bar to get it and gave it to us. We asked for some soy sauce and she said ok, then started pouring drinks and completely ignored us. We each took a bite and nearly spit it up. If you have ever eaten warm sushi it isn't a pleasant taste. We immediately asked her if it had been sitting out for a while because it was warm and she insanely replied, "I don't know, I can't see through the wall." I can honestly go on and on about how terrible the service was, the lack of hospitality, and the lack of deliciousness from the food, but I think it is quite clear this was a less than average dining experience. The tattooed inhospitable bartender needs to really be taught a lesson in service and overall decent hospitality skills.  

I feel bad that ICHI has taken a turn for the worse, because it is such a rad place in a great location and my first memory was a great one. 

Hospitality is everything and there was none at all. I hope ICHI is able to instill a sense of hospitality in their employees because no matter how good the food is, the service will always have a far lasting affect on people. People always remember how a restaurant made them feel, and they made us feel terrible.

I absolutely hate writing bad reviews, but it was an experience I wish I could forget. I give it 2 stars and not 1, because the first time I came it wasn't that bad...so I thought I would give them the benefit of the doubt.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Service = ZERO.  
I was initially excited to try this place, as it's in my neighborhood, and a friend OK'ed it prior.  Anyway, walking in noticed that every server and kitchen worker, outside of the Sushi chef was an Etsy-ish mid 20s caucasian... no Japanese at this Sushi place, either in the staff, or the clientele.  No worries, it's California, and good food usually translates.
So, my wife, son and I got the last table at the bar and grill area. Unlike most 5-8 year olds, my son loves himself some Sushi, but we were told by the server that the bar side he couldn't have anything from the sushi menu, as the Sushi chefs were too busy, and they don't serve that menu on this side of the restaurant.  Fine, I said, we'll order from that menu, but I asked if I can I get a sheet of Nor for my son to use with his rice, so that he can be placated by 'rolling his own' rice and seaweed maki with a sheet of nori, while his mom and dad enjoy an adult night out at the same time? Nope, says the restaurant... not allowed. 
Despite the fact we are about to drop $200 on a meal, the management wouldn't budge on the kid-friendly aspect of giving my kid a sheet of seaweed from the sushi bar... the waitress asked the manager, the manager said "no". So, after a quick deliberation, we decided that we'd try a more kid flexible place. Just as we were leaving, they finally served us a beer we had put an order in for earlier. We refused it, as we had decided to leave.  They gave us problems, asking us to pay for the beer.  At this point, I just let them know that we didn't want it, and we were leaving. The manager stopped me on the way out, and engaged with me about our leaving... it was way more conflict-y than I would have wanted, and not kid friendly.  I usually don't place a premium on service, but when it's this bad, I have to.  It seems to be sushi for twitter transplants, rather than Bernal Heights families, anyway, but I'll never know at this point, as I couldn't get any service. Hacker Pizza across the street ended up taking us instead.
author: Peter O.

description: Hipster vibe. Manageable sake list. A sushi bar that does omakase. Sushi chefs that look more like a lineup for startup guys. But I rather the waitress not mention that one can get omakase at the table. It turned out that the service is slow and waiting 15 minutes between each 60 seconds of devouring 3 pieces of delicious sushi is not that enjoyable. And P:E ratio is kind of high. We have to go binge on Mitchell's ice cream afterward to fill up.
author: W C.

description: Ichi sushi is amazing. It's expensive, but the Nigiri is to die for. My husband and I did partial omakase (we ordered a few other things, and just had a few courses of Omakase), and the chef explained which part of the fish each piece of Nigiri was from.
author: Berkeley A.

description: We ate at the Ni Bar and the food was very bland. The sushi was average at best and the size of the sushi pieces in one roll were small.
author: Lady w.

description: This place was so underwhelming it's insane. The second you step through the front door it smells like old fish, not a good sign. The waitresses are snobby and terrible, food was beyond forgettable, not sure what people see in this place.
author: Kyle W.

description: A friend and I came in for 7x7s big eats: Omakase which I learned means "tasting menu".  Sushi is one of my favorite meals/ foods, so I was excited. The chef tasting menu is like nothing you will experience anywhere else. The chef literally makes and presents different fish pieces/ rolls/ nigiri, etc for you until you scream mercy. Each piece is drastically different from the last, and every time I professed finding a new favorite, another was placed in front of me- challenging my statement. We sat at the sushi bar, which is the way to go if you're doing the tasting menu, to interact and watch the chef was part of the experience. I cannot say enough good things about this meal--it was expensive, but I felt as though I got every bit of what I paid for. I'd love to go back and do it all over again.
author: Lacy R.

description: I have heard over and over how amazing this place was but never went due to difficulty in getting a reservation. I actually walked in rather late last night and ended up having an amazing experience at the Sushi Bar.  The Chef's Choice Omakase was simply divine. The quality of the fish was extraordinary.  Along the likes of Kusakabe and Maruya.  I will definitely return. If you like sushi, this restaurant is a must!
author: Eric F.

description: What a gem! The service was excellent and the food was better. It gets a little packed but well worth it! The rolls were fantastic and who knew the skewers at a Japanese food place would be soooo good! I can't wait to go back again.
author: Amy S.

description:
I'd give this joint 10 stars if I could. Here's why:
1) The music is BOMB. Go eat tea sandwiches with your mom somewhere else if it's too loud.
2) Erik. Effin. Marinovich. He did the mural. Yeah, that mural.
3) Freshest fish in town!
4) Best sushi chefs you can find (yeah, that means you Erik!)
5) The staff is accommodating and there to help you. Hats off to Shasta for holding it together!
6) In every piece of sushi/sashimi you can taste the freshness of the fish - regardless of what they add to the fish, be it yuzu, soy, scallions, ginger, etc. You taste the FISH in all of it's amazing glory.
7) Best fish collars. For days.
8) The chef/owner Tim comes out and greets us. He's awesome. Maybe even super awesome.
9) They got Almanac to brew them a signature beer. A bay-area beer-brewing darling makes ICHI a special beer! Awww yeah.
10) They make all the other sushi joints seem overpriced for what those other joints offer.

There you have it. 10 points for the ten stars they deserve. If you think they're too expensive or too fancy or too loud or too pretentious or too anything other than awesome then go somewhere else.
author: Eric M.

description:
I LOVE Ichi. The folks who run the place are some of the sweetest I know, and the chefs are incredibly talented. 

My boyfriend and I made a reservation, and were super excited to see the new space. When we showed up, the group ahead of us was just wrapping up so the hostess suggested we have a drink at the bar while we wait. No biggie. The server at the bar was helpful in recommending a sake and we had the Ichi beer, which was full of flavor but refreshing, as well. Then, we went a little crazy ordering from the bar menu: clams, eggplant, chicken wings, cold somen. Everything sounded delicious. I had to remind my bf that we still had omakase to make room for. He was undeterred. He said we could do it. 

Our table at the sushi bar opened up more quickly than we anticipated and before our dishes arrived at the bar in the back. But, the hostess said that they'd get delivered to us at the sushi bar and helped us with our drinks. The seating at the sushi bar is a little squishy but not uncomfortably so. Perhaps the people next to us were just taking over more than their allotted space. Either way, it was cozy, in a good way, for the two of us. 

Our sushi chef, Daniel, introduced himself. We told him we wanted omakase, that we eat any and everything, and that we had ordered a bunch of dishes from the bar already. He said no problem; he'll take good care of us. Then, the influx of food came -- one dish at a time so not overwhelming. The clams with pork was amazing. I wanted a bigger bowl of that. I would eat that all day. The grilled eggplant was super flavorful. The chicken wings were tender and juicy. For the sushi, I can't remember all of what we had because we had so much but the standouts were the scallop (incredibly sweet and buttery), the shrimp two ways (raw body on rice and fried head on the side -- the fried head was delicious; I wish more places served fried shrimp head), and the uni (amazing how something can taste so much like the sea). I was stuffed. I couldn't even eat the last complimentary piece that Daniel put in front of us. 

Everything we had was delicious, exquisitely prepared, and all the nigiri had the right balance of warm rice and cool, perfectly seasoned seafood. I would put a bite in my mouth and just let it sit there for a second before chewing and savoring the flavors and textures. My boyfriend, who I was a little concerned about since he likes dunking his sushi in soy sauce with lots of wasabi, was beyond okay in trusting Daniel. He didn't ask for soy sauce or wasabi, and enjoyed each bite. That's a huge win. 

And, as for the price, it was totally reasonable for how much we ate and drank. So, for the quality and creativity of the food and the attentive but not overbearing service, Ichi is on the top of my list of sushi places in SF.
author: Susan T.

description: Good food! Over priced and  horrible service! With as many people working there you think you would get your food at a reasonable time.  Waited way too long! !
author: Graham K.

description: So good! The service can be a bit slow though. And getting into the restaurant is a nightmare. But the food is good. All the fish is fresh and delicious. Can't get enough of it.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description: Was dying to try the new Ichi...I just loved the old place so much...Was seriously disappointed...A whole different experience. The restaurant is a dark grey room, bar stools where cheap and uncomfortable and crammed together. The service was just ok. Sake and beer selection was no-existent (not even any Nigori)..Very loud, so could barely hear what the chef was handing me.  I must have asked him to repeat himself 10 times....Oysters were overpriced and way to salty...Bring back the Kumamoto oysters..Overall, i would never go back to Ichi, its kinda lost its charm...Its just another SF sushi bar now......
author: John S.

description: New Year's Eve omakase was amazing. The progression was thoughtful and tasteful, culminating in an unbelievable dessert. Highlight was the crab chawanmushi. But also loved the gindara on parsnip purée. The prawn with pickled cukes comes to mind too.  Loved the yuzu sake that was served just before the yummy dessert. Chef Erik outdid himself. What a perfect way to ring out 2014.
author: Linda A.

description: Fantastic omakase, and good sake pairings. Too bad they were out of both Salmon and Uni.
author: Boris C.

description: my friend and i got omakase sushi here last week, and it was tasty.  we sat at the bar, and we had the chef make us whatever he wanted.  the sushi here does not require dipping, as all pieces are already flavored.  we ended up eating most of the specials and then requested a couple other more typical items.  all were good, and the price wasn't too bad.
author: Helen T.

description: Oh man, guys. This place is an experience!  I could go on and on, but suffice it to say that this is - hands down - the best sushi place in the city.  Freshest fish, dishes that allow the diner to really experience the taste of the fish, not dress it up with gross mayo sauces or hose it down with soy sauce.  Be prepared to let the food melt in your mouth. The cocktails and sake are great.  The customer service is friendly, accommodating, and everything I want and need a San Francisco mom and pop to be.  And the prices are absolutely reasonable and a great value for the flavors and fun ambience.  I highly suggest gettin' crazy with the Omakase style and let the chef choose your dishes for you.  During my second visit, we gave the server a per person budget and threw out some favorite fish and flavors of ours. The dinner that followed was extraordinary and, of course, exactly what we were willing to spend.  Plus we learned a lot about dishes that we didn't know before and were served new items that we wouldn't have ordered on our own but are now new favorites.  See what I mean?  A total experience.
author: Kim Lan G.

description: The waitstaff if attentive and courteous, however the food is overpriced and mediocre.  In an area with many quality dining options you can do better than Ichi Sushi.  Take your hard earned elsewhere.
author: Ryan S.

description: As far as I'm concerned, this is the best sushi in town! Yum!
author: Teri G.

description: Born and raised native with a foodie palate... I gotta be honest. This place is a pure rep of gentrification right here. Food is clean, no doubt. But waaaay over priced and nothing crazy mind blowing original. I spent almost$120 for two of us. Full of white folks, with no neighborhood rep whatsoever. And that says something. I had to check to white girls from getting in line at opening bc they thought they could  cut  bc "they had reservations"... that kinda place.  We ordered the house ichibier  ($6), maguro and hamchi  nigiri, chicken wings ($9.50)- beef tataki (14.50)- pork belly (11.50)... cali roll (6.75)... mostsu nikomi (tripe and short rib) ( 11. 75)... tataki we order one Skewer of pork shoulder (3.75) and one Skewer of flank stea (3.75)... seriously everything was good. But really NOT GREAT. To.much cash for the what it is. I would come to just try nigiri and short ribs dish. The service was dope but food took foooorever to come out. Im bummed. Thats a lot of cash to spend on a dinner.
author: Amber M.

description: maybe too much green tea salt on the omakase set. but still very tasty and fresh!
author: Alyssa A.

description: Two of us walked in on a Saturday night at 9pm with no reservation. There were empty tables and we were still told the wait would be an hour. I guess they were honoring reservations even though they didn't all come in. We waited at the bar, and the bartender was awesome - cute, sophisticated and personable, and also helpful with suggestions. Around an hour later, we were offered two seats at the sushi bar. It was well worth the wait. The sushi was delicious and not overpriced. The manager came by and asked how we were doing and apologized for the wait. We didn't have a reservation, so we were fine with waiting. The sushi chef was entertaining and friendly as well. I look forward to returning again - with a reservation!
author: Gina R.

description: Perhaps I am missing something? In my opinion this is overrated, overpriced, hipster sushi.  Top ten sushi in the city? Sorry but I beg to differ.
author: Francisco G.

description:
Had a very good meal here, ordered Omakase, which is apparently the way to go.  I would concur since many of the sushi we received, I would have never known to order. 
Off the hot menu, the chicken wings, were dry and none of us got what the big deal was. They need some sort of sauce to compliment and the beef, was just ok.  Next time I think I'll try the pork belly and the clams, my friends weren't into either.  
We went on a Tuesday at 5:30pm because that was the only time we could get a reservation.  I was baffled during our whole dinner why Open Table said they were so booked and when we called the restaurant directly to see if we could get a 6pm reservation they couldn't accommodate us, but during the entire length of our dinner, at least 2 hours, there were open tables all around us.  I think the hype of it being the best sushi restaurant in the city maybe just that, hype.
However, the food was good and the service excellent with a nice looking space and vibe.  I will go back.  Especially since it's down the street from where I live.
author: Anne S.

description: really good fish, love how the nigiri is seasoned and you don't need soy sauce.  my new favorite sushi place in SF.  only wish it wasn't so loud so as to be able to have a conversation.
author: Yin L.
